    This is a graded discussion: 20 points possible

    Module 1 Discussion: Innovation Processes - IBD Team Members

    From 
    Jan 22 at 3:57pm
    198 198 unread replies. 198 198 replies.

    Part of innovation is taking what you experience, including what you read, and thinking about the missing pieces, the next steps, or just something you are curious about. In each module of PFPS, you will do so with one or more of the readings from that week by considering the application of the concepts in the readings to your own life and work, capturing your thoughts on the Discussions pages in bCourses and responding to your classmates’ posts.

    This week’s introductory readings ask you to consider “design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up” (aka hypothesis-driven entrepreneurship) frameworks, the basic mindsets and capabilities that underlie them and how they might play out in your lives or the organizations you work in.  As you read, think about the parallels and differences among the three approaches to innovation.

    Compose a thoughtful answer to the questions: what are the similarities and differences among “design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up”?  For example, how are the personal skills or mindsets required by each similar or different?  In what ways have the organizations you've worked in supported the development of these skills or mindsets? In what ways might they better support these approaches? Which approaches are likely to be most valuable in the Applied Innovation course you are taking?  What questions do you have about the approaches that you would like to discuss with your classmates?  Be specific in your responses.  

    Post your response, including questions for your classmates, on bCourses and then respond to at least two of your classmates.

    General Guidelines for Discussion: Be thoughtful, constructive and inclusive.  In your responses, be kind, present objections or different points of view open to the possibility that there may be a reasonable response, and object to the responses rather than to the people.  Objections are fine, but you can also choose to be constructive, and you needn't repeat the same objection multiple times.  Be inclusive in your contributions, acknowledging previous contributions, avoiding unnecessarily offensive examples.  It is perfectly alright to raise questions that may seem to you to be unsophisticated or uninformed.  This is a place to learn and explore.  There are no right or wrong answers.

    Filter replies by unread Show deleted replies

    Reply Reply to Main Discussion

        Collapse Subdiscussion Natalie Osterweil

        Natalie Osterweil

        Jan 26, 2017 Jan 26 at 4:39pm
        To me, comparing these three things is a little tricky. One is a mindset (design thinking), one is a tool (positive deviance), and one is a framework (lean start-up). You could apply a design thinking mindset to a lean start-up work space, while using positive deviance. What these things share is the idea that the "solo inventor" model of work won't drive change. In order to find success, people need to blend their ideas, experiences, and their experiments together to drive the whole organization or team. Successful users of any of the three ideas will seek to remove themselves from isolation and bump their work up against other teammates and the outside world.  I used to work for a company that was incredibly focused on putting out "perfect" work to our customers. I was in the IT division of an eCommerce company, and no feature would be released to the website until we had decided it was polished 100%. The thought behind that was that we "knew" our customers. That we were familiar enough with their actions, learning through things like phone interactions and observed behaviors in things like how they paid their invoices, to understand how they would react to any change or new feature. In reality, what we knew was how they had behaved in the past, not how they would behave in the future. We would have benefited from adopting more of an MVP-style development process and reacted to real data, not the way we imagined things would happen. I think we are most likely to find value in the design thinking mindset in our IBD work. The businesses and projects we're working on may not lend themselves to positive deviance, or we might not have enough time to take on a lean start-up process, but we can bring a mindset of empathy for our users and an "action first" principle to whatever we do. I'm curious about how our teams will develop this mindset and style of work over the semester. It's something that takes time and practice and I'm curious about how we'll cultivate our practice. 
        Manage Discussion Entry
        • Go To Topic
        • Edit
        • Delete
        • Open in SpeedGrader

        To me, comparing these three things is a little tricky. One is a mindset (design thinking), one is a tool (positive deviance), and one is a framework (lean start-up). You could apply a design thinking mindset to a lean start-up work space, while using positive deviance. What these things share is the idea that the "solo inventor" model of work won't drive change. In order to find success, people need to blend their ideas, experiences, and their experiments together to drive the whole organization or team. Successful users of any of the three ideas will seek to remove themselves from isolation and bump their work up against other teammates and the outside world. 

        I used to work for a company that was incredibly focused on putting out "perfect" work to our customers. I was in the IT division of an eCommerce company, and no feature would be released to the website until we had decided it was polished 100%. The thought behind that was that we "knew" our customers. That we were familiar enough with their actions, learning through things like phone interactions and observed behaviors in things like how they paid their invoices, to understand how they would react to any change or new feature. In reality, what we knew was how they had behaved in the past, not how they would behave in the future. We would have benefited from adopting more of an MVP-style development process and reacted to real data, not the way we imagined things would happen.

        I think we are most likely to find value in the design thinking mindset in our IBD work. The businesses and projects we're working on may not lend themselves to positive deviance, or we might not have enough time to take on a lean start-up process, but we can bring a mindset of empathy for our users and an "action first" principle to whatever we do. I'm curious about how our teams will develop this mindset and style of work over the semester. It's something that takes time and practice and I'm curious about how we'll cultivate our practice. 

        Reply Reply to Comment (2 likes)

          • Collapse Subdiscussion Annie Porter

            Annie Porter

            Jan 26, 2017 Jan 26 at 5:57pm
            Thanks for the interesting insights Natalie! The different theories can definitely be primarily a tool / framework and mindset, but if adopted wholeheartedly, I don't think they will remain just that.  For example, despite the "lean start up" theory primarily being a framework, the rapid prototyping becomes a tool and the customer centric nature infiltrates the business mindset.    I am curious to understand whether you feel that there would have been any negative repercussions of your prior company releasing MVP features to their website?  Would customers start thinking less of your company? And how would customers be incentivised to give meaningful feedback on the MVP?   I am also curious how we will cultivate design thinking in IBD especially with the limited interaction with our respective clients.    
            Manage Discussion Entry
            • Go To Parent
            • Edit
            • Delete
            • Open in SpeedGrader

            Thanks for the interesting insights Natalie! The different theories can definitely be primarily a tool / framework and mindset, but if adopted wholeheartedly, I don't think they will remain just that.  For example, despite the "lean start up" theory primarily being a framework, the rapid prototyping becomes a tool and the customer centric nature infiltrates the business mindset. 

             

            I am curious to understand whether you feel that there would have been any negative repercussions of your prior company releasing MVP features to their website?  Would customers start thinking less of your company? And how would customers be incentivised to give meaningful feedback on the MVP?

             

            I am also curious how we will cultivate design thinking in IBD especially with the limited interaction with our respective clients.

              Cancel
              • Collapse Subdiscussion Natalie Osterweil

                Natalie Osterweil

                Apr 24, 2017 Apr 24 at 10:16pm
                There is definitely a tension between releasing early and often for the sake of learning and creating a thoughtful customer experience. Reputation and word of mouth were our main marketing tools, so making sure that customers had a consistently positive experience was important to us as a company. One of the principles that we held as being super important was the idea of "graceful recovery." Meaning, there were certainly times we made mistakes, but showing customers that we were willing and able to make things right when problems arose helped inspire loyalty. I think that mindset could help inform how an MVP style of working could be successful. Push things out early and often but have a plan for how to right the ship if it goes awry.    As far as incentivizing meaningful feedback, we always held the belief that customers were constantly giving us feedback through their actions. We would look at the "customer journey" - what they searched for, where they clicked, what they added to their cart, and what they ultimately ordered - to see how certain changes affected behavior. Actions like abandoned searches or unplaced orders helped us understand the effects of our changes. But you're right, there are certainly things that are lost in translation there. 
                Manage Discussion Entry
                • Go To Parent
                • Edit
                • Delete
                • Open in SpeedGrader

                There is definitely a tension between releasing early and often for the sake of learning and creating a thoughtful customer experience. Reputation and word of mouth were our main marketing tools, so making sure that customers had a consistently positive experience was important to us as a company. One of the principles that we held as being super important was the idea of "graceful recovery." Meaning, there were certainly times we made mistakes, but showing customers that we were willing and able to make things right when problems arose helped inspire loyalty. I think that mindset could help inform how an MVP style of working could be successful. Push things out early and often but have a plan for how to right the ship if it goes awry. 

                 

                As far as incentivizing meaningful feedback, we always held the belief that customers were constantly giving us feedback through their actions. We would look at the "customer journey" - what they searched for, where they clicked, what they added to their cart, and what they ultimately ordered - to see how certain changes affected behavior. Actions like abandoned searches or unplaced orders helped us understand the effects of our changes. But you're right, there are certainly things that are lost in translation there.

                  Cancel
                • Collapse Subdiscussion Matt Shelton

                  Matt Shelton

                  Jan 30, 2017 Jan 30 at 11:58am
                  I definitely agree with the overarching theme of getting out of isolation and seeing how things work in the real world. In that way, I think design thinking does come with a certain toolkit, especially with regard to customer interviews. But you're right that elements of all 3 can/should be blended together to drive everything forward. Based on your work experience (which resonates strongly with mine), it's clear that the delivery of perfect work has become so entrenched in our corporate cultures that it will be ridiculously hard to shift. As anyone in management knows it's frustrating when you receive work from your teams that feels half-assed. But if we as leaders can be more clear about our desire for work that tests a specific hypothesis, rather than work that answers every question perfectly, maybe we can start to socialize that message down to our teams. And if they actually believe us (not easy), it could be fun to start iterating and experimenting more with our products or business solutions, rather than continue to be obsessed with the 'perfect solution.'
                  Manage Discussion Entry
                  • Go To Parent
                  • Edit
                  • Delete
                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                  I definitely agree with the overarching theme of getting out of isolation and seeing how things work in the real world. In that way, I think design thinking does come with a certain toolkit, especially with regard to customer interviews. But you're right that elements of all 3 can/should be blended together to drive everything forward. Based on your work experience (which resonates strongly with mine), it's clear that the delivery of perfect work has become so entrenched in our corporate cultures that it will be ridiculously hard to shift. As anyone in management knows it's frustrating when you receive work from your teams that feels half-assed. But if we as leaders can be more clear about our desire for work that tests a specific hypothesis, rather than work that answers every question perfectly, maybe we can start to socialize that message down to our teams. And if they actually believe us (not easy), it could be fun to start iterating and experimenting more with our products or business solutions, rather than continue to be obsessed with the 'perfect solution.'

                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Jeannie Valkevich

                      Jeannie Valkevich

                      Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 8:22am
                      I think that making the transition from a working culture that demands “perfection” to one that values risk taking can be really hard.  At my old job, we cited “risk taking” as an important part of our culture as we went through a redesign process, but I never saw it fully play out in the way we did our jobs each day.  I think for people to “actually believe” it is ok to test hypotheses (even if it doesn’t yield a perfect answer), they need to see examples of what this looks like across every level of a company/organization.  How can managers model risk-taking for their teams?
                      Manage Discussion Entry
                      • Go To Parent
                      • Edit
                      • Delete
                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                      I think that making the transition from a working culture that demands “perfection” to one that values risk taking can be really hard.  At my old job, we cited “risk taking” as an important part of our culture as we went through a redesign process, but I never saw it fully play out in the way we did our jobs each day.  I think for people to “actually believe” it is ok to test hypotheses (even if it doesn’t yield a perfect answer), they need to see examples of what this looks like across every level of a company/organization.  How can managers model risk-taking for their teams?

                      Edited by Jeannie Valkevich on Feb 10 at 8:26am

                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Mark Angel

                        Mark Angel

                        Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 8:43pm
                        Your previous work experience resonates strongly with me, as in consulting (my previous experience), perfection is highly valued. Everything needed to be "client-ready." When I moved to working with a startup immediately before Haas, I quickly learned that "perfection" was not valued, but rather, quick iterations and constant adjustments. This concept was foreign to me and in hindsight, I wish I had taken better advantage of that opportunity to learn how a lean startup truly works from the inside out.  I also agree that I am excited to apply some of these tools on our IBD projects; it will be a great opportunity to learn how these tools can operate well (or not so well) within an organization.
                        Manage Discussion Entry
                        • Go To Parent
                        • Edit
                        • Delete
                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                        Your previous work experience resonates strongly with me, as in consulting (my previous experience), perfection is highly valued. Everything needed to be "client-ready." When I moved to working with a startup immediately before Haas, I quickly learned that "perfection" was not valued, but rather, quick iterations and constant adjustments. This concept was foreign to me and in hindsight, I wish I had taken better advantage of that opportunity to learn how a lean startup truly works from the inside out. 

                        I also agree that I am excited to apply some of these tools on our IBD projects; it will be a great opportunity to learn how these tools can operate well (or not so well) within an organization.

                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Angel Napit

                            Angel Napit

                            Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 10:56pm
                            This is an interesting point you make Mark about the differences between your consulting firm and your startup experience.  As I was reflecting on your comments and thinking back to my last job, I realized that many times we were required to have a "finished" product when presenting internally but were presenting WIP goods and services (and iterating more often) when working with a client. This difference in how we interacted however caused quite a bit of confusion, especially for new team members.  I wonder now how better our results could have been if we could have created the atmosphere of a partnerships internally even when working with vertical teams.     
                            Manage Discussion Entry

                            This is an interesting point you make Mark about the differences between your consulting firm and your startup experience.  As I was reflecting on your comments and thinking back to my last job, I realized that many times we were required to have a "finished" product when presenting internally but were presenting WIP goods and services (and iterating more often) when working with a client. This difference in how we interacted however caused quite a bit of confusion, especially for new team members.  I wonder now how better our results could have been if we could have created the atmosphere of a partnerships internally even when working with vertical teams.

                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Natalie Osterweil

                                  Natalie Osterweil

                                  Apr 24, 2017 Apr 24 at 10:22pm
                                  Totally different mentality for internal projects. In those cases, we worked in the "80/20" style, but it often felt closer to 70/30. When it came to our internal work, we were very conscious of the opportunity cost associated with finishing the long tail of work. And it was frustrating for everyone involved. IT project teams felt like they weren't putting out great products and internal partners felt like they were getting unfinished work. But, at the end of the day I do think it was the right call to do it that way. It meant we got to tackle more of the big problems, even if we didn't get a chance to solve all of the small ones associate with them. 
                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                  • Go To Parent
                                  • Edit
                                  • Delete
                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                  Totally different mentality for internal projects. In those cases, we worked in the "80/20" style, but it often felt closer to 70/30. When it came to our internal work, we were very conscious of the opportunity cost associated with finishing the long tail of work. And it was frustrating for everyone involved. IT project teams felt like they weren't putting out great products and internal partners felt like they were getting unfinished work. But, at the end of the day I do think it was the right call to do it that way. It meant we got to tackle more of the big problems, even if we didn't get a chance to solve all of the small ones associate with them.

                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Annie Porter

                                  Annie Porter

                                  Jan 26, 2017 Jan 26 at 5:47pm
                                  Similarities/ Differences: All three frameworks are inherently consumer centric, either drawing inspiration from the consumer (as in positive deviance) or drawing early and rapid feedback from the consumer (lean start up and design thinking) Personal skills / Mindsets different: The three frameworks all seek to push mindsets from "perfect" (and often untested) to simple (and easily tested) solutions, even when faced with complex problems. As a result these frameworks both tolerate failure and accept average solutions, in the context of consumers wants and situational constraints Prior Organisations support mindset (or could better support): Used to work at McKinsey & Co.  McKinsey had an answer-first, hypothesis approach to problem solving, to deal with complex projects over short deadlines.  In some cases consumers were not sufficiently consulted which resulted in poor implementation (often after McKinsey consultants had left). McKinsey has spent a lot of money, both acquiring Lunar and redesigning their practices to introduce a focus on design thinking During my time working as an Investment Associate on a Social Venture Capital fund, we sought out companies who applied the Lean approach, as we were more confident of their success.  Most applicable to AI course: I imagine all will be applicable, but depending on resource constraints in the Social Impact IBD course, the positive deviation framework may be the most helpful. Questions: Do you feel that products formed using design thinking practices are more vulnerable to consumer trends than traditionally designed products? What do you suppose the biggest long term effect of design thinking will be in the business world? Is it possible to assign growth in  innovation to these frameworks?  If so how have the trends of these frameworks effected the innovation growth rate?
                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                  • Go To Topic
                                  • Edit
                                  • Delete
                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                  Similarities/ Differences:

                                  • All three frameworks are inherently consumer centric, either drawing inspiration from the consumer (as in positive deviance) or drawing early and rapid feedback from the consumer (lean start up and design thinking)

                                  Personal skills / Mindsets different:

                                  • The three frameworks all seek to push mindsets from "perfect" (and often untested) to simple (and easily tested) solutions, even when faced with complex problems. As a result these frameworks both tolerate failure and accept average solutions, in the context of consumers wants and situational constraints

                                  Prior Organisations support mindset (or could better support):

                                  • Used to work at McKinsey & Co.  McKinsey had an answer-first, hypothesis approach to problem solving, to deal with complex projects over short deadlines.  In some cases consumers were not sufficiently consulted which resulted in poor implementation (often after McKinsey consultants had left). McKinsey has spent a lot of money, both acquiring Lunar and redesigning their practices to introduce a focus on design thinking
                                  • During my time working as an Investment Associate on a Social Venture Capital fund, we sought out companies who applied the Lean approach, as we were more confident of their success. 

                                  Most applicable to AI course:

                                  • I imagine all will be applicable, but depending on resource constraints in the Social Impact IBD course, the positive deviation framework may be the most helpful.

                                  Questions:

                                  • Do you feel that products formed using design thinking practices are more vulnerable to consumer trends than traditionally designed products?
                                  • What do you suppose the biggest long term effect of design thinking will be in the business world?
                                  • Is it possible to assign growth in  innovation to these frameworks?  If so how have the trends of these frameworks effected the innovation growth rate?
                                  Reply Reply to Comment (1 like)
                                  HTML Editor Rich Content Editor

                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Matt Shelton

                                      Matt Shelton

                                      Jan 30, 2017 Jan 30 at 12:04pm
                                      I love your first question about how consumer trends might creep into product solutions. I guess the pure answer would be that if you dig deep enough into the desire of the consumer, then you should be able to create a product that satisfies their true need even if it is not 'trendy'. But realistically, you as a design thinker are going to be influenced by the trends, and frankly, the consumer may report higher levels of satisfaction with a product that follows a trend, meaning they are more familiar with how it works and why others like it. So maybe some element of consumer trend creep is unavoidable?   I also like your point about trusting companies more who employed the Lean approach. I hadn't thought about it as an evaluation tool, but it does provide a quicker way to ensure that the company's vision is not solely based on the burning desire of a founder to solve the problem he or she imagines is most imporant, even if that belief is misinformed. 
                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                      • Go To Parent
                                      • Edit
                                      • Delete
                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                      I love your first question about how consumer trends might creep into product solutions. I guess the pure answer would be that if you dig deep enough into the desire of the consumer, then you should be able to create a product that satisfies their true need even if it is not 'trendy'. But realistically, you as a design thinker are going to be influenced by the trends, and frankly, the consumer may report higher levels of satisfaction with a product that follows a trend, meaning they are more familiar with how it works and why others like it. So maybe some element of consumer trend creep is unavoidable?

                                       

                                      I also like your point about trusting companies more who employed the Lean approach. I hadn't thought about it as an evaluation tool, but it does provide a quicker way to ensure that the company's vision is not solely based on the burning desire of a founder to solve the problem he or she imagines is most imporant, even if that belief is misinformed.

                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Donald Bullock

                                          Donald Bullock

                                          Feb 8, 2017 Feb 8 at 4:36pm
                                          In response to your first question, this is where I feel Lean Start-Up could take the place of Design Thinking or that they could easily be combined into a new form of problem solving. In Lean Start-Up, it is important to think about false negatives and positives and that you don't fall prey to any of the biases. I like the fact that in Design Thinking you are not looking for confirmation/falsification of your hypotheses from a test group that doesn't take mainstream consumers into thought. So this should easily address the risk of falling vulnerable to consumer trends.
                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                          • Go To Parent
                                          • Edit
                                          • Delete
                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                          In response to your first question, this is where I feel Lean Start-Up could take the place of Design Thinking or that they could easily be combined into a new form of problem solving. In Lean Start-Up, it is important to think about false negatives and positives and that you don't fall prey to any of the biases. I like the fact that in Design Thinking you are not looking for confirmation/falsification of your hypotheses from a test group that doesn't take mainstream consumers into thought. So this should easily address the risk of falling vulnerable to consumer trends.

I personally don't feel products formed using design thinking practices are more vulnerable to consumer trends because it is capturing the kind of universal customer needs or make things easier to use.  

                                              Reply Reply to Comment
                                              HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                               
                                                Cancel
                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Matt Shelton

                                                Matt Shelton

                                                Jan 30, 2017 Jan 30 at 11:40am
                                                The first theme that strikes me as I compare the three methodologies is the way in which each seeks to generate insights from others’ experience about the problem at hand. Positive deviance passively looks to the crowd for a source of inspiration – how a few individuals managed on their own to avoid the fate of the rest of the group. This thinking is less concerned with why the individuals acted the way they did (i.e. fed their children a certain diet or used condoms during sex work), and more with the results, whether intended or not. A necessary skill in this sociological research is the ability to spot trends among users and connect which behaviors are similar in a meaningful way.  In contrast, design thinking looks similarly to examples from the population but with a keener eye for the reasons behind an individual’s actions – why does he schedule his doctor appointments in that way or why does she send money to friends using her smartphone? Here, the ‘right’ answer has probably not been figured out by random folks in the population, but their desires have led them to act a certain way. If the analyzer can identify this need and create a better way to serve it, then they have put their design thinking to use effectively. The mindset here is that of empathy. A person will need to conduct meaningful interviews to burrow into the expanse of why a person is motivated to act in a certain way. After understanding the user, the design thinker will also need to think one step ahead and consider incremental or wholesale changes in a product or experience and ponder how the respondent might have benefited from what the design thinker could create for them.  And lastly, the lean startup method assumes that the entrepreneur may have a valid idea on which to base a successful product, but that the product will not take proper form without exiting the building and putting a form of the product (MVP) into the hands of users. So rather than search for the already created answer or even the needs behind the answer, the experimenter here searches for his/her ability to design something truly novel and useful. To be successful a person will need the ability to quickly switch their frame of reference between inward and outward to adapt to the challenges along the way: What does the user need, followed by how do I create a product that addresses their need, followed by assessing their reaction to my product in their hands, and returning to the first step and repeating the loop. Excelling in the creative step or in the research step will not be enough to employ this method well, but having the awareness and ability to switch between them rapidly will likely yield positive results. In my consulting experience, I cannot say that my company was too encouraging of any of these methods for our external work. A client asked for a product, and we labored intensely on our end, figuring out the most efficient way to return the most impressive results – those that we felt were our strongest work. But if we had spent more time working on empathy for our client, I think we could have been more effective. If asked for revenue projections for a business unit, for example, we rarely stopped to ask why, and then ask again. Working harder to understand the client’s base needs would certainly have provided a more meaningful analysis or recommendation at times, as well as saving unnecessary work. However, an area in which we did excel in our design thinking approach was in our internal training curriculum for new consultants. We, as management, frequently worked to understand their journey through our training modules and the work they were assigned on their projects so that we could better understand their specific knowledge or skill needs at specific times. We modified certain trainings to make them on demand or virtually accessible, which was all in response to understanding how consultants felt the rigid training schedule did not actually fit their needs all the time.  I’m really excited to use these new methods in my IBD course as a team participant. I think that maintaining empathy for our clients/users and conducting informative interviews will be extremely helpful. I am a little confused about how we will be able to prototype rapidly when the solution our client desires might be large and complex, but then again this style is new to me so I’m sure there is room to experiment. I really hope that my classmates and I can discuss or brainstorm ways to break down the deliverable into smaller segments so that we can try our hands at prototyping and getting more frequent feedback, rather than falling into the consulting trap I discussed above.
                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                • Go To Topic
                                                • Edit
                                                • Delete
                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                The first theme that strikes me as I compare the three methodologies is the way in which each seeks to generate insights from others’ experience about the problem at hand. Positive deviance passively looks to the crowd for a source of inspiration – how a few individuals managed on their own to avoid the fate of the rest of the group. This thinking is less concerned with why the individuals acted the way they did (i.e. fed their children a certain diet or used condoms during sex work), and more with the results, whether intended or not. A necessary skill in this sociological research is the ability to spot trends among users and connect which behaviors are similar in a meaningful way. 

                                                In contrast, design thinking looks similarly to examples from the population but with a keener eye for the reasons behind an individual’s actions – why does he schedule his doctor appointments in that way or why does she send money to friends using her smartphone? Here, the ‘right’ answer has probably not been figured out by random folks in the population, but their desires have led them to act a certain way. If the analyzer can identify this need and create a better way to serve it, then they have put their design thinking to use effectively. The mindset here is that of empathy. A person will need to conduct meaningful interviews to burrow into the expanse of why a person is motivated to act in a certain way. After understanding the user, the design thinker will also need to think one step ahead and consider incremental or wholesale changes in a product or experience and ponder how the respondent might have benefited from what the design thinker could create for them. 

                                                And lastly, the lean startup method assumes that the entrepreneur may have a valid idea on which to base a successful product, but that the product will not take proper form without exiting the building and putting a form of the product (MVP) into the hands of users. So rather than search for the already created answer or even the needs behind the answer, the experimenter here searches for his/her ability to design something truly novel and useful. To be successful a person will need the ability to quickly switch their frame of reference between inward and outward to adapt to the challenges along the way: What does the user need, followed by how do I create a product that addresses their need, followed by assessing their reaction to my product in their hands, and returning to the first step and repeating the loop. Excelling in the creative step or in the research step will not be enough to employ this method well, but having the awareness and ability to switch between them rapidly will likely yield positive results.

                                                In my consulting experience, I cannot say that my company was too encouraging of any of these methods for our external work. A client asked for a product, and we labored intensely on our end, figuring out the most efficient way to return the most impressive results – those that we felt were our strongest work. But if we had spent more time working on empathy for our client, I think we could have been more effective. If asked for revenue projections for a business unit, for example, we rarely stopped to ask why, and then ask again. Working harder to understand the client’s base needs would certainly have provided a more meaningful analysis or recommendation at times, as well as saving unnecessary work. However, an area in which we did excel in our design thinking approach was in our internal training curriculum for new consultants. We, as management, frequently worked to understand their journey through our training modules and the work they were assigned on their projects so that we could better understand their specific knowledge or skill needs at specific times. We modified certain trainings to make them on demand or virtually accessible, which was all in response to understanding how consultants felt the rigid training schedule did not actually fit their needs all the time. 

                                                I’m really excited to use these new methods in my IBD course as a team participant. I think that maintaining empathy for our clients/users and conducting informative interviews will be extremely helpful. I am a little confused about how we will be able to prototype rapidly when the solution our client desires might be large and complex, but then again this style is new to me so I’m sure there is room to experiment. I really hope that my classmates and I can discuss or brainstorm ways to break down the deliverable into smaller segments so that we can try our hands at prototyping and getting more frequent feedback, rather than falling into the consulting trap I discussed above.

                                                Edited by Matt Shelton on Jan 30 at 11:59am

It's easy to apply iteration and MVP with start ups and if you are trying to start a project, but can see this being more complicated when venturing into other territory.

                                                        Jeannie Valkevich

                                                        Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 8:40am
                                                        I like your thought/intention here on maintaining empathy as we work with clients and users throughout our IBD projects.  I think your reflection on not having worked in this way with clients in your past role can serve as a counterexample that will likely help you re-position your work in this way for this project.  I am looking forward to learning from you and other former consultants (or others who worked primarily with external clients) about your experience working collaboratively with clients and how we might establish empathetic, positive working relationships as we employ some of these tools alongside our clients this term.

                                                        I like your thought/intention here on maintaining empathy as we work with clients and users throughout our IBD projects.  I think your reflection on not having worked in this way with clients in your past role can serve as a counterexample that will likely help you re-position your work in this way for this project.  I am looking forward to learning from you and other former consultants (or others who worked primarily with external clients) about your experience working collaboratively with clients and how we might establish empathetic, positive working relationships as we employ some of these tools alongside our clients this term.

                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Anik Mathur

                                                            Anik Mathur

                                                            Feb 15, 2017 Feb 15 at 8:28pm
                                                            Hey Matt, I can definitely relate to the lack of application of these methods from my consulting experience as well :)  We placed to much emphasis on performing the work that was being asked of us that we never stopped to consider if what we were doing was best for our customer.  Sure, it led to a substantial amount of revenue early on, however, over the course of a few years it was apparent that not thinking critically caught up to us and made us easily replaceable by other firms.  The lack of focus on doing what was best for client was personally something that I found actually hurt employee morale as well.  It wasn't until I moved to a much more progressive tech job that I was exposed to empathy for our clients.  No sales meeting would begin without our "partners," no longer "clients," first explaining to us what their concerns were.  I absolutely loved that approach and can't wait to apply that to IBD this Spring!!
                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                            • Go To Parent
                                                            • Edit
                                                            • Delete
                                                            • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                            Hey Matt, I can definitely relate to the lack of application of these methods from my consulting experience as well :)  We placed to much emphasis on performing the work that was being asked of us that we never stopped to consider if what we were doing was best for our customer.  Sure, it led to a substantial amount of revenue early on, however, over the course of a few years it was apparent that not thinking critically caught up to us and made us easily replaceable by other firms.  The lack of focus on doing what was best for client was personally something that I found actually hurt employee morale as well.  It wasn't until I moved to a much more progressive tech job that I was exposed to empathy for our clients.  No sales meeting would begin without our "partners," no longer "clients," first explaining to us what their concerns were.  I absolutely loved that approach and can't wait to apply that to IBD this Spring!!

                                                            HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                             
                                                              Cancel
                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Rachel Garrison

                                                              Rachel Garrison

                                                              Feb 6, 2017 Feb 6 at 11:48am
                                                              All three approaches fit into the PFPS framework of 1) frame and reframe, 2) observe and notice, 3) imagine and design, and 4) make and experiment.  The hypothesis driven approach focuses most on the framing and reframing step, through multiple MVP tests and the revision process. Positive deviance centers around the observe and notice step, giving more weight to finding uncommon use cases.  And lastly, the design thinking approach centers around the make and experiment step, with an emphasis on prototyping. All three approaches require us to perform the imagine and design step in the problem-solution discovery process.  The three disciplines can all provide innovative end products and solutions, but they also have their limitations.  The hypothesis driven approach is often short-sighted through constant A/B testing, false positives, and false negatives.  Design thinking requires more risk and ambiguity given the singular hypothesis and often expensive prototyping.  And lastly, positive deviance is hard to come by –the whole premise is finding an uncommon success story.  Using elements of each approach throughout IBD will be crucial, and it will be important to map out which to use when during our initial team meetings. When it comes to my experience with the approaches, I am most familiar with the Hypothesis Driven Entrepreneurship model.  However, all three approaches to framing and solving problems had useful applications in my day to day job.  Working in ecommerce, we were highly focused on the A/B testing step in the lean startup model. We would strategize and launch new landing pages and functionality that met our company mission to be mom’s best friend and help her find the baby and toddler products she needs, at the click of a button.  We would then run tests, launching the pages to certain customer segments and groups to validate or falsify our hypotheses.  Conversion and sales were our main quantitative metrics for validation. We were constantly pivoting and not truly learning from our tests.  None of the pages really drove the results we wanted – it came down to a bigger problem of not spending on marketing.  How have you learned from constant repivoting at work? How do you deal with the frustration of starting over? For positive deviance, I had the thought to interview customers who would call our customer service center to place orders for our ecommerce business.  A lot of these customers didn’t own computers, but somehow they heard about Diapers.com and understood that we could ship them products. This never came to fruition, but I would love to hear if anyone has successful cases of using positive deviance.  Additionally, how do you make sure not to lead the audience?  It seems like confirmation bias would be a big risk in this model.  Do you think we will have time given the short duration of our IBD program to use positive deviance? For design thinking, what are examples of prototypes you have used?  How do you keep the whole organization customer experience focused?
                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                              • Go To Topic
                                                              • Edit
                                                              • Delete
                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                              All three approaches fit into the PFPS framework of 1) frame and reframe, 2) observe and notice, 3) imagine and design, and 4) make and experiment.  The hypothesis driven approach focuses most on the framing and reframing step, through multiple MVP tests and the revision process. Positive deviance centers around the observe and notice step, giving more weight to finding uncommon use cases.  And lastly, the design thinking approach centers around the make and experiment step, with an emphasis on prototyping. All three approaches require us to perform the imagine and design step in the problem-solution discovery process. 

                                                              The three disciplines can all provide innovative end products and solutions, but they also have their limitations.  The hypothesis driven approach is often short-sighted through constant A/B testing, false positives, and false negatives.  Design thinking requires more risk and ambiguity given the singular hypothesis and often expensive prototyping.  And lastly, positive deviance is hard to come by –the whole premise is finding an uncommon success story.  Using elements of each approach throughout IBD will be crucial, and it will be important to map out which to use when during our initial team meetings.

                                                              When it comes to my experience with the approaches, I am most familiar with the Hypothesis Driven Entrepreneurship model.  However, all three approaches to framing and solving problems had useful applications in my day to day job.  Working in ecommerce, we were highly focused on the A/B testing step in the lean startup model. We would strategize and launch new landing pages and functionality that met our company mission to be mom’s best friend and help her find the baby and toddler products she needs, at the click of a button.  We would then run tests, launching the pages to certain customer segments and groups to validate or falsify our hypotheses.  Conversion and sales were our main quantitative metrics for validation. We were constantly pivoting and not truly learning from our tests.  None of the pages really drove the results we wanted – it came down to a bigger problem of not spending on marketing.  How have you learned from constant repivoting at work? How do you deal with the frustration of starting over?

                                                              For positive deviance, I had the thought to interview customers who would call our customer service center to place orders for our ecommerce business.  A lot of these customers didn’t own computers, but somehow they heard about Diapers.com and understood that we could ship them products. This never came to fruition, but I would love to hear if anyone has successful cases of using positive deviance.  Additionally, how do you make sure not to lead the audience?  It seems like confirmation bias would be a big risk in this model.  Do you think we will have time given the short duration of our IBD program to use positive deviance?

                                                              For design thinking, what are examples of prototypes you have used?  How do you keep the whole organization customer experience focused?

                                                                  IAN COLLAZO

                                                                  Feb 8, 2017 Feb 8 at 4:55pm
                                                                  Rachel! I'm living for your post. I think a lot of this, especially being customer centric is something all companies aspires to naturally, but so hard to instill in the culture of an organization. There are so many competing interesting for senior managers that can lead organizations astray and prevent them from fully implementing these design thinking principles. Easy to say we do, but hard to install system wide.

                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Michelle Hernandez Rosa

                                                                      Michelle Hernandez Rosa

                                                                      Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 10:32am
                                                                      To answer your question of using positive deviance, I used it in my last company to design our rotational development program.  We looked at our college hires that had been in the company for a year and had been marked in the top 5% performers. We did 360 evaluations to pin point which skills/traits that made them successful where shared among them.  We then developed training workshops to replicate these skills in our new incoming class of college hires.  The main challenge was figuring out what skills can be developed/taught vs what skills we had to hire for. 
                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                      • Go To Parent
                                                                      • Edit
                                                                      • Delete
                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                      To answer your question of using positive deviance, I used it in my last company to design our rotational development program.  We looked at our college hires that had been in the company for a year and had been marked in the top 5% performers. We did 360 evaluations to pin point which skills/traits that made them successful where shared among them.  We then developed training workshops to replicate these skills in our new incoming class of college hires.  The main challenge was figuring out what skills can be developed/taught vs what skills we had to hire for.

                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Anne Kramer

                                                                          Anne Kramer

                                                                          Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 8:52am
                                                                          Your story of how your previous company didn't truly learn from their success and kept pivoting instead deeply resonates with me. At the Gates Foundation there was a strategy called the "shiny object" - dangle a new and exciting project in-front of Bill Gates and he'll fund it. This strategy often disregarded past learnings, both good and bad, and instead drew on recent trends in international development or, worse, personal biases towards specific programs and people.  Something I felt that was missing from these readings was how to shift a culture that applies few or none of these three approaches towards a place where failure is tolerated, learnings are encouraged, and hypothesis driven testing is the norm. The articles spoke to why these principles lead to better innovation and greater product-market fit, but not how to create the incentives to do it. What are your thoughts?  
                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                          • Go To Parent
                                                                          • Edit
                                                                          • Delete
                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                          Your story of how your previous company didn't truly learn from their success and kept pivoting instead deeply resonates with me. At the Gates Foundation there was a strategy called the "shiny object" - dangle a new and exciting project in-front of Bill Gates and he'll fund it. This strategy often disregarded past learnings, both good and bad, and instead drew on recent trends in international development or, worse, personal biases towards specific programs and people. 

                                                                          Something I felt that was missing from these readings was how to shift a culture that applies few or none of these three approaches towards a place where failure is tolerated, learnings are encouraged, and hypothesis driven testing is the norm. The articles spoke to why these principles lead to better innovation and greater product-market fit, but not how to create the incentives to do it. What are your thoughts?

                                                                              Rachel Garrison

                                                                              Feb 14, 2017 Feb 14 at 9:17am
                                                                              I am completely agree that incentives are key to allowing failures flourish. It's especially hard when incentives are tied to financial performance to take risks. Some companies have specific teams for base vs innovation teams, and I have conflicting feelings about if this structure truly allows for the best environment for ideation, but it is possible that it provides the best incentive structure.

                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Anik Mathur

                                                                                Anik Mathur

                                                                                Feb 15, 2017 Feb 15 at 8:41pm
                                                                                Hey Rachel!  Admittedly, situations very significantly based on the industries companies belong in and how large they are, however, my specific department did a great job of shifting focus to customer experience.  We had some executive coaches come in and speak to every single team in the sales organization about how to effectively present.  However, the lesson from these that no one forget wasn't about speech delivery, it was about empathy.  The coaches had everyone role play a variety of situations, and all of us type-A "hi client, this is why you should buy our amazing ads" salespeople realized that the pretend meetings which were solely focused on hearing the client's needs and concerns were most impactful.  Maybe I need to explain it in person, but it was an eye opening experience for all of us :)  The importance of how customers felt became increasingly evident during my time at FB as the teams which destroyed their quotas and led the company weren't made up of brilliant orators, but rather people who had earned an incredible amount of trust from their clients.
                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                • Go To Parent
                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                Hey Rachel!  Admittedly, situations very significantly based on the industries companies belong in and how large they are, however, my specific department did a great job of shifting focus to customer experience.  We had some executive coaches come in and speak to every single team in the sales organization about how to effectively present.  However, the lesson from these that no one forget wasn't about speech delivery, it was about empathy.  The coaches had everyone role play a variety of situations, and all of us type-A "hi client, this is why you should buy our amazing ads" salespeople realized that the pretend meetings which were solely focused on hearing the client's needs and concerns were most impactful.  Maybe I need to explain it in person, but it was an eye opening experience for all of us :)  The importance of how customers felt became increasingly evident during my time at FB as the teams which destroyed their quotas and led the company weren't made up of brilliant orators, but rather people who had earned an incredible amount of trust from their clients.

                                                                                    Rachel, I always love your insights from your retail experience! It seems like a very data driven industry for decision making. I was really interested to hear how you would run A/B tests to evaluate landing pages with sales and conversion metrics. I came from a very data light company and was always jealous of this type of structured decision making. I often felt similarly that we would constantly be shifting to new approaches without ever slowing down to learn from the data. I would definitely get a little frustrated at the short-sightedness of the decision making. Honestly, it's something that was never changed or improved upon and is still going on there today!

                                                                                    Rachel, I always love your insights from your retail experience! It seems like a very data driven industry for decision making. I was really interested to hear how you would run A/B tests to evaluate landing pages with sales and conversion metrics. I came from a very data light company and was always jealous of this type of structured decision making. I often felt similarly that we would constantly be shifting to new approaches without ever slowing down to learn from the data. I would definitely get a little frustrated at the short-sightedness of the decision making. Honestly, it's something that was never changed or improved upon and is still going on there today!

                                                                                    HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                     
                                                                                      Cancel
                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion IAN COLLAZO

                                                                                      IAN COLLAZO

                                                                                      Feb 7, 2017 Feb 7 at 6:19pm
                                                                                      While learning about the three frameworks, the main similarity between the three is the robust analytical mindset. Each is rooted in, at the basic level, of taking data or thoughts and distilling them into insights that can potentially benefit an organization. However, there are obvious difference: Design thinking - seems more of an early mindset that focuses on ideation and design. There is little in terms of actual product performance or pragmatism. Positive deviance - in this mindset it seems the major focus on being able to observe and notice variances in a system. There is less of an importance on design or actual testing.  Lean start up - rapid creating of various iterations and constant testing seem to be the differentiator for this framework. Lean startup seems more useful for actual products and ideas that plan to hit the market and will interact with customers. From professional experience, I can say that Walmart is rather effective of following the three frameworks presented in this module. Walmart's customer-centric culture forces management to think of problems in the viewpoint of the customer - do they need it, how will they interact with it, will it save them money? Walmart is also obsessive with data analytics and always trying to gather insights from shopper data to view positive deviances - why do our top 10% of shoppers visit almost daily, but others don't? In terms of lean start up, Walmart has a robust pipeline of new products and services that it plans to implement, but has a structured process for roll out that includes soft launches, revisions and pivoting. This is to ensure that all business plans are perfect before the are scaled at the Walmart national/global level. In general, Walmart can better support these approaches by giving management better latitude to explore and fail while implementing these frameworks. There is often a strong pressure for profitability and a desire to product something quickly - all pressures that can cause the frameworks to be implemented on a shallow level and less analysis and synthesis. In the applies innovation coursework, I think the most valuable aspect will be the design thinking. You can implement processes and workflows that can incorporate observation and robust testing, but design thinking is more theoretical and can easily be ignored in the working world. I'm excited to further utilize design thinking, especially because it appears to be easily transferable to all business situations, which will benefit our IBD project, which will most likely be in an area that we have little/no knowledge in. A question about the approaches that I would like to discuss with my classmates is the implementation of these principles, like design thinking, on international organizations. With IBD being international, It would be interesting to see how companies in various parts of the world have harness or have their own iteration of the principles.  
                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                      • Go To Topic
                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                      While learning about the three frameworks, the main similarity between the three is the robust analytical mindset. Each is rooted in, at the basic level, of taking data or thoughts and distilling them into insights that can potentially benefit an organization. However, there are obvious difference:

                                                                                      • Design thinking - seems more of an early mindset that focuses on ideation and design. There is little in terms of actual product performance or pragmatism.
                                                                                      • Positive deviance - in this mindset it seems the major focus on being able to observe and notice variances in a system. There is less of an importance on design or actual testing. 
                                                                                      • Lean start up - rapid creating of various iterations and constant testing seem to be the differentiator for this framework. Lean startup seems more useful for actual products and ideas that plan to hit the market and will interact with customers.

                                                                                      From professional experience, I can say that Walmart is rather effective of following the three frameworks presented in this module. Walmart's customer-centric culture forces management to think of problems in the viewpoint of the customer - do they need it, how will they interact with it, will it save them money? Walmart is also obsessive with data analytics and always trying to gather insights from shopper data to view positive deviances - why do our top 10% of shoppers visit almost daily, but others don't? In terms of lean start up, Walmart has a robust pipeline of new products and services that it plans to implement, but has a structured process for roll out that includes soft launches, revisions and pivoting. This is to ensure that all business plans are perfect before the are scaled at the Walmart national/global level. In general, Walmart can better support these approaches by giving management better latitude to explore and fail while implementing these frameworks. There is often a strong pressure for profitability and a desire to product something quickly - all pressures that can cause the frameworks to be implemented on a shallow level and less analysis and synthesis.

                                                                                      In the applies innovation coursework, I think the most valuable aspect will be the design thinking. You can implement processes and workflows that can incorporate observation and robust testing, but design thinking is more theoretical and can easily be ignored in the working world. I'm excited to further utilize design thinking, especially because it appears to be easily transferable to all business situations, which will benefit our IBD project, which will most likely be in an area that we have little/no knowledge in.

                                                                                      A question about the approaches that I would like to discuss with my classmates is the implementation of these principles, like design thinking, on international organizations. With IBD being international, It would be interesting to see how companies in various parts of the world have harness or have their own iteration of the principles.

                                                                                      HTML Editor Rich Content Editor

                                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Andy Kang

                                                                                          Andy Kang

                                                                                          Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 12:19am
                                                                                          Ian! I really liked your example of positive deviance at WalMart. To be honest, I had a tough time visualizing positive deviance outside the social impact space, but your example did a very nice job extrapolating the idea of uncommon positive examples to promote more ideal customer behavior when shopping. While I agree with you that design thinking is painted as being more theoretical in the reading, I believe that design thinking can also incorporate analytical rigor like the lean start-up and positive deviance, such as by quantifying the level of emotions users may feel with a certain design innovation.
                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                          • Go To Parent
                                                                                          • Edit
                                                                                          • Delete
                                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                          Ian! I really liked your example of positive deviance at WalMart. To be honest, I had a tough time visualizing positive deviance outside the social impact space, but your example did a very nice job extrapolating the idea of uncommon positive examples to promote more ideal customer behavior when shopping. While I agree with you that design thinking is painted as being more theoretical in the reading, I believe that design thinking can also incorporate analytical rigor like the lean start-up and positive deviance, such as by quantifying the level of emotions users may feel with a certain design innovation.

                                                                                          Reply Reply to Comment (1 like)
                                                                                          HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                           
                                                                                            Cancel
                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Michelle Hernandez Rosa

                                                                                              Michelle Hernandez Rosa

                                                                                              Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 10:39am
                                                                                              Love your comment on how the three frameworks are rooted on taking data to derive insights that lead to value for the consumer and the company. This shows how the frameworks have evolved over time from a design more artistic approach to a way to reframe problems.  These frameworks bring data to life by adding a humanistic lens to analytics.

                                                                                              Love your comment on how the three frameworks are rooted on taking data to derive insights that lead to value for the consumer and the company. This shows how the frameworks have evolved over time from a design more artistic approach to a way to reframe problems.  These frameworks bring data to life by adding a humanistic lens to analytics.

                                                                                                  Rachel Garrison

                                                                                                  Feb 14, 2017 Feb 14 at 9:26am
                                                                                                  Ian! I completely agree that design thinking will be the first and most important step for our IBD project. Design thinking requires truly thinking outside a company's frame of reference and our diverse perspectives and experiences will be especially useful. Question on your positive deviance example - are the 10% of customers that view the site daily also Walmart's best customers? At Diapers.com we segmented customers based on profitability, and studied the habits of our A customers (most profitable). Interested to see how positive deviance takes into account sales/profit.
