                                                                                                  Ian! I completely agree that design thinking will be the first and most important step for our IBD project. Design thinking requires truly thinking outside a company's frame of reference and our diverse perspectives and experiences will be especially useful. Question on your positive deviance example - are the 10% of customers that view the site daily also Walmart's best customers? At Diapers.com we segmented customers based on profitability, and studied the habits of our A customers (most profitable). Interested to see how positive deviance takes into account sales/profit.

                                                                                                  Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                  HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                   
                                                                                                    Cancel
                                                                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Jason Palacios

                                                                                                    Jason Palacios

                                                                                                    Feb 8, 2017 Feb 8 at 8:03am
                                                                                                    Design Thinking – is an approach that is one of a creative nature requiring the ability and leniency to fail. It is an approach around using models to understand complex problems and to determine if something is a good idea before dumping a lot of time, resources, and cash into a project.   Lean Start-up – is a very structured way of approaching projects. It provides a step by step road map for you to follow when creating and developing. This is also a method that promotes the utilization of models and prototypes to test ideas and learn from the positive and negative results. The lean start-up approach is big on learning by doing.   Positive Deviance -  This approach requires that there is someone out there doing the same thing efficiently and successfully that you can then mimic. Additionally, this person needs to be willing to share their processes with you. This may not always be the case or available to you. Though, if positive deviance is an option, it is a very quick and efficient way of improving and jumpstart a project.   In my past professional experience, I could say that the company that I worked for was very quick to utilize positive deviance to a fault. I say this because they would often see one division have success with a particular system or approach then mandate that other divisions implement similar processes. The problem we ran into was that though applying these processes to some of the other divisions worked out well, it did not apply as smoothly for other divisions. This is because some divisions had intricacies that other divisions did not. This became an issue when management would become frustrated when they did not see results from the more nuanced divisions and could not understand why they were having so much difficulty.   As it comes to how I see these different approaches being useful in my IBD course, it really depends on the type of project my team ends up getting. I can see multiple different types of cases that each of these approaches could be helpful. I actually can see myself using all three approaches on different aspects of our project in the future. Each one can be beneficial depending on the situation and the problem at hand.   Design Thinking and Lean Start-up require some time to work through and produce results; how do you go about convincing a company’s executive team that it’s the best approach and that they need to be patient and flexible with failures? I can see this being a difficult sell to an executive team that is trying to navigate and produce in what has become a very fast paced and results driven business environment.
                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                    • Go To Topic
                                                                                                    • Edit
                                                                                                    • Delete
                                                                                                    • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                    Design Thinking – is an approach that is one of a creative nature requiring the ability and leniency to fail. It is an approach around using models to understand complex problems and to determine if something is a good idea before dumping a lot of time, resources, and cash into a project.

                                                                                                     

                                                                                                    Lean Start-up – is a very structured way of approaching projects. It provides a step by step road map for you to follow when creating and developing. This is also a method that promotes the utilization of models and prototypes to test ideas and learn from the positive and negative results. The lean start-up approach is big on learning by doing.

                                                                                                     

                                                                                                    Positive Deviance -  This approach requires that there is someone out there doing the same thing efficiently and successfully that you can then mimic. Additionally, this person needs to be willing to share their processes with you. This may not always be the case or available to you. Though, if positive deviance is an option, it is a very quick and efficient way of improving and jumpstart a project.

                                                                                                     

                                                                                                    In my past professional experience, I could say that the company that I worked for was very quick to utilize positive deviance to a fault. I say this because they would often see one division have success with a particular system or approach then mandate that other divisions implement similar processes. The problem we ran into was that though applying these processes to some of the other divisions worked out well, it did not apply as smoothly for other divisions. This is because some divisions had intricacies that other divisions did not. This became an issue when management would become frustrated when they did not see results from the more nuanced divisions and could not understand why they were having so much difficulty.

                                                                                                     

                                                                                                    As it comes to how I see these different approaches being useful in my IBD course, it really depends on the type of project my team ends up getting. I can see multiple different types of cases that each of these approaches could be helpful. I actually can see myself using all three approaches on different aspects of our project in the future. Each one can be beneficial depending on the situation and the problem at hand.

                                                                                                     

                                                                                                    Design Thinking and Lean Start-up require some time to work through and produce results; how do you go about convincing a company’s executive team that it’s the best approach and that they need to be patient and flexible with failures? I can see this being a difficult sell to an executive team that is trying to navigate and produce in what has become a very fast paced and results driven business environment.

                                                                                                    Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                    HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                     
                                                                                                      Cancel
                                                                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Risa Shen

                                                                                                        Risa Shen

                                                                                                        Feb 8, 2017 Feb 8 at 6:16pm
                                                                                                        Hey Jason, with regard to your question about convincing management to be patient with failures, I think you could make the argument that it's better to fail quickly (with cheap paper prototypes and smoke screen tests) than to invest tons of resources before realizing that your idea isn't what customers actually want. It takes many ideas to be generated for 1 winning one to be picked, and company executives should understand that the first idea likely won't be the best. I think the way to convince management would be to give a clear time frame for when you'll be able to prove or disprove hypotheses -- maybe a week to test 3 ideas?
                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                        • Go To Parent
                                                                                                        • Edit
                                                                                                        • Delete
                                                                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                        Hey Jason, with regard to your question about convincing management to be patient with failures, I think you could make the argument that it's better to fail quickly (with cheap paper prototypes and smoke screen tests) than to invest tons of resources before realizing that your idea isn't what customers actually want. It takes many ideas to be generated for 1 winning one to be picked, and company executives should understand that the first idea likely won't be the best. I think the way to convince management would be to give a clear time frame for when you'll be able to prove or disprove hypotheses -- maybe a week to test 3 ideas?

                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                         
                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Gianfranco Gentille

                                                                                                            Gianfranco Gentille

                                                                                                            Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 2:51am
                                                                                                            Your question is something that I was also wondering as I felt that was the starting point to apply these frameworks in organizations. I think a reasonable way could be  to research the history of the company and look for times when a decision taken quickly just because management was afraid of failing ended having bad results or generating a financial burden for the company. In my experience in the companies where I worked, I have been witness of at least two examples that I could cite to the executive team to make a point about changing the culture of permitting failure. That proof converted into money saved in the long term could be a good argument to convince the executive team.
                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry

                                                                                                            Your question is something that I was also wondering as I felt that was the starting point to apply these frameworks in organizations. I think a reasonable way could be  to research the history of the company and look for times when a decision taken quickly just because management was afraid of failing ended having bad results or generating a financial burden for the company. In my experience in the companies where I worked, I have been witness of at least two examples that I could cite to the executive team to make a point about changing the culture of permitting failure. That proof converted into money saved in the long term could be a good argument to convince the executive team.

I think we all have experienced similar issues at organizations but I have never really been able to clearly identify or articulate what was happening. Very interesting!

                                                                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Donald Bullock

                                                                                                                          Donald Bullock

                                                                                                                          Feb 8, 2017 Feb 8 at 4:18pm
                                                                                                                          Design Thinking and Lean Start-Up are more similar to each other than Positive Deviance. I say this because Design Thinking and Lean Start-Up require you to come up with a solution that most likely has not been thought of anywhere else. Positive Deviance takes a solution that has already worked well for someone and applying it to someone else. This is also why Design Thinking and Lean Start-Up require you to devise come up with a solution in its minimal form first, either a prototype or a MVP, respectively. Within the sales organization at Google, being a Positive Deviant was the most encouraged. Everyone would always say, “Don’t reinvent the wheel.” However, within the product organization, Design Thinking and Lean Start-Up were the most encouraged. In alpha and beta phases, I would receive products to pitch to my clients that weren’t fully built out.  In the IBD course, I feel the skills needed for Lean Start-Up would be the most valuable to hone. The MVP is very similar to the prototype, however, you should have more quantitative hypotheses on which to test your MVP. Since we will only be working in-country for a short period of time, we will want to have very measurable KPIs.   After these readings, I feel that Lean Start-Up can take the place of Design Thinking. Or am I missing something of Design Thinking that Lean Start-Up can't address? What do you think?
                                                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                          • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                          • Edit
                                                                                                                          • Delete
                                                                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                          Design Thinking and Lean Start-Up are more similar to each other than Positive Deviance. I say this because Design Thinking and Lean Start-Up require you to come up with a solution that most likely has not been thought of anywhere else. Positive Deviance takes a solution that has already worked well for someone and applying it to someone else. This is also why Design Thinking and Lean Start-Up require you to devise come up with a solution in its minimal form first, either a prototype or a MVP, respectively.

                                                                                                                          Within the sales organization at Google, being a Positive Deviant was the most encouraged. Everyone would always say, “Don’t reinvent the wheel.” However, within the product organization, Design Thinking and Lean Start-Up were the most encouraged. In alpha and beta phases, I would receive products to pitch to my clients that weren’t fully built out. 

                                                                                                                          In the IBD course, I feel the skills needed for Lean Start-Up would be the most valuable to hone. The MVP is very similar to the prototype, however, you should have more quantitative hypotheses on which to test your MVP. Since we will only be working in-country for a short period of time, we will want to have very measurable KPIs.  

                                                                                                                          After these readings, I feel that Lean Start-Up can take the place of Design Thinking. Or am I missing something of Design Thinking that Lean Start-Up can't address? What do you think?

                                                                                                                          Edited by Donald Bullock on Feb 8 at 4:23pm

                                                                                                                          HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                           
                                                                                                                            Cancel
                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Risa Shen

                                                                                                                              Risa Shen

                                                                                                                              Feb 8, 2017 Feb 8 at 6:10pm
                                                                                                                              Hey Donald -- I totally agree with positive deviance being used in sales! Coming from financial sales this was definitely emphasized. I think that there are more nuanced differences between lean startup and design thinking. Design thinking to me is practiced almost before a vision is developed (a vision is required for lean startup). I see it as more creative and free-flowing than lean startup, but I might be wrong. Design thinking focuses on getting in tune with the emotions of the customer -- their needs, fears, and aspirations -- whereas lean startup is focused on validating or disproving an existing idea.
                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                              • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                              Hey Donald -- I totally agree with positive deviance being used in sales! Coming from financial sales this was definitely emphasized. I think that there are more nuanced differences between lean startup and design thinking. Design thinking to me is practiced almost before a vision is developed (a vision is required for lean startup). I see it as more creative and free-flowing than lean startup, but I might be wrong. Design thinking focuses on getting in tune with the emotions of the customer -- their needs, fears, and aspirations -- whereas lean startup is focused on validating or disproving an existing idea.

                                                                                                                                  Jason Palacios

                                                                                                                                  Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 8:04am
                                                                                                                                  Hi Donald, I have a similar feeling about Lean Start-Up and Design Thinking. I feel as though Design Thinking is more of a general way of thinking about problems and that Lean Start-Up has most of the same concepts but then adds some structure to it by laying out a step by step road map to follow. Perhaps the two can be thought of as a one framework together.

                                                                                                                                  Hi Donald,

                                                                                                                                  I have a similar feeling about Lean Start-Up and Design Thinking. I feel as though Design Thinking is more of a general way of thinking about problems and that Lean Start-Up has most of the same concepts but then adds some structure to it by laying out a step by step road map to follow. Perhaps the two can be thought of as a one framework together.

                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Rachel Garrison

                                                                                                                                      Rachel Garrison

                                                                                                                                      Feb 14, 2017 Feb 14 at 9:33am
                                                                                                                                      Hi Donald! I really enjoyed reading your post. I definitely agree that having measurable KPIs will be extremely important for us and that the Lean Start-Up methodology will provide the best framework to do so.  As for the differences between Lean Start-Up and Design Thinking, my feeling is that Design Thinking requires you to pick a solution earlier on and run with it. Given the short duration of our project, finding the right balance between hypothesizing, pivoting, and sticking to our original premise will be especially challenging. I imagine that getting buy in from the company early and frequently will allow us to more strategically pick and test a limited number of solutions that design thinking requires given the length and complexity of the prototyping step.
                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                      • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                      Hi Donald! I really enjoyed reading your post. I definitely agree that having measurable KPIs will be extremely important for us and that the Lean Start-Up methodology will provide the best framework to do so.  As for the differences between Lean Start-Up and Design Thinking, my feeling is that Design Thinking requires you to pick a solution earlier on and run with it. Given the short duration of our project, finding the right balance between hypothesizing, pivoting, and sticking to our original premise will be especially challenging. I imagine that getting buy in from the company early and frequently will allow us to more strategically pick and test a limited number of solutions that design thinking requires given the length and complexity of the prototyping step.

                                                                                                                                                  Donald, what an interesting post! I totally agree that Design Thinking is more of a general way of thinking about problems and Lean Start-Up has more to do with tactical road maps.

                                                                                                                                                  HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                   
                                                                                                                                                    Cancel
                                                                                                                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Risa Shen

                                                                                                                                                    Risa Shen

                                                                                                                                                    Feb 8, 2017 Feb 8 at 4:51pm
                                                                                                                                                    Lean startup, design thinking, and positive deviance are all similar in that they require significant qualitative customer research to do properly. Lean startup and design thinking are both highly iterative processes, in which failing fast is encouraged. For positive deviance there is a bit more structure in the approach because it's typically used to change societal behaviors. In terms of personal skills, lean startup is unique in that it relies on a leader who has a vision at the outset. This leader has to be passionate about solving a particular problem but also has to be receptive to feedback and be willing to pivot from the original solution idea. Positive deviance relies on people who can identify positive outliers with very specific characteristics. The positive behaviors have to be replicable but only occur in a small percentage of the population. Design thinking requires a strong sense of empathy and the ability to create testable, physical prototypes quickly. In my previous role in financial sales, senior management employed positive deviance to better understand what the top salesmen were doing to succeed. Unfortunately, these behaviors were generally difficult to teach others. As an IBD team member I expect to use a combination of design thinking, to develop an emotional connection to our customers, and lean startup to test our ideas while incorporating feedback from our client. Questions: can principles of positive deviance be applied to encourage customers to adopt a particular solution? In the context of tech, for example, how do we encourage our target market to adopt a new technology and effectively change their behaviors? In the consulting space how much leeway do the consultants usually get to brainstorm a variety of different ideas and test them on customers?
                                                                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                    • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                    • Edit
                                                                                                                                                    • Delete
                                                                                                                                                    • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                    Lean startup, design thinking, and positive deviance are all similar in that they require significant qualitative customer research to do properly. Lean startup and design thinking are both highly iterative processes, in which failing fast is encouraged. For positive deviance there is a bit more structure in the approach because it's typically used to change societal behaviors.

                                                                                                                                                    In terms of personal skills, lean startup is unique in that it relies on a leader who has a vision at the outset. This leader has to be passionate about solving a particular problem but also has to be receptive to feedback and be willing to pivot from the original solution idea. Positive deviance relies on people who can identify positive outliers with very specific characteristics. The positive behaviors have to be replicable but only occur in a small percentage of the population. Design thinking requires a strong sense of empathy and the ability to create testable, physical prototypes quickly.

                                                                                                                                                    In my previous role in financial sales, senior management employed positive deviance to better understand what the top salesmen were doing to succeed. Unfortunately, these behaviors were generally difficult to teach others. As an IBD team member I expect to use a combination of design thinking, to develop an emotional connection to our customers, and lean startup to test our ideas while incorporating feedback from our client.

                                                                                                                                                    Questions: can principles of positive deviance be applied to encourage customers to adopt a particular solution? In the context of tech, for example, how do we encourage our target market to adopt a new technology and effectively change their behaviors? In the consulting space how much leeway do the consultants usually get to brainstorm a variety of different ideas and test them on customers?

                                                                                                                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Annie Porter

                                                                                                                                                        Annie Porter

                                                                                                                                                        Feb 8, 2017 Feb 8 at 11:03pm
                                                                                                                                                        Hi Risa!  I would love to hear more about the positive deviance technique used to motivate your salesforce. To take a stab at your questions, I believe that the technology can use positive deviance to encourage users to adopt a new technology.  Technology companies could, for instance, credit a high tech sling device to help mothers care for their babies using the kangaroo method (the kangaroo method being a commonly used example of positive deiviance)
                                                                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                        • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                        • Edit
                                                                                                                                                        • Delete
                                                                                                                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                        Hi Risa! 

                                                                                                                                                        I would love to hear more about the positive deviance technique used to motivate your salesforce.

                                                                                                                                                        To take a stab at your questions, I believe that the technology can use positive deviance to encourage users to adopt a new technology.  Technology companies could, for instance, credit a high tech sling device to help mothers care for their babies using the kangaroo method (the kangaroo method being a commonly used example of positive deiviance)

                                                                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Andy Kang

                                                                                                                                                            Andy Kang

                                                                                                                                                            Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 12:40am
                                                                                                                                                            Regarding your first question, I believe that positive deviance can be applied to encourage customers to adopt a particular solution in tech, but this may be challenging. My biggest concern here is that positive deviance starts with discovering uncommon positive examples that naturally existed and applying them broadly, whereas to me, tech feels very conscious and focused. One example that I can think of in which positive deviance does come into play is early adopters of technology who go onto demonstrate to the world how helpful that technology has been to their lives.  Hopefully, this IBD team member experience will gear you to be able to better develop emotional connections to customers, test ideas, and incorporate feedback. This is one of my goals as well!
                                                                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                            • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                            • Edit
                                                                                                                                                            • Delete
                                                                                                                                                            • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                            Regarding your first question, I believe that positive deviance can be applied to encourage customers to adopt a particular solution in tech, but this may be challenging. My biggest concern here is that positive deviance starts with discovering uncommon positive examples that naturally existed and applying them broadly, whereas to me, tech feels very conscious and focused. One example that I can think of in which positive deviance does come into play is early adopters of technology who go onto demonstrate to the world how helpful that technology has been to their lives. 

                                                                                                                                                            Hopefully, this IBD team member experience will gear you to be able to better develop emotional connections to customers, test ideas, and incorporate feedback. This is one of my goals as well!

                                                                                                                                                            Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                            HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                             
                                                                                                                                                              Cancel
                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Andy Kang

                                                                                                                                                              Andy Kang

                                                                                                                                                              Feb 8, 2017 Feb 8 at 9:30pm
                                                                                                                                                              The similarities between positive deviance, design thinking, and lean start-up are that they all involve prototyping or testing to develop a business model, product or social solution. The testing process in positive thinking and the learn start-up is premised on the gathering of information using analytics. With this process comes various iterations and tolerance for failure as hypotheses are constantly revisited and revised. A common theme tying all these together is that each of these concepts places importance on the actual users and begins with simplicity.                  A key difference in positive deviance is that it is based on discovering uncommon positive examples and then leveraging those and the self-discovery process to mobilize communities/customers. While the examples given speak about positive deviance from the perspective of social impact, I believe that it can be applied much more broadly. Design thinking differs from the others in that it is not only applicable to the entrepreneurial space, but it also applies to more traditional industries like management consulting, can be widely applied, and really emphasizes a design-centric culture. Yet design thinking also seems the least tangible. Finally, lean startups is a framework centered on minimizing waste and can be best applied to entrepreneurial ventures and start-ups while having concrete steps: from developing a vision to conducting minimum viable products, pivoting, and ultimately scaling up or shutting a venture down. Before Haas, I worked in finance at Delta Air Lines, and there was very little room for the above-mentioned concepts. Failure was not tolerated while agility and a track record for success were highly valued. There was an overall desire for me to be as efficient and timely as possible with my work. However, I did have the opportunity to work on independent projects that required redesigning processes and building financial models, during which I went through countless iterations and constantly tested my models and processes. My company could have better supported this by creating a culture that tolerates failure and rewards reimagining processes and ideas. I think one of the best ways this could have been accomplished is if the leaders had created a system that allows employees to dedicate up to 20% of their time to new ideas and ventures, similar to how tech giants like Google empowers employees to work on independent projects. Based on my current career goals and enrollment in IBD – Tech, I believe that each of these can be valuable. However, of all these, I think that design thinking and lean start-up methodologies would be most relevant, especially the ideas of iteration/prototyping, using a hypothesis-driven approach, and simplifying complexities. Questions - How do we design quantitative hypotheses when all we have are qualitative data? How have you incorporated MVP tests in your work experience? Finally, how do we actually create a culture of tolerating and embracing failure especially when the stakes are high?
                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                              The similarities between positive deviance, design thinking, and lean start-up are that they all involve prototyping or testing to develop a business model, product or social solution. The testing process in positive thinking and the learn start-up is premised on the gathering of information using analytics. With this process comes various iterations and tolerance for failure as hypotheses are constantly revisited and revised. A common theme tying all these together is that each of these concepts places importance on the actual users and begins with simplicity.                 

                                                                                                                                                              A key difference in positive deviance is that it is based on discovering uncommon positive examples and then leveraging those and the self-discovery process to mobilize communities/customers. While the examples given speak about positive deviance from the perspective of social impact, I believe that it can be applied much more broadly. Design thinking differs from the others in that it is not only applicable to the entrepreneurial space, but it also applies to more traditional industries like management consulting, can be widely applied, and really emphasizes a design-centric culture. Yet design thinking also seems the least tangible. Finally, lean startups is a framework centered on minimizing waste and can be best applied to entrepreneurial ventures and start-ups while having concrete steps: from developing a vision to conducting minimum viable products, pivoting, and ultimately scaling up or shutting a venture down.

                                                                                                                                                              Before Haas, I worked in finance at Delta Air Lines, and there was very little room for the above-mentioned concepts. Failure was not tolerated while agility and a track record for success were highly valued. There was an overall desire for me to be as efficient and timely as possible with my work. However, I did have the opportunity to work on independent projects that required redesigning processes and building financial models, during which I went through countless iterations and constantly tested my models and processes. My company could have better supported this by creating a culture that tolerates failure and rewards reimagining processes and ideas. I think one of the best ways this could have been accomplished is if the leaders had created a system that allows employees to dedicate up to 20% of their time to new ideas and ventures, similar to how tech giants like Google empowers employees to work on independent projects.

                                                                                                                                                              Based on my current career goals and enrollment in IBD – Tech, I believe that each of these can be valuable. However, of all these, I think that design thinking and lean start-up methodologies would be most relevant, especially the ideas of iteration/prototyping, using a hypothesis-driven approach, and simplifying complexities.

                                                                                                                                                              Questions - How do we design quantitative hypotheses when all we have are qualitative data? How have you incorporated MVP tests in your work experience? Finally, how do we actually create a culture of tolerating and embracing failure especially when the stakes are high?

                                                                                                                                                              Edited by Andy Kang on Feb 9 at 12:24am
                                                                                                                                                              Reply Reply to Comment

                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Donald Bullock

                                                                                                                                                                  Donald Bullock

                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 8, 2017 Feb 8 at 9:48pm
                                                                                                                                                                  I'd be very curious to see how these principles could be applied in finance. Taking on the perspective of Delta, I could see how there's not much to really innovate on when in comes to finance. I mean, there are already a ton of financial models out there that are pretty set with it comes to something so quantitative as finance. Finance can be a part of the hypothesis step of Lean Start-Up, but it would be interesting to see what MVP can be created to support or falsify a finance-related hypothesis.
                                                                                                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                  • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                  • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                  • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                  I'd be very curious to see how these principles could be applied in finance. Taking on the perspective of Delta, I could see how there's not much to really innovate on when in comes to finance. I mean, there are already a ton of financial models out there that are pretty set with it comes to something so quantitative as finance. Finance can be a part of the hypothesis step of Lean Start-Up, but it would be interesting to see what MVP can be created to support or falsify a finance-related hypothesis.

                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Gianfranco Gentille

                                                                                                                                                                      Gianfranco Gentille

                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 2:24am
                                                                                                                                                                      I would say that every qualitative characteristic can be categorized into different rankings (depending on the level that we think is good and the level we think is bad) and that could serve as a reference to make it quantitative.  In my experience, it is very difficult to create a culture of tolerating failure without the support of management of the company. That's why I think the most necessary tool the organization needs to promote this kind of culture is the management support.
                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Parent

                                                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                      I would say that every qualitative characteristic can be categorized into different rankings (depending on the level that we think is good and the level we think is bad) and that could serve as a reference to make it quantitative. 

                                                                                                                                                                      In my experience, it is very difficult to create a culture of tolerating failure without the support of management of the company. That's why I think the most necessary tool the organization needs to promote this kind of culture is the management support.

                                                                                                                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Tyler Owens

                                                                                                                                                                          Tyler Owens

                                                                                                                                                                          Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 9:46pm
                                                                                                                                                                          Gianfranco, I fully agree that management buy-in is key to fostering a culture that tolerates failure. I would further venture to say that the buy-in of other, external stakeholders (customers, vendors, etc.) is equally critical, particularly when those stakeholders are involved in the iterative prototyping process. Failure of these stakeholders to understand the role of failure in the design thinking process could certainly lead to unmet expectations as unfinished prototypes are iterated and improved upon. 
                                                                                                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                          • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                          • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                          • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                          Gianfranco,

                                                                                                                                                                          I fully agree that management buy-in is key to fostering a culture that tolerates failure. I would further venture to say that the buy-in of other, external stakeholders (customers, vendors, etc.) is equally critical, particularly when those stakeholders are involved in the iterative prototyping process. Failure of these stakeholders to understand the role of failure in the design thinking process could certainly lead to unmet expectations as unfinished prototypes are iterated and improved upon.

                                                                                                                                                                            Hi Andy, My prior professional experience was very similar to yours and I felt the same way. Reading about these frameworks, I often thought, yeah these are great but I have a hard time thinking of ways they can be applied to more core, non-creative, roles of a company. I am excited to learn about more examples of how these approaches can be applied in a more broad business context. Would love to hear about other peoples experiences and examples.

                                                                                                                                                                              Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Gianfranco Gentille

                                                                                                                                                                              Gianfranco Gentille

                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 2:13am
                                                                                                                                                                              Similarities: They all contribute to the appropriate functioning of organizations because they are all frameworks used to solve problems that organizations have in different stages of life. The mindset required for all the frameworks is an innovative one. All the frameworks try to change the traditional way in which problems get solved in organizations by using a more innovative way. Also, to apply any of the frameworks, tolerance to failure and perseverance is required because the application might not work immediately and might need some change before giving good results. All three of them require certain preparation and research before application (design thinking requires training of employees, positive deviance requires research of the positive agent into the community and lean start-up requires planning to make sure to find a sustainable business before building and marketing the product or service. Differences: Each framework is applied in different environments and requires different types of people to promote it: design thinking is applied to define a corporate culture in a already developed and big company and is promoted by the Board or the Management of the company, positive deviance is usually applied to communities in need of a positive change and is promoted by social NGOs and/or governmental institutions, and lean start-up is usually applied in start-ups before launching the product or service and is promoted by the entrepreneur.  I used to work for a government institution and one of the biggest banks in Peru. Neither of the organizations supported the development of the skill set or mindset required to apply these frameworks. Instead, the institutions were bureaucratic and were extremely scared of failures.   In the Applied Innovation course that I am taking; design thinking would probably be most important because I will have to work with a corporation to find a solution to a strategical problem it may have.  Given the bureaucracy of the organizations where I used to work, how could you manage to introduce any of these frameworks without having the support of the management of the companies? 
                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                              Similarities: They all contribute to the appropriate functioning of organizations because they are all frameworks used to solve problems that organizations have in different stages of life. The mindset required for all the frameworks is an innovative one. All the frameworks try to change the traditional way in which problems get solved in organizations by using a more innovative way. Also, to apply any of the frameworks, tolerance to failure and perseverance is required because the application might not work immediately and might need some change before giving good results. All three of them require certain preparation and research before application (design thinking requires training of employees, positive deviance requires research of the positive agent into the community and lean start-up requires planning to make sure to find a sustainable business before building and marketing the product or service.

                                                                                                                                                                              Differences: Each framework is applied in different environments and requires different types of people to promote it: design thinking is applied to define a corporate culture in a already developed and big company and is promoted by the Board or the Management of the company, positive deviance is usually applied to communities in need of a positive change and is promoted by social NGOs and/or governmental institutions, and lean start-up is usually applied in start-ups before launching the product or service and is promoted by the entrepreneur. 

                                                                                                                                                                              I used to work for a government institution and one of the biggest banks in Peru. Neither of the organizations supported the development of the skill set or mindset required to apply these frameworks. Instead, the institutions were bureaucratic and were extremely scared of failures.  

                                                                                                                                                                              In the Applied Innovation course that I am taking; design thinking would probably be most important because I will have to work with a corporation to find a solution to a strategical problem it may have. 

                                                                                                                                                                              Given the bureaucracy of the organizations where I used to work, how could you manage to introduce any of these frameworks without having the support of the management of the companies?

                                                                                                                                                                                  Jose Vitor Ribeiro Dos Santos

                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 7:32pm
                                                                                                                                                                                  Hi Gianfranco, very interesting post. I wonder how would applying the frameworks discussed would impact the organizations that you used to work on - specially in the government. How do you see it? I also have a banking background, and in my case I could see some aspects of positive deviance - even if it wasn't entirely intentional and stimulated by the senior management. In this sense, once those activities started being more and more encouraged, it was very clear to see the development of the initiatives and solid results. I believe that this would be very replicable, in particular to other financial institutions.

                                                                                                                                                                                  I also have a banking background, and in my case I could see some aspects of positive deviance - even if it wasn't entirely intentional and stimulated by the senior management.                                                                                                                                                                                       Manav Khurana

                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 14, 2017 Feb 14 at 10:45pm
                                                                                                                                                                                      Great post! Similar to Jose and yourself, I am coming from a more traditional finance/banking background and faced similar concerns about bureaucracy. But with regards to your question, I think that idea has to be sparked from somewhere! So if you believe that one of these frameworks would benefit your firm or your team, you must present it to your manager! This will hopefully cause an upstream effect (opposite of downstream haha :)) Yes, larger companies are bureaucratic, but people like us should try to break out of those chains!

Similar to Jose and yourself, I am coming from a more traditional finance/banking background and faced similar concerns about bureaucracy. But with regards to your question, I think that idea has to be sparked from somewhere! So if you believe that one of these frameworks would benefit your firm or your team, you must present it to your manager! This will hopefully cause an upstream effect (opposite of downstream haha :)) Yes, larger companies are bureaucratic, but people like us should try to break out of those chains!

                                                                                                                                                                                          Diego Butrich

                                                                                                                                                                                          Apr 16, 2017 Apr 16 at 6:40pm
                                                                                                                                                                                          Thanks for your comment GF! I wanted to share with you that Interbank actually started applying Design Thinking a couple of years ago to address customer service and attention at the bank's offices. I don't have the details of the results, but I know they were heavily committed to this process, and even started a Design Thinking firm to tackle from an outside perspective other problems that the bank was facing. This evidence supports the your view that even in the most bureaucratic businesses, innovation can be promoted through structured proceses if there is a commitment to do so.

I don't have the details of the results, but I know they were heavily committed to this process, and even started a Design Thinking firm to tackle from an outside perspective other problems that the bank was facing. This evidence supports the your view that even in the most bureaucratic businesses, innovation can be promoted through structured proceses if there is a commitment to do so.
