                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Johnny Gutierrez

                                                                                                                                                                                              Johnny Gutierrez

                                                                                                                                                                                              May 5, 2017 May 5 at 6:32am
                                                                                                                                                                                              Great comment! Coming from large organizations myself, I understand the constraints you talked about regarding the use of design thinking in such organizations. However, I noticed that team dynamics play a significant role in fostering design thinking processes, in some ways more than corporate bureaucracy. For example, some teams at a prior company were known as the innovators of the business unit, while other teams seemed to give-in to the dull bureaucracy of the system. All these teams performed the same tasks, were under the same company, but their team-specific cultural differences resulted in different levels of openness towards innovation
                                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                              Great comment! Coming from large organizations myself, I understand the constraints you talked about regarding the use of design thinking in such organizations. However, I noticed that team dynamics play a significant role in fostering design thinking processes, in some ways more than corporate bureaucracy. For example, some teams at a prior company were known as the innovators of the business unit, while other teams seemed to give-in to the dull bureaucracy of the system. All these teams performed the same tasks, were under the same company, but their team-specific cultural differences resulted in different levels of openness towards innovation

                                                                                                                                                                                              Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                              HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Michelle Hernandez Rosa

                                                                                                                                                                                                Michelle Hernandez Rosa

                                                                                                                                                                                                Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 9:42am
                                                                                                                                                                                                Design thinking, lean startup and positive deviance are all tools used to solve complex problems in a structured and simplified way.  For all of them, there is a focus on the consumer and on providing solutions that are flexible as the environment changes.  To apply these methods, you need to be comfortable with multiple iterations, ambiguity and risk taking.  Design thinking and lean startup are similar in that they use prototypes to test a product/service as soon as possible to pivot if necessary.  The main difference is that lean startup focuses on maximizing each resource while design thinking focuses on empathy with the consumer. In addition, design thinking starts with brainstorming all possible solutions while lean startup starts with one hypothesis it’s trying to prove. Positive deviance’s main difference from the other two methods it that it observes the consumer to find behaviors that already exist and tries to replicate them vs trying to come up with a new solution.  In my last company, there was a huge focus on prototyping.  For example, before purchasing new software tools we would make Excel mockups and have focus groups to obverse how they were used and what features where needed.  It wasn’t until various rounds of prototype iterations that approval would be granted to buy the actual software product.  It was encouraged to use tools that would simplify processes and save cost.    One way that my company could have encouraged these design thinking mindsets would be to provide training on best practices.  The company had a “learn by doing” mentality which was great because it was hands on but it missed out on transferring knowledge from one team to another.  I am taking IBD as my applied innovation course, and I believe that using positive deviance will be key.  There will be a lot of value in observing which practices are already successful and analyze how they can be replicated.  From there, having empathy with the consumer and testing prototypes will give us insights into how to modify our product/service to provide the most value.  With my classmates I would like to explore the following: How to best observe the consumer? What are the right questions to ask to find those behaviors that risk people are doing that have positive results? How to build effective prototypes?
                                                                                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                Design thinking, lean startup and positive deviance are all tools used to solve complex problems in a structured and simplified way.  For all of them, there is a focus on the consumer and on providing solutions that are flexible as the environment changes.  To apply these methods, you need to be comfortable with multiple iterations, ambiguity and risk taking.

                                                                                                                                                                                                 Design thinking and lean startup are similar in that they use prototypes to test a product/service as soon as possible to pivot if necessary.  The main difference is that lean startup focuses on maximizing each resource while design thinking focuses on empathy with the consumer. In addition, design thinking starts with brainstorming all possible solutions while lean startup starts with one hypothesis it’s trying to prove. Positive deviance’s main difference from the other two methods it that it observes the consumer to find behaviors that already exist and tries to replicate them vs trying to come up with a new solution.

                                                                                                                                                                                                 In my last company, there was a huge focus on prototyping.  For example, before purchasing new software tools we would make Excel mockups and have focus groups to obverse how they were used and what features where needed.  It wasn’t until various rounds of prototype iterations that approval would be granted to buy the actual software product.  It was encouraged to use tools that would simplify processes and save cost.  

                                                                                                                                                                                                 One way that my company could have encouraged these design thinking mindsets would be to provide training on best practices.  The company had a “learn by doing” mentality which was great because it was hands on but it missed out on transferring knowledge from one team to another.

                                                                                                                                                                                                 I am taking IBD as my applied innovation course, and I believe that using positive deviance will be key.  There will be a lot of value in observing which practices are already successful and analyze how they can be replicated.  From there, having empathy with the consumer and testing prototypes will give us insights into how to modify our product/service to provide the most value.

                                                                                                                                                                                                 With my classmates I would like to explore the following:

                                                                                                                                                                                                1. How to best observe the consumer?
                                                                                                                                                                                                2. What are the right questions to ask to find those behaviors that risk people are doing that have positive results?
                                                                                                                                                                                                3. How to build effective prototypes?
                                                                                                                                                                                                Reply Reply to Comment (1 like)
                                                                                                                                                                                                HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                 
                                                                                                                                                                                                  Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Ejede Okogbo

                                                                                                                                                                                                    Ejede Okogbo

                                                                                                                                                                                                    Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 9:45pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                    Positive deviance and how to build effective prototypes are also of interest to me, and I share your views on positive deviance. The piece that draws me is how it's essentially "stealing" an idea for "good." In the examples, novel ideas that provide value were studied in order to apply them in analogous scenarios. It's similar to how I view the practical purpose of patents. In the sense that people innovate (or try something random out of desperation) to successfully solve a personal problem only to discover that others have the same problem, and the solution is unique and original. It's a fascinating method of creative problem solving.
                                                                                                                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                    Positive deviance and how to build effective prototypes are also of interest to me, and I share your views on positive deviance. The piece that draws me is how it's essentially "stealing" an idea for "good." In the examples, novel ideas that provide value were studied in order to apply them in analogous scenarios. It's similar to how I view the practical purpose of patents. In the sense that people innovate (or try something random out of desperation) to successfully solve a personal problem only to discover that others have the same problem, and the solution is unique and original. It's a fascinating method of creative problem solving.

                                                                                                                                                                                                        Sophie Kaady

                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 8:13pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                        It's great to hear of the ways your organizations have been able to implement these methods. Design thinking has become so much of a buzz word in the region yet I find it hard to find everyday examples of how companies use these methods in practice.  Your examples, "learn by doing" and prototyping with excel are ones that I could absolutely see myself being able to implement in my next organization.

                                                                                                                                                                                                        It's great to hear of the ways your organizations have been able to implement these methods. Design thinking has become so much of a buzz word in the region yet I find it hard to find everyday examples of how companies use these methods in practice.  Your examples, "learn by doing" and prototyping with excel are ones that I could absolutely see myself being able to implement in my next organization.

                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Jose Vitor Ribeiro Dos Santos

                                                                                                                                                                                                          Jose Vitor Ribeiro Dos Santos

                                                                                                                                                                                                          Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 1:27pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                          I have previous experience in Banking, and I believe that overall, this industry - maybe even without noticing it - strongly applies something close to the positive deviance approach. When one specific team starting having a much higher success rate than the others, it is very natural that this team will start being bench-market, and closely analyzed by the others - and I have been in both sides of this situation. My first experience was to gather all information I could about a team (other than mine) from the Bank I worked on, and bring their best practices to my original colleagues - and it worked out very well. There were some organizational practices and client facing strategies that we didn't applied and that showed to be very successful and improved our results latter. When comparing the three approaches, I believe that they have a lot in common. Both design thinking and lean start-up rely on generating ideas and creating experiment to test them, while the positive deviance framework is more about using one specific “success case” in order to analyze its external validity and possibility of implementation in different scenarios.   I believe that all three frameworks can be important in the IBD projects, but I believe, considering that we will be facing a specific problem of specific company, the first two approaches (lean start-up and design thinking) might help us a bit more to generate new and creative ideas on how to tackle those problems that will be presented to us is these cases. I would like to further explore how is it that we will be able to direct implement the positive deviance approach in the IBD context.   
                                                                                                                                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                          I have previous experience in Banking, and I believe that overall, this industry - maybe even without noticing it - strongly applies something close to the positive deviance approach. When one specific team starting having a much higher success rate than the others, it is very natural that this team will start being bench-market, and closely analyzed by the others - and I have been in both sides of this situation.

                                                                                                                                                                                                          My first experience was to gather all information I could about a team (other than mine) from the Bank I worked on, and bring their best practices to my original colleagues - and it worked out very well. There were some organizational practices and client facing strategies that we didn't applied and that showed to be very successful and improved our results latter.

                                                                                                                                                                                                          When comparing the three approaches, I believe that they have a lot in common. Both design thinking and lean start-up rely on generating ideas and creating experiment to test them, while the positive deviance framework is more about using one specific “success case” in order to analyze its external validity and possibility of implementation in different scenarios.

                                                                                                                                                                                                           

                                                                                                                                                                                                          I believe that all three frameworks can be important in the IBD projects, but I believe, considering that we will be facing a specific problem of specific company, the first two approaches (lean start-up and design thinking) might help us a bit more to generate new and creative ideas on how to tackle those problems that will be presented to us is these cases. I would like to further explore how is it that we will be able to direct implement the positive deviance approach in the IBD context. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                           

                                                                                                                                                                                                          Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                          HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                           
                                                                                                                                                                                                            Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Manav Khurana

                                                                                                                                                                                                              Manav Khurana

                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 14, 2017 Feb 14 at 10:48pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                              Hey Jose, I had trouble with the positive deviance framework, as well, but I think that the idea can also incorporate larger companies or even smaller startups. For example, as I wrote in my post, my firm used to try to mimic other firms in the industry (who were seemingly performing better). I remember my CEO basically saying that we need to change a specific process to match another firm's process to hopefully increase efficiency. So I think positive deviance can be effective in our projects, as well. We just need to be able to observe what our peers or competitors are doing in the industry. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                              Hey Jose, I had trouble with the positive deviance framework, as well, but I think that the idea can also incorporate larger companies or even smaller startups. For example, as I wrote in my post, my firm used to try to mimic other firms in the industry (who were seemingly performing better). I remember my CEO basically saying that we need to change a specific process to match another firm's process to hopefully increase efficiency. So I think positive deviance can be effective in our projects, as well. We just need to be able to observe what our peers or competitors are doing in the industry.

                                                                                                                                                                                                              HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Mariana Martinez Alarcon

                                                                                                                                                                                                                Mariana Martinez Alarcon

                                                                                                                                                                                                                Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 4:32pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                What are the similarities and differences among “design thinking”, “positive deviance” and “lean startup”? Design thinking is about matching customer’s demand for an intuitive and delightful experience when dealing with technology and complex systems. Design thinking involves embracing risk to invest in design even when confronting ambiguous returns and exhibiting thoughtful restraint when deciding on a course of action for the company. Positive Deviance involves improving a community’s lifestyle by studying a subset of the community that has exhibited unexpected good outcomes despite the underlying performance distribution of the community. This outstanding group is studied and the objective is to identify the behavior that sets them apart and that has been contributing to their outlier performance. Positive Deviance encourages the other members of the community to adopt these behaviors and monitors the results. Lean Startup refers to the companies that follow the principles of hypothesis-driven entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurs are encouraged to develop a vision and translate that vision into hypotheses for a new business. Afterwards, the entrepreneur must come up with the Minimum Variable Product (MVP) and test a business hypothesis by launching a series of MVPs to get feedback and improve product. In what ways have the organizations you've worked in supported the development of these skills or mindsets? In solar systems, it is common to link the solar installation to an app so that the customer can easily visualize how much electricity consumed by his house is being supplied by the solar array. These app frequently include a calculation on how much money the customer is saving from the current month’s utility bill and how much CO2 is being offset by the solar array. This app is very user friendly and as such, very much in line with the “Design thinking” approach. Which approaches are likely to be most valuable in the Applied Innovation course you are taking?   Positive deviance, because I’m enrolled for the social impact IBD, I believe the positive deviance approach will be most relevant. What questions do you have about the approaches that you would like to discuss with your classmates?   What benchmarks are used to assess the customer satisfaction in the design thinking approach? If returns on design thinking investments are ambiguous, what are the valuation tools that are used in the decision making process?  
                                                                                                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                What are the similarities and differences among “design thinking”, “positive deviance” and “lean startup”?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                Design thinking is about matching customer’s demand for an intuitive and delightful experience when dealing with technology and complex systems. Design thinking involves embracing risk to invest in design even when confronting ambiguous returns and exhibiting thoughtful restraint when deciding on a course of action for the company.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                Positive Deviance involves improving a community’s lifestyle by studying a subset of the community that has exhibited unexpected good outcomes despite the underlying performance distribution of the community. This outstanding group is studied and the objective is to identify the behavior that sets them apart and that has been contributing to their outlier performance. Positive Deviance encourages the other members of the community to adopt these behaviors and monitors the results.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                Lean Startup refers to the companies that follow the principles of hypothesis-driven entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurs are encouraged to develop a vision and translate that vision into hypotheses for a new business. Afterwards, the entrepreneur must come up with the Minimum Variable Product (MVP) and test a business hypothesis by launching a series of MVPs to get feedback and improve product.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                In what ways have the organizations you've worked in supported the development of these skills or mindsets?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                In solar systems, it is common to link the solar installation to an app so that the customer can easily visualize how much electricity consumed by his house is being supplied by the solar array. These app frequently include a calculation on how much money the customer is saving from the current month’s utility bill and how much CO2 is being offset by the solar array. This app is very user friendly and as such, very much in line with the “Design thinking” approach.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                Which approaches are likely to be most valuable in the Applied Innovation course you are taking?  

                                                                                                                                                                                                                Positive deviance, because I’m enrolled for the social impact IBD, I believe the positive deviance approach will be most relevant.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                What questions do you have about the approaches that you would like to discuss with your classmates?  

                                                                                                                                                                                                                What benchmarks are used to assess the customer satisfaction in the design thinking approach?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                If returns on design thinking investments are ambiguous, what are the valuation tools that are used in the decision making process?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Elizabeth Miller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Elizabeth Miller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 2:18pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Mariana, I love your point about ambiguous returns. It seems very relevant to the social impact space, and I am excited to explore this in my IBD class project. To answer your question, I think it's important for any investment to have quantitive metrics attached, but it is also ok for organizations to admit that they are not able to capture all of the value they are creating. For instance, on the impact section of REDF's website (an organization that invests in social enterprises that employ the chronically underemployed populations), they write, "We’re proud of these results. We’re equally proud of the results we can’t measure. An increase in hope and dignity. A sense of belonging. A more optimistic future."
                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Mariana, I love your point about ambiguous returns. It seems very relevant to the social impact space, and I am excited to explore this in my IBD class project.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    To answer your question, I think it's important for any investment to have quantitive metrics attached, but it is also ok for organizations to admit that they are not able to capture all of the value they are creating. For instance, on the impact section of REDF's website (an organization that invests in social enterprises that employ the chronically underemployed populations), they write, "We’re proud of these results. We’re equally proud of the results we can’t measure. An increase in hope and dignity. A sense of belonging. A more optimistic future."

                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                    HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Ejede Okogbo

                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Ejede Okogbo

                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 7:16pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      All three approaches are methods to tackle wicked problems, problems without a clear definition and with a vague or even non-existent solution space. Observation is a key feature of all three. Design thinking requires an empathetic understanding of the victim of a problem and focuses on developing a solution by giving the user what would make he or she "fulfilled." In essence, this need for an emotionally fulfilling solution is the primary quality of the design thinking methodology. Observing the user's needs and forming an emotional connection with it is highly important in design thinking. Positive deviance reaches broad solutions by observing already working solutions and expanding them to larger populations within a community. While the reading focused on individuals in small communities, I extrapolate to say that a student who develops a study technique for high grades which is later introduced to the rest of the student population is an example of positive deviance.  The lean start-up requires observing how well a solution is received, and then making a determination on what pieces to keep within a solution and what pieces need to be further developed or completely changed. A unified incorporation of all three would have been very valuable in my previous organizations. Observing our customer's needs should help us define what problem we're essentially trying to solve (user-centered design). Observing what successful homegrown solutions our customers have developed (positive deviance) would help us develop our minimum viable product (lean start-up), and testing out our solution based on this home grown solution would help us observe what we could do to further iterate on our proposed product. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                      All three approaches are methods to tackle wicked problems, problems without a clear definition and with a vague or even non-existent solution space. Observation is a key feature of all three.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Design thinking requires an empathetic understanding of the victim of a problem and focuses on developing a solution by giving the user what would make he or she "fulfilled." In essence, this need for an emotionally fulfilling solution is the primary quality of the design thinking methodology. Observing the user's needs and forming an emotional connection with it is highly important in design thinking.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Positive deviance reaches broad solutions by observing already working solutions and expanding them to larger populations within a community. While the reading focused on individuals in small communities, I extrapolate to say that a student who develops a study technique for high grades which is later introduced to the rest of the student population is an example of positive deviance. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                      The lean start-up requires observing how well a solution is received, and then making a determination on what pieces to keep within a solution and what pieces need to be further developed or completely changed.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                      A unified incorporation of all three would have been very valuable in my previous organizations. Observing our customer's needs should help us define what problem we're essentially trying to solve (user-centered design). Observing what successful homegrown solutions our customers have developed (positive deviance) would help us develop our minimum viable product (lean start-up), and testing out our solution based on this home grown solution would help us observe what we could do to further iterate on our proposed product. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Jose Vitor Ribeiro Dos Santos

                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Jose Vitor Ribeiro Dos Santos

                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 7:43pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Hi Ejede, I liked your look-back at your previous organization and how the usage of the frameworks that we have discussed could have impacted it.  Do you believe that using only one of the frameworks in an entire case would have also been positive for the company? From the articles, I felt that each of the three approaches would tackle each of the problems that you mentioned in a different way. For instance, the Positive Deviance approach would allow you to observe and determine the top-performers solutions, understand the problems that are being assessed by those solutions and look to also adapt them to other potential problems. I wonder how you feel that this approach would have impacted your organization.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Hi Ejede, I liked your look-back at your previous organization and how the usage of the frameworks that we have discussed could have impacted it. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Do you believe that using only one of the frameworks in an entire case would have also been positive for the company? From the articles, I felt that each of the three approaches would tackle each of the problems that you mentioned in a different way. For instance, the Positive Deviance approach would allow you to observe and determine the top-performers solutions, understand the problems that are being assessed by those solutions and look to also adapt them to other potential problems. I wonder how you feel that this approach would have impacted your organization.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Reply Reply to Comment (1 like)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                          HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Ejede Okogbo

                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Ejede Okogbo

                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 10:37pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Thanks for the comment Jose. I do believe that would have been successful at my last organization. We built a solution for customers to have access to subprime financing in the point of sale after being rejected by the retailer's primary lender. For instance, a customer who gets rejected by citi financing at a jewelry store would automatically receive a message of potential approval for Monterey financial. While we were a technology company, it would have served us well to observe which actual stores of the same retailers performed better than others even though the customers had similar credit scores, debt-to-income ratio, etc. We never actively sent employees to stores to truly study the experience from store to store. I think it's one of the challenges of B-to-B-to-C companies. The end user in these cases isn't high enough of a priority because the immediate client is a business. These companies are starved of user-centered design.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Thanks for the comment Jose. I do believe that would have been successful at my last organization. We built a solution for customers to have access to subprime financing in the point of sale after being rejected by the retailer's primary lender. For instance, a customer who gets rejected by citi financing at a jewelry store would automatically receive a message of potential approval for Monterey financial. While we were a technology company, it would have served us well to observe which actual stores of the same retailers performed better than others even though the customers had similar credit scores, debt-to-income ratio, etc. We never actively sent employees to stores to truly study the experience from store to store. I think it's one of the challenges of B-to-B-to-C companies. The end user in these cases isn't high enough of a priority because the immediate client is a business. These companies are starved of user-centered design.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                              HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Mark Angel

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Mark Angel

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 8:35pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                I had a similar reaction as Jose. As I understood positive deviance, it appeared to be the least applicable in a business context, especially because it seemed to focus on "point solutions" rather than holistic solutions. One of my hesitancies about applying positive deviance in a business context is that it does not seem dynamic enough. Businesses thrive on diversity - does positive deviance stifle this, given it has only been proven for point solutions in healthcare? I would be interested to learn more.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                I had a similar reaction as Jose. As I understood positive deviance, it appeared to be the least applicable in a business context, especially because it seemed to focus on "point solutions" rather than holistic solutions. One of my hesitancies about applying positive deviance in a business context is that it does not seem dynamic enough. Businesses thrive on diversity - does positive deviance stifle this, given it has only been proven for point solutions in healthcare? I would be interested to learn more.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Reply Reply to Comment (1 like)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Deleted by Ejede Okogbo on Feb 9 at 10:12pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    •
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Collapse Subdiscussion Ejede Okogbo

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Ejede Okogbo

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 10:22pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Could you expand on businesses thrive on diversity? I would argue that we apply positive deviance all the time because the term literally translates to "success with unconventional solutions." Which is what I believe "disruption" is grounded in. I would say Uber's gamble was that maybe human beings would get in a car with a stranger without a taxi "uniform" that signaled regulation. Similarly, people once thought online clothing retail would never work because it was believed that people wouldn't buy without trying on and touching the clothes first. Or how Netflix's and Zappos' shipping policies were not supposed to work. Even Billy Bean applying statistics to baseball could fall in this camp. Although I do believe that drawing the right analogies is very important in this context.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Could you expand on businesses thrive on diversity? I would argue that we apply positive deviance all the time because the term literally translates to "success with unconventional solutions." Which is what I believe "disruption" is grounded in. I would say Uber's gamble was that maybe human beings would get in a car with a stranger without a taxi "uniform" that signaled regulation. Similarly, people once thought online clothing retail would never work because it was believed that people wouldn't buy without trying on and touching the clothes first. Or how Netflix's and Zappos' shipping policies were not supposed to work. Even Billy Bean applying statistics to baseball could fall in this camp. Although I do believe that drawing the right analogies is very important in this context.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Sophie Kaady

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Ejede I liked the way you extrapolated the Positive Deviance method beyond small communities to the classroom. I think one of the most powerful aspects of learning these methods is to be able to think of how we can apply the concepts beyond the business case and beyond even the organizational context.  How can we use these methods in our everyday lives to better make decisions and to get the most from our communities.

I think one of the most powerful aspects of learning these methods is to be able to think of how we can apply the concepts beyond the business case and beyond even the organizational context.  How can we use these methods in our everyday lives to better make decisions and to get the most from our communities.
