                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Johnny Gutierrez

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Johnny Gutierrez

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            May 5, 2017 May 5 at 6:39am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Great company look-back. After reading the articles I had one of those "ofcourse" type of moments, but it's amazing to see how few organizations actually engage the customer at an adequate level to try to understand the problem and viable solutions from their point of view. I've had various experiences at my previous employer where systems were designed for the operators without ever getting feedback from the operators before construction. As a result, future engineers would need to fix problems that could have been avoided if the project engineer would have just consulted the operators. It's important to constantly engage your customer to make sure you're building what they truly want. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Great company look-back. After reading the articles I had one of those "ofcourse" type of moments, but it's amazing to see how few organizations actually engage the customer at an adequate level to try to understand the problem and viable solutions from their point of view. I've had various experiences at my previous employer where systems were designed for the operators without ever getting feedback from the operators before construction. As a result, future engineers would need to fix problems that could have been avoided if the project engineer would have just consulted the operators. It's important to constantly engage your customer to make sure you're building what they truly want. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Jeannie Valkevich

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Jeannie Valkevich

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 8:21pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The “design thinking”, “positive deviance” and “lean start up” concepts each provide a frame or process through which to observe and approach problem solving.  To me, each seems well suited to solving different types of problems.  The lean start up model seems like a very structured approach for launching a new product or business, whereas design thinking seems like it could be more easily applied to a broader set of questions (such as organizational challenges, etc.), and the “positive deviance” approach seems well suited to elevating best practices to combating societal issues.  While each calls on different personal skills and mindsets for their users, I think that they also require similar skills and mindsets across the board: active/intuitive listening and observing, an ability to collaborate with others, and a willingness to “pivot” or change course (among others). My previous organization (an education non-profit supporting new teachers) adopted design-thinking as a method to redesign our program for supporting teachers in the Bay Area.  We worked together as a team to develop several design principles that we then used to design our new program model.  It was cool to be able to collaborate to enact change, but also hard to then implement the new direction when risk-taking could have a negative impact on teachers' learning and, in turn, on their students' experience.  The parts of the design thinking article that touched on cultural challenges to design thinking really resonated with me, and I look forward to learning more about the shift from design to implementation, especially when implemented in the social sector or involving organizational change. I am looking forward to seeing which of these and other approaches we might take with our projects in IBD.  I imagine it might be very context-dependent, so am excited to know more about the projects we’ll be taking on and which of these strategies will be relevant to deploy. Questions I had while reading: Do people have experience with community- initiated examples of “positive deviance”? I am curious to know what this looks like when enacted from within a community, instead of by an outside organization. Again (from above), I am interested in knowing more about how to successfully apply these approaches to problem solving across fields and industries, especially in the social sector.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The “design thinking”, “positive deviance” and “lean start up” concepts each provide a frame or process through which to observe and approach problem solving.  To me, each seems well suited to solving different types of problems.  The lean start up model seems like a very structured approach for launching a new product or business, whereas design thinking seems like it could be more easily applied to a broader set of questions (such as organizational challenges, etc.), and the “positive deviance” approach seems well suited to elevating best practices to combating societal issues.  While each calls on different personal skills and mindsets for their users, I think that they also require similar skills and mindsets across the board: active/intuitive listening and observing, an ability to collaborate with others, and a willingness to “pivot” or change course (among others).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              My previous organization (an education non-profit supporting new teachers) adopted design-thinking as a method to redesign our program for supporting teachers in the Bay Area.  We worked together as a team to develop several design principles that we then used to design our new program model.  It was cool to be able to collaborate to enact change, but also hard to then implement the new direction when risk-taking could have a negative impact on teachers' learning and, in turn, on their students' experience.  The parts of the design thinking article that touched on cultural challenges to design thinking really resonated with me, and I look forward to learning more about the shift from design to implementation, especially when implemented in the social sector or involving organizational change.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I am looking forward to seeing which of these and other approaches we might take with our projects in IBD.  I imagine it might be very context-dependent, so am excited to know more about the projects we’ll be taking on and which of these strategies will be relevant to deploy.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Questions I had while reading:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Do people have experience with community- initiated examples of “positive deviance”? I am curious to know what this looks like when enacted from within a community, instead of by an outside organization.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Again (from above), I am interested in knowing more about how to successfully apply these approaches to problem solving across fields and industries, especially in the social sector.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Edited by Jeannie Valkevich on Feb 9 at 8:33pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Ejede Okogbo

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Ejede Okogbo

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 10:45pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Your comment on social and organizational change made me think of the Toyota case from Ops. I felt that much of that was how to implement an innovative manufacturing solution from Japan to the US. It highlighted the cultural difference and how to it was important to adopt a shift in mindset in order to be successful.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Karin Schmidt

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 8:38am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      It was interesting to read about your experience applying design-thinking to redesign your program to support teachers in the Bay. How was this different from how your team approached problems in the past? You mentioned it was "hard to then implement the new direction when risk-taking could have a negative impact on teachers' learning.." Was your solution more risky than solutions you had developed in the past that didn't involve the design thinking process?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Elizabeth Foster

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Elizabeth Foster

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 10:01am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          I have a little experience with the "positive deviance" appraoch from my time as a Peace Corps Volunteer. In Rwanda, there's been a huge move towards encouraging people to start saving money in local banks - with varying degrees of success. Where this change in behavior has been most successful has actually been amongst school staff. Usually one teacher will start saving and encourage the rest of his/her colleagues to do so. Over the course of my two years I saw more and more teacher communities operning up bank accounts together.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          I have a little experience with the "positive deviance" appraoch from my time as a Peace Corps Volunteer. In Rwanda, there's been a huge move towards encouraging people to start saving money in local banks - with varying degrees of success. Where this change in behavior has been most successful has actually been amongst school staff. Usually one teacher will start saving and encourage the rest of his/her colleagues to do so. Over the course of my two years I saw more and more teacher communities operning up bank accounts together.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Elizabeth Miller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Elizabeth Miller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 2:26pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              This is a really interesting example, thanks for sharing it Beth! It really shows the power of people and networks to influence one another, and the trust that is necessary to motivate behavior change. I loved the positive deviance article, especially this part about building on strengths: "Participants have said that they are motivated by learning that they are doing something right and that a successful solution to their problem already exists within their community, instead of receiving criticism for their inadequacies."

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              This is a really interesting example, thanks for sharing it Beth! It really shows the power of people and networks to influence one another, and the trust that is necessary to motivate behavior change. I loved the positive deviance article, especially this part about building on strengths: "Participants have said that they are motivated by learning that they are doing something right and that a successful solution to their problem already exists within their community, instead of receiving criticism for their inadequacies."

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Mark Angel

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Mark Angel

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 8:27pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Although "design thinking," "lean startup," and "positive deviance" are often used in the same breath, they are all take a "ground up" approach to understanding and addressing problems with empathy at its core. In "design thinking" and "lean startups," individuals seek to gain a deep understanding of consumers or users and their experiences. In design thinking, this helps inform the framing of the problem and "imagining the future." For a lean startup, understanding and validating the customer value proposition helps an organization validate their business model; it helps the startup know address the key needs of their customers. "Positive deviance" also relies significantly on empathy, as it requires an intimate understanding of a community in order to implement sustainable solutions. It is different from lean startups or design thinking, however, in that its scope currently is limited to healthcare in the developing world. While I admire the purpose and success to date of positive deviance, I struggle with its relevance and applicability outside of point solutions for developing countries. It does not appear to be easily replicated among businesses or relevant for developing successful business models, as it focuses more on amplifying what already exists and is working. For the reasons mentioned above, positive deviance seems to be more distinct from lean startups and design thinking; however, differences still remain between these two. Although they both "[rely on rapid iteration, small batches, and short cycle times," as noted in the HBS article on lean startup, design thinking is more about framing problems, whereas the lean startup is more focused on iterating solutions (i.e., Minimum Viable Products) to create a successful business model. As a consultant, I have limited exposure to these concepts. However, I would interested in hearing from my classmates who have used them in their past jobs. It seems that design thinking is the most broadly applicable, followed by the lean startup methodology, followed by positive deviance; however, I would love to hear other's perspectives. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Although "design thinking," "lean startup," and "positive deviance" are often used in the same breath, they are all take a "ground up" approach to understanding and addressing problems with empathy at its core.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              In "design thinking" and "lean startups," individuals seek to gain a deep understanding of consumers or users and their experiences. In design thinking, this helps inform the framing of the problem and "imagining the future." For a lean startup, understanding and validating the customer value proposition helps an organization validate their business model; it helps the startup know address the key needs of their customers.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              "Positive deviance" also relies significantly on empathy, as it requires an intimate understanding of a community in order to implement sustainable solutions. It is different from lean startups or design thinking, however, in that its scope currently is limited to healthcare in the developing world. While I admire the purpose and success to date of positive deviance, I struggle with its relevance and applicability outside of point solutions for developing countries. It does not appear to be easily replicated among businesses or relevant for developing successful business models, as it focuses more on amplifying what already exists and is working.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              For the reasons mentioned above, positive deviance seems to be more distinct from lean startups and design thinking; however, differences still remain between these two. Although they both "[rely on rapid iteration, small batches, and short cycle times," as noted in the HBS article on lean startup, design thinking is more about framing problems, whereas the lean startup is more focused on iterating solutions (i.e., Minimum Viable Products) to create a successful business model.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              As a consultant, I have limited exposure to these concepts. However, I would interested in hearing from my classmates who have used them in their past jobs. It seems that design thinking is the most broadly applicable, followed by the lean startup methodology, followed by positive deviance; however, I would love to hear other's perspectives. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Reply Reply to Comment

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Laura Smith

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Laura Smith

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 19, 2017 Feb 19 at 5:05pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Hey Mark - like your identification of empathy as being core to these approaches. Easy to lose that in the downstream methods of the approaches (experimenting and validation). I also struggled with positive deviance's applications -- the way I interpreted it applied to my experience was the idea of taking and applying the practices of other teams within a similar environment....so maybe I would see something another business team was doing successfully and apply it to my own group. Possibly a loose interpretation of the concept though. :)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Hey Mark - like your identification of empathy as being core to these approaches. Easy to lose that in the downstream methods of the approaches (experimenting and validation). I also struggled with positive deviance's applications -- the way I interpreted it applied to my experience was the idea of taking and applying the practices of other teams within a similar environment....so maybe I would see something another business team was doing successfully and apply it to my own group. Possibly a loose interpretation of the concept though. :)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Brian Burke

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Brian Burke

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 8:52pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    The problem-solving frameworks examined in module one struck me as variations on a similar theme: they are all mechanisms of discovery. These heuristics, while each distinct in its own way, are structured to promote a break from conventional thinking as a means to innovate and adapt in complex, ambiguous settings. As such, at a high level all of the methods covered require a similar open-mindedness, a focus on the target user, and a willingness to fail. In fact, one could even argue that each of these methods promote structured failure as a means to glean new insight and rule out potential alternatives (particularly the lean startup method). Despite these broad similarities, each approach is undeniably unique when it comes to the specifics and required skills. Lean methods are prospective, testing new solutions through meticulous application of the scientific method such as lean, whereas positive deviance is retrospective, deriving insights through backwards induction of successful agents. Design thinking, on the other hand, requires high degrees of empathy and relies on intuition and iterative spontaneity. Building more on these more granular differences, backwards induction is perhaps more appropriate when dealing with large scale systems, while lean startup methods work best with an n of one.  Turning to the potential applications of these approaches to project work in IBD, the value is clear. Design thinking, in particular, will be very useful to promote open-mindedness and empathy as a way to improve understanding of target markets in an unfamiliar country. Depending on the stage of the company, lean startup methodologies may also be very useful as a structured approach to development and commercialization of a new product or market. These iterative approaches will be very beneficial as we seek to navigate uncertainty and ambiguity. To date, I’ve had very little personal experience deploying these methods. So, naturally, I’ve got a lot of questions for those who have. First, how does one identify which scenarios lend themselves to a given approach (e.g. design thinking vs. lean startup methods). Furthermore, has anyone used these methods in combination? If so, how did that turn out? Finally, how does one measure success under these methods? The articles speak at length about process, but does anyone have experience or insight into how to measure success? Basically, how do I know that I’m “doing it right?”
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    The problem-solving frameworks examined in module one struck me as variations on a similar theme: they are all mechanisms of discovery. These heuristics, while each distinct in its own way, are structured to promote a break from conventional thinking as a means to innovate and adapt in complex, ambiguous settings. As such, at a high level all of the methods covered require a similar open-mindedness, a focus on the target user, and a willingness to fail. In fact, one could even argue that each of these methods promote structured failure as a means to glean new insight and rule out potential alternatives (particularly the lean startup method).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Despite these broad similarities, each approach is undeniably unique when it comes to the specifics and required skills. Lean methods are prospective, testing new solutions through meticulous application of the scientific method such as lean, whereas positive deviance is retrospective, deriving insights through backwards induction of successful agents. Design thinking, on the other hand, requires high degrees of empathy and relies on intuition and iterative spontaneity. Building more on these more granular differences, backwards induction is perhaps more appropriate when dealing with large scale systems, while lean startup methods work best with an n of one. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Turning to the potential applications of these approaches to project work in IBD, the value is clear. Design thinking, in particular, will be very useful to promote open-mindedness and empathy as a way to improve understanding of target markets in an unfamiliar country.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Depending on the stage of the company, lean startup methodologies may also be very useful as a structured approach to development and commercialization of a new product or market. These iterative approaches will be very beneficial as we seek to navigate uncertainty and ambiguity.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    To date, I’ve had very little personal experience deploying these methods. So, naturally, I’ve got a lot of questions for those who have. First, how does one identify which scenarios lend themselves to a given approach (e.g. design thinking vs. lean startup methods). Furthermore, has anyone used these methods in combination? If so, how did that turn out? Finally, how does one measure success under these methods? The articles speak at length about process, but does anyone have experience or insight into how to measure success? Basically, how do I know that I’m “doing it right?”

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Anne Kramer

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Anne Kramer

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 9am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Brian - thank you for your questions. Reading these articles raised similar questions for me both about how to deploy these methods effectively in a company that isn't currently using them and, once deployed, how do companies know they're doing it right. You said that you have had little experience using these methods to date. I'm curious then, what methods did your company use to discover insights? How did your company ensure they were focused on the target user? Personally, I think the a huge gap at my last company was that the target user's perspective was often voiced by someone else - the government or partner organization we worked with on the ground. This left lots of room for error, and meant that our programs and initiatives sometimes weren't targeted or designed correctly. People's own personal biases about the effectiveness of certain programs often overshadowed empirical research suggesting another approach. These were some of the challenges I encountered. Intrigued to hear more about yours!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Brian - thank you for your questions. Reading these articles raised similar questions for me both about how to deploy these methods effectively in a company that isn't currently using them and, once deployed, how do companies know they're doing it right. You said that you have had little experience using these methods to date. I'm curious then, what methods did your company use to discover insights? How did your company ensure they were focused on the target user? Personally, I think the a huge gap at my last company was that the target user's perspective was often voiced by someone else - the government or partner organization we worked with on the ground. This left lots of room for error, and meant that our programs and initiatives sometimes weren't targeted or designed correctly. People's own personal biases about the effectiveness of certain programs often overshadowed empirical research suggesting another approach.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        These were some of the challenges I encountered. Intrigued to hear more about yours! 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Edited by Anne Kramer on Feb 10 at 9:01am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Angel Napit

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Angel Napit

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 10:50pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          A part of design thinking (albeit not mentioned in the article) is the idea of studying the extremes of human behavior in order to find a solution for the masses.  This seems to be aligned well with the idea of positive deviance.  Likewise, both methods require observations and interviews of real people to gain understanding, iterations, and evaluations.  The idea of iterations is also brought up in the Lean Startup process which pushes companies to get the product in the hands of the consumers early and often.  The difference between the three it seems comes within where the solution is generated.  In lean startup, the essence of the product is already created and the goal of iterations is to better fit the product to consumer’s needs.  In design thinking, teams are looking to create the solutions while positive deviance calls upon solutions that already exist. All three processes require a culture that promotes learning and reiterating.  Throughout my time in CPG, I found that while companies have a desire to learn about the consumer and find the best solutions, many times teams determine what they believe the best solution is before testing with any outside stakeholders.  Thus, so much time and money is invested into that one idea that to go back to the drawing board or to reiterate in any fashion becomes a monumental task and thus is perceived negatively.  There is also a sense in CPG that we are constantly fighting deadlines and thus sometimes we push forward without taking the time to truly learn and evaluate.  While I am not as familiar with positive deviance, having seen the successful results of both design thinking and lean startup makes me believe that our Applied Innovation course could do well by building an atmosphere where divergent thinking and iterations are encouraged.  I am interested to see how we can manage these processes and also our time wisely to meet the demands of our clients. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          A part of design thinking (albeit not mentioned in the article) is the idea of studying the extremes of human behavior in order to find a solution for the masses.  This seems to be aligned well with the idea of positive deviance.  Likewise, both methods require observations and interviews of real people to gain understanding, iterations, and evaluations.  The idea of iterations is also brought up in the Lean Startup process which pushes companies to get the product in the hands of the consumers early and often.  The difference between the three it seems comes within where the solution is generated.  In lean startup, the essence of the product is already created and the goal of iterations is to better fit the product to consumer’s needs.  In design thinking, teams are looking to create the solutions while positive deviance calls upon solutions that already exist.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          All three processes require a culture that promotes learning and reiterating.  Throughout my time in CPG, I found that while companies have a desire to learn about the consumer and find the best solutions, many times teams determine what they believe the best solution is before testing with any outside stakeholders.  Thus, so much time and money is invested into that one idea that to go back to the drawing board or to reiterate in any fashion becomes a monumental task and thus is perceived negatively.  There is also a sense in CPG that we are constantly fighting deadlines and thus sometimes we push forward without taking the time to truly learn and evaluate. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          While I am not as familiar with positive deviance, having seen the successful results of both design thinking and lean startup makes me believe that our Applied Innovation course could do well by building an atmosphere where divergent thinking and iterations are encouraged.  I am interested to see how we can manage these processes and also our time wisely to meet the demands of our clients.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Karin Schmidt

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Karin Schmidt

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 8:32am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Were people using design thinking, lean start up or positive deviance while you were still at your company? It seems like CPG, given the intense focus on the customer, in theory is well-positioned to take advantage of these approaches. In reality, I think it is very challenging to build a prototype or minimum viable product in industries that require significant levels of R&D without investing millions of dollars.  I, like you, am interested to see how we can manage divergent thinking and iterations within the time constraints to meet the demands of our clients. Do you thinking the atmosphere of divergent thinking will make it challenging to work as a team to come up with a single solution?  
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Were people using design thinking, lean start up or positive deviance while you were still at your company? It seems like CPG, given the intense focus on the customer, in theory is well-positioned to take advantage of these approaches. In reality, I think it is very challenging to build a prototype or minimum viable product in industries that require significant levels of R&D without investing millions of dollars. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I, like you, am interested to see how we can manage divergent thinking and iterations within the time constraints to meet the demands of our clients. Do you thinking the atmosphere of divergent thinking will make it challenging to work as a team to come up with a single solution?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Angel Napit

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Angel Napit

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Feb 9, 2017 Feb 9 at 11:01pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Ian - loved reading about how WM is executing on these three principles internally.  The one thing I would note however is that when we worked with Walmart as a manufacturer, these three processes did not seem to be top of mind.  It seemed as though WM was constantly trying to be first to market which meant making decisions on our end without enough data or research.  Rather than looking at why consumers were behaving the way they were or how the design of the store was helping them with their shopping behaviors, it seemed we were always chasing the next big item.  I wonder if there is a way for WM to put some of these practices into their interactions with their manufacturers as well.  I could imagine some profound changes (and value add) coming into play if these massive players were to work together and create a space where experimentation and innovation was truly encouraged. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Ian - loved reading about how WM is executing on these three principles internally.  The one thing I would note however is that when we worked with Walmart as a manufacturer, these three processes did not seem to be top of mind.  It seemed as though WM was constantly trying to be first to market which meant making decisions on our end without enough data or research.  Rather than looking at why consumers were behaving the way they were or how the design of the store was helping them with their shopping behaviors, it seemed we were always chasing the next big item.  I wonder if there is a way for WM to put some of these practices into their interactions with their manufacturers as well.  I could imagine some profound changes (and value add) coming into play if these massive players were to work together and create a space where experimentation and innovation was truly encouraged. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Karin Schmidt

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Karin Schmidt

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 7:58am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    One of the main similarities among design thinking, positive deviance and lean start-up is the intense focus on the consumer; the consumer is at the center of decision-making. Each of these processes require in-depth inquiries or analysis of the consumer—their concerns, interaction with the product, etc. Design thinking and positive deviance are more at the beginning stage when the entrepreneur is trying to come up with a product idea. They are about identifying unconventional or innovate ways to solve problems. Lean start-up is about building a product that optimizes a startup’s scarce resources. Once the product is built, analysis of consumer behavior drives product enhancements, or determines whether a product will be shutdown. One of the companies I worked for was IBM, which was mentioned in the design thinking article. I worked there 3 years ago at that time design thinking was just starting to be talked about within the company, or at least from what I heard. Based on the article it seems like the company is really trying to incorporate design thinking into the product development process. While there is a push for incorporating design thinking into customer facing departments, I think those roles that are very disconnected from the customer, such as finance, will take much longer to get exposure to design thinking. Support functions, such as finance, often don't get as much training or investment as other departments. Moreover, I don't think the business case for using approaches such as design thinking are as evident for these departments. I think that the approach my team will take during IBD will depend on the problem that we are trying to solve. If we are trying to redesign a product or service for a company, design thinking or positive deviance are likely the best methods. If we are trying to come up with a new product or service then lean startup or design thinking with likely be used. It is also possible that none of these methods will work for solving our problem, and we should be open to this as well. A few of my questions are: What does the design thinking process look like? Is there a single/standard design thinking process or various processes? (the article focused on the principles rather than the process) Can these approaches work for any type of business? Which types of businesses are they best suited for?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    One of the main similarities among design thinking, positive deviance and lean start-up is the intense focus on the consumer; the consumer is at the center of decision-making. Each of these processes require in-depth inquiries or analysis of the consumer—their concerns, interaction with the product, etc. Design thinking and positive deviance are more at the beginning stage when the entrepreneur is trying to come up with a product idea. They are about identifying unconventional or innovate ways to solve problems. Lean start-up is about building a product that optimizes a startup’s scarce resources. Once the product is built, analysis of consumer behavior drives product enhancements, or determines whether a product will be shutdown.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    One of the companies I worked for was IBM, which was mentioned in the design thinking article. I worked there 3 years ago at that time design thinking was just starting to be talked about within the company, or at least from what I heard. Based on the article it seems like the company is really trying to incorporate design thinking into the product development process. While there is a push for incorporating design thinking into customer facing departments, I think those roles that are very disconnected from the customer, such as finance, will take much longer to get exposure to design thinking. Support functions, such as finance, often don't get as much training or investment as other departments. Moreover, I don't think the business case for using approaches such as design thinking are as evident for these departments.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    I think that the approach my team will take during IBD will depend on the problem that we are trying to solve. If we are trying to redesign a product or service for a company, design thinking or positive deviance are likely the best methods. If we are trying to come up with a new product or service then lean startup or design thinking with likely be used. It is also possible that none of these methods will work for solving our problem, and we should be open to this as well.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    A few of my questions are:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • What does the design thinking process look like? Is there a single/standard design thinking process or various processes? (the article focused on the principles rather than the process)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Can these approaches work for any type of business? Which types of businesses are they best suited for?
