                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Elizabeth Foster

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 9:52am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Thanks for sharing your experience with IBM - it's interesting to hear about what implementing design-thinking actually looked like withing the organization at the time. I really liked your insight about how design-thinking likely takes longer to reach less customer-oriented departments. Having only worked with small organizations in which everyone is connected to the customer, I hadn't considered that!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Thanks for sharing your experience with IBM - it's interesting to hear about what implementing design-thinking actually looked like withing the organization at the time.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        I really liked your insight about how design-thinking likely takes longer to reach less customer-oriented departments. Having only worked with small organizations in which everyone is connected to the customer, I hadn't considered that!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Brian Burke

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Brian Burke

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Feb 13, 2017 Feb 13 at 12:46pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Thanks for the thoughtful analysis, Karin! Your point about how the sales pitch for design thinking gets more difficult as functional areas get further removed from the customer really resonated with me. As a growth strategy consultant, we were consistently running up against the tension between new customer needs and entrenched interests of groups like finance etc. In order to generate buy in for these new approaches, often the incentives and KPI targets also needed to change to align priorities with evolving customer needs. This can be a challenge, but can improve the business case for using these approaches.    I also share your question about where these approaches can be best deployed. My initial impression is that perhaps these approaches are versatile enough that they can apply to basically all companies. The catch is that they need to be catered to the context of the business or process in question. Customers aren't always online shoppers - sometimes they take the form of B2B partners - but the core concepts of design thinking can probably still apply with some adaptation.   Looking forward to digging into these questions more as the course unfolds! 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Thanks for the thoughtful analysis, Karin! Your point about how the sales pitch for design thinking gets more difficult as functional areas get further removed from the customer really resonated with me. As a growth strategy consultant, we were consistently running up against the tension between new customer needs and entrenched interests of groups like finance etc. In order to generate buy in for these new approaches, often the incentives and KPI targets also needed to change to align priorities with evolving customer needs. This can be a challenge, but can improve the business case for using these approaches. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            I also share your question about where these approaches can be best deployed. My initial impression is that perhaps these approaches are versatile enough that they can apply to basically all companies. The catch is that they need to be catered to the context of the business or process in question. Customers aren't always online shoppers - sometimes they take the form of B2B partners - but the core concepts of design thinking can probably still apply with some adaptation.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Looking forward to digging into these questions more as the course unfolds!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Reggie Davis

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Mar 1, 2017 Mar 1 at 12:31pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Karin- With IBM being a leader in the design thinking space, I would be interested to learn about how it extends that thought to their organization as a whole. Many large companies prescribe to an idea and publish their support broadly, however, they fail to incorporate into all of their lines of business. Would you be able to do more research on how design thinking has changed IBM as a whole? Also, it would be interesting how your role would have changed if you were just starting now. Do you have anyone you can contact at the firm in order to get that answer. Overall, I think you made valid points and I agree with your train of thought.    Reggie

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                With IBM being a leader in the design thinking space, I would be interested to learn about how it extends that thought to their organization as a whole. Many large companies prescribe to an idea and publish their support broadly, however, they fail to incorporate into all of their lines of business. Would you be able to do more research on how design thinking has changed IBM as a whole? Also, it would be interesting how your role would have changed if you were just starting now.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 • Collapse Subdiscussion Anne Kramer

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Anne Kramer

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 8:44am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  At the highest level, the biggest differences between the lean startup, design thinking, and positive deviance are as follows: the lean startup is a business model to produce product-market fit, design thinking is set of collective principles that inspire innovation, while positive deviance is a strategy for identifying and scaling effective behaviors that already work. A shared tenant of both the lean startup and design thinking methods is not being afraid to fail. Not all products or services will be the right fit for the market and emotionally resonate with consumers, but, both methods insist there’s no way to know unless you test it. The relevance of each of these approaches to our applied innovation work will depend on what problems we are asked to solve. Design thinking is likely to be the most helpful mindset for imaging a new future for a business, while the lean startup will be more effective for designing a new product. Compared with the lean startup, design thinking is a set of principles and not a set of prescriptive steps, and it lends itself better to ideation. In addition, design thinking provides a variety of techniques and tools to encourage innovation and ideation, such as customer journey maps to identify problems, tinkering with ideas in a public forum, and tolerance for failure. In contrast, the lean startup lays out clear steps for determining if you have product-market fit, starting with developing a testable hypothesis, to launching a minimum viable product, and then the decision to persevere, pivot or perish. Positive deviance seems like a less relevant approach. However, we should be asking what other solutions are people already trying as part of our initial scoping and research.  How can we use design thinking and the lean startup approaches together? Specifically, how can we have space to prototype, and potentially to fail?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  At the highest level, the biggest differences between the lean startup, design thinking, and positive deviance are as follows: the lean startup is a business model to produce product-market fit, design thinking is set of collective principles that inspire innovation, while positive deviance is a strategy for identifying and scaling effective behaviors that already work. A shared tenant of both the lean startup and design thinking methods is not being afraid to fail. Not all products or services will be the right fit for the market and emotionally resonate with consumers, but, both methods insist there’s no way to know unless you test it.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  The relevance of each of these approaches to our applied innovation work will depend on what problems we are asked to solve. Design thinking is likely to be the most helpful mindset for imaging a new future for a business, while the lean startup will be more effective for designing a new product. Compared with the lean startup, design thinking is a set of principles and not a set of prescriptive steps, and it lends itself better to ideation. In addition, design thinking provides a variety of techniques and tools to encourage innovation and ideation, such as customer journey maps to identify problems, tinkering with ideas in a public forum, and tolerance for failure. In contrast, the lean startup lays out clear steps for determining if you have product-market fit, starting with developing a testable hypothesis, to launching a minimum viable product, and then the decision to persevere, pivot or perish. Positive deviance seems like a less relevant approach. However, we should be asking what other solutions are people already trying as part of our initial scoping and research.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   How can we use design thinking and the lean startup approaches together? Specifically, how can we have space to prototype, and potentially to fail?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Jeanne Godleski

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Jeanne Godleski

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 1:24pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Hi Anne, One thought I had in reading your response around creating space to prototype and potentially fail. I worked on a project at Deloitte developing Performance Management strategy. One of the areas we spent a lot of time on was the idea of rewarding innovation even if it meant failure. Often times organizations struggle to create the right incentive structures to promote this culture. I think one key piece of this working is having the support for innovative thinking, brainstorming, prototyping and also rewarding the progress associated (even if it ends in failure). You can track how comprehensive someone thought through a complex problem, how many interviews / other forms of data collection a person pursued, how structured the solution concept is, etc. and reward based on the quality and intention of that effort. Of course it needs to be an authentic pursuit but I think incentive structure is huge here.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Hi Anne,

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      One thought I had in reading your response around creating space to prototype and potentially fail. I worked on a project at Deloitte developing Performance Management strategy. One of the areas we spent a lot of time on was the idea of rewarding innovation even if it meant failure. Often times organizations struggle to create the right incentive structures to promote this culture. I think one key piece of this working is having the support for innovative thinking, brainstorming, prototyping and also rewarding the progress associated (even if it ends in failure). You can track how comprehensive someone thought through a complex problem, how many interviews / other forms of data collection a person pursued, how structured the solution concept is, etc. and reward based on the quality and intention of that effort. Of course it needs to be an authentic pursuit but I think incentive structure is huge here.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Elizabeth Foster

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Elizabeth Foster

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 9:29am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        I'm excited to apply alot of the ideas from PFPS to my work as a Berkeley Board Fellow, especially design-thinking and the lean start-up principles. In fact I've already started to do so in a few ways. My co-fellow and I recently met again with the director of our nonprofit to clarify what the actual goal of our project was. We were tasked with helping out the organization's social enterprise nursery and farm, which also serve as training programs for people who face barriers to employment. After PFPS, I realized that I needed greater clarity around what the true aim of the project was if I stood any chance of being successful. By discussing the goals of the social enterprises at a deeper level with the director, a clear direction finally emerged that ultimately was very different from the course we'd initially pursued. Then, once it became clear that increasing the profitability of the nursery was the true goal, my co-fellow and I began brainstorming ideas for how to achieve this. While we are still in the beginning stages, looking at it through the lens of design-thinking and hypothesis-driven entrepreneurship is going to be key. Currently the nursery is selling alot of products, such as native lawn plants, that people don't actually want but which require a great deal of money and labor to produce. Being intentional about understanding the customer through design-thinking will help me explore what plants the nursery should sell based on customer needs. Regarding the hypothesis-driven approach, I believe that, especially when working with resource-strapped organizations, we don't have the luxury of wasting resources by putting out an untested product or service. I'd also argue that the stakes are higher and the success or failure of the enterprise impact more people. I hope to be able to implement the lean-startup ideas in a way that truly benefits the organization. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        I'm excited to apply alot of the ideas from PFPS to my work as a Berkeley Board Fellow, especially design-thinking and the lean start-up principles.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In fact I've already started to do so in a few ways.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        My co-fellow and I recently met again with the director of our nonprofit to clarify what the actual goal of our project was. We were tasked with helping out the organization's social enterprise nursery and farm, which also serve as training programs for people who face barriers to employment. After PFPS, I realized that I needed greater clarity around what the true aim of the project was if I stood any chance of being successful. By discussing the goals of the social enterprises at a deeper level with the director, a clear direction finally emerged that ultimately was very different from the course we'd initially pursued.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Then, once it became clear that increasing the profitability of the nursery was the true goal, my co-fellow and I began brainstorming ideas for how to achieve this. While we are still in the beginning stages, looking at it through the lens of design-thinking and hypothesis-driven entrepreneurship is going to be key. Currently the nursery is selling alot of products, such as native lawn plants, that people don't actually want but which require a great deal of money and labor to produce. Being intentional about understanding the customer through design-thinking will help me explore what plants the nursery should sell based on customer needs.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Regarding the hypothesis-driven approach, I believe that, especially when working with resource-strapped organizations, we don't have the luxury of wasting resources by putting out an untested product or service. I'd also argue that the stakes are higher and the success or failure of the enterprise impact more people. I hope to be able to implement the lean-startup ideas in a way that truly benefits the organization.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Jeanne Godleski

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Jeanne Godleski

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 1:18pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                What are the similarities and differences among “design thinking”, “positive deviance”, and “lean start-up”? For example, how are the personal skills or mindsets required by each similar or different?   Design Thinking, Positive Deviance, and Lean Start-Up are all approaches that respond to the increasing complexities of globalized societies and business environments. All three aim to innovate how we run organizations, drive change, and launch products in a dynamic world. At their core, they are approaches that aim to solve the most complex problems. All three also share a strong human reliance. In Design Thinking, one key principle is empathy with users to develop a responsive, flexible organizational culture. In Positive Deviance, the humans who are behaving in a way that drives a positive outcome are the solution finders. With mobilization support, these individuals serve as role models in their communities to spread the solution and achieve wide spread improvement. In Lean Start-Up, rapid cycling and feedback collection from consumers allows entrepreneurs to maintain their business model, pivot, or abandon the idea. The information from potential users early on is what drives and informs the start-up path. All three approaches also maintain an element of simplicity. Design Thinking aims to simplify and humanize, Positive Deviance leverages solutions that are tried and true and address resource constraints in specific communities while leading to quick improvements (even if large scale development efforts still need to be done over longer term horizon), and Lean Start-Up promotes the concept of MVP (minimum viable product) to simplify what gets tested with consumers and ensure rapid turnarounds. The three methodologies share an innovative, strategic, creative, simple, and risk-tolerant mindset.   The three approaches are also unique from one another. Design Thinking is an approach used within an organization whereby teams can creatively outline ideas in a nurturing environment that tolerates failure and promotes taking risks. Often these ideas are innovative and are solving extremely complex problems. Positive Deviance is an approach that takes a simple solution being done in one community (even if not the ultimate solution to the underlying issue) and finds a way to rapidly expand the behaviors in a realistic way to facilitate progress on a complex issue. Often, these solutions are basic (even though they are working toward solving complex issues). Lean Start-Up is an approach that promotes rapid information gathering to prevent costly resource investments in new ideas. The entrepreneurial ventures may be simple, complex, completely revolutionary, or an offshoot of existing market products or services. The forward-looking nature of this approach comes in the way the business model is tested and pivoted early in the process (not in the product itself).    In what ways have the organizations you’ve worked in supported the development of these skills or mindsets? In what ways might they better support these approaches?   I spent my career at Deloitte Consulting as a Strategy & Operations consultant. Often, due to tight timelines and limited information, I was encouraged to rapidly turn around straw models of deliverables, frameworks, models, etc. There is overlap with this mindset and the Lean Start-Up mindset. However, while there was an element of reduced expectation given the goal (see the rough draft / direction of the product to course correct early), there was limited tolerance of failure. If the output was completely irrelevant it would be a problem so the risks I was encouraged to take were limited. I might not waste time on the formatting and beautifying of a deliverable but I would invest a lot of time in the logic behind it. They might better support these approaches by being more open minded to new ways of doing things. There is a contradictory cookie cutter approach to creative problem solving that defeats the innovative, forward-looking progress the firm strives to make for clients.   Which approaches are likely to be most valuable in the Applied Innovation course you are taking?   While I am not sure what my project is yet, I think that all three will be beneficial. From a Design Thinking perspective, our team should embrace open sharing of ideas and information and build momentum on this exchange. I also believe that depending on the organization and location we are in, there will likely be resource constraints that make the learnings from Positive Deviance very critical to our success. Lastly, as we develop solutions we should embrace the Lean Start-Up methodology to get ideas and basic mvp products on paper quickly and obtain critical feedback throughout our development of the final business case.   What questions do you have about the approaches that you would like to discuss with your classmates?   Did anyone work for an organization that formally embraced Design Thinking? How did performance evaluation work in this context (i.e. rewarded for number of ideas you proposed, viability of ideas you proposed, ultimate success compared to failure rate)? Has anyone pitched an entrepreneurial venture using the Lean Start-Up approach? What was the product? Did you get valuable feedback early on? Were you able to pivot before exhausting resources? What do people think about the concept of Positive Deviance? Is this the right expenditure of resources and time when it may not work toward longer-term development needs?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. What are the similarities and differences among “design thinking”, “positive deviance”, and “lean start-up”? For example, how are the personal skills or mindsets required by each similar or different?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Design Thinking, Positive Deviance, and Lean Start-Up are all approaches that respond to the increasing complexities of globalized societies and business environments. All three aim to innovate how we run organizations, drive change, and launch products in a dynamic world. At their core, they are approaches that aim to solve the most complex problems. All three also share a strong human reliance. In Design Thinking, one key principle is empathy with users to develop a responsive, flexible organizational culture. In Positive Deviance, the humans who are behaving in a way that drives a positive outcome are the solution finders. With mobilization support, these individuals serve as role models in their communities to spread the solution and achieve wide spread improvement. In Lean Start-Up, rapid cycling and feedback collection from consumers allows entrepreneurs to maintain their business model, pivot, or abandon the idea. The information from potential users early on is what drives and informs the start-up path. All three approaches also maintain an element of simplicity. Design Thinking aims to simplify and humanize, Positive Deviance leverages solutions that are tried and true and address resource constraints in specific communities while leading to quick improvements (even if large scale development efforts still need to be done over longer term horizon), and Lean Start-Up promotes the concept of MVP (minimum viable product) to simplify what gets tested with consumers and ensure rapid turnarounds. The three methodologies share an innovative, strategic, creative, simple, and risk-tolerant mindset.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                The three approaches are also unique from one another. Design Thinking is an approach used within an organization whereby teams can creatively outline ideas in a nurturing environment that tolerates failure and promotes taking risks. Often these ideas are innovative and are solving extremely complex problems. Positive Deviance is an approach that takes a simple solution being done in one community (even if not the ultimate solution to the underlying issue) and finds a way to rapidly expand the behaviors in a realistic way to facilitate progress on a complex issue. Often, these solutions are basic (even though they are working toward solving complex issues). Lean Start-Up is an approach that promotes rapid information gathering to prevent costly resource investments in new ideas. The entrepreneurial ventures may be simple, complex, completely revolutionary, or an offshoot of existing market products or services. The forward-looking nature of this approach comes in the way the business model is tested and pivoted early in the process (not in the product itself). 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. In what ways have the organizations you’ve worked in supported the development of these skills or mindsets? In what ways might they better support these approaches?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                I spent my career at Deloitte Consulting as a Strategy & Operations consultant. Often, due to tight timelines and limited information, I was encouraged to rapidly turn around straw models of deliverables, frameworks, models, etc. There is overlap with this mindset and the Lean Start-Up mindset. However, while there was an element of reduced expectation given the goal (see the rough draft / direction of the product to course correct early), there was limited tolerance of failure. If the output was completely irrelevant it would be a problem so the risks I was encouraged to take were limited. I might not waste time on the formatting and beautifying of a deliverable but I would invest a lot of time in the logic behind it. They might better support these approaches by being more open minded to new ways of doing things. There is a contradictory cookie cutter approach to creative problem solving that defeats the innovative, forward-looking progress the firm strives to make for clients.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. Which approaches are likely to be most valuable in the Applied Innovation course you are taking?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                While I am not sure what my project is yet, I think that all three will be beneficial. From a Design Thinking perspective, our team should embrace open sharing of ideas and information and build momentum on this exchange. I also believe that depending on the organization and location we are in, there will likely be resource constraints that make the learnings from Positive Deviance very critical to our success. Lastly, as we develop solutions we should embrace the Lean Start-Up methodology to get ideas and basic mvp products on paper quickly and obtain critical feedback throughout our development of the final business case.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                1. What questions do you have about the approaches that you would like to discuss with your classmates?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Did anyone work for an organization that formally embraced Design Thinking? How did performance evaluation work in this context (i.e. rewarded for number of ideas you proposed, viability of ideas you proposed, ultimate success compared to failure rate)?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Has anyone pitched an entrepreneurial venture using the Lean Start-Up approach? What was the product? Did you get valuable feedback early on? Were you able to pivot before exhausting resources?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • What do people think about the concept of Positive Deviance? Is this the right expenditure of resources and time when it may not work toward longer-term development needs?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Kevin Schuster

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Kevin Schuster

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 10:55am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Hi Jeanne, Thanks for the post! I found your experiences at Deloitte really interesting with how there can be this contradicting method between what a company projects external / strives to do and what the process for "innovation" actually looks like day-to-day. I've found this to be a challenge even within a start-up environment where the day-to-day pressure to meet deadlines soon gets in the way of lean start-up or design thinking mindsets that were stressed from executives.  I like your question on positive deviance as I've been grappling with where I stand on it. I see the benefits as so much of international development work doesn't take into account the realities or feedback "on-the-ground" and just prescribes solutions, as well as the benefits that come from this approach potentially being more sustainable as international development funding for a project typically runs out. On the other hand, when something like someone's health is on the line - is it ok to go with an good solutions vs aiming for the ideal solution? One example where I think the approach did work to some extent was during the Ebola outbreak where much of the disease spreading was coming from people washing the bodies of relatives who had died from Ebola. One approach was to do massive messaging to stop washing relatives' bodies to stop the spread of the disease. With cultural and religious elements tied to the body washing, the medical communities "best practice" wasn't widely adopted compared to an approach of looking for ways to accommodate these strongly held customs by looking at ways some families were honoring the dead while staying safe and hygienic.     
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Hi Jeanne, Thanks for the post! I found your experiences at Deloitte really interesting with how there can be this contradicting method between what a company projects external / strives to do and what the process for "innovation" actually looks like day-to-day. I've found this to be a challenge even within a start-up environment where the day-to-day pressure to meet deadlines soon gets in the way of lean start-up or design thinking mindsets that were stressed from executives. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    I like your question on positive deviance as I've been grappling with where I stand on it. I see the benefits as so much of international development work doesn't take into account the realities or feedback "on-the-ground" and just prescribes solutions, as well as the benefits that come from this approach potentially being more sustainable as international development funding for a project typically runs out. On the other hand, when something like someone's health is on the line - is it ok to go with an good solutions vs aiming for the ideal solution? One example where I think the approach did work to some extent was during the Ebola outbreak where much of the disease spreading was coming from people washing the bodies of relatives who had died from Ebola. One approach was to do massive messaging to stop washing relatives' bodies to stop the spread of the disease. With cultural and religious elements tied to the body washing, the medical communities "best practice" wasn't widely adopted compared to an approach of looking for ways to accommodate these strongly held customs by looking at ways some families were honoring the dead while staying safe and hygienic.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Jeanne Godleski

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 17, 2017 Feb 17 at 3:30pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Hey Kevin! I really appreciate your insights on the Ebola outbreak and I agree that in matters of health and urgent care or disaster relief or other time sensitive, complex problem there has to be a progress over perfection type mentality because the perfect solution may not exist and a near perfect solution could take too long to arrive at.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Go To Parent
