                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Hey Kevin!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        I really appreciate your insights on the Ebola outbreak and I agree that in matters of health and urgent care or disaster relief or other time sensitive, complex problem there has to be a progress over perfection type mentality because the perfect solution may not exist and a near perfect solution could take too long to arrive at.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Elizabeth Miller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Elizabeth Miller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 2:11pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Positive deviance, design thinking and lean start-ups share one main commonality: an emphasis on listening to the consumer above all else. This mindset requires openness and receptivity, especially to ideas that one might initially find surprising. In positive deviance models, the entire solution is consumer-generated, having been identified as an existing practice that works well. For design-thinking, workers must strongly empathize with the customers they are designing for during the creation process. Finally, the lean-start up model prevents one of an entrepreneur’s worst nightmares: creating a product that no customer wants to buy. The main difference between these processes is their varied methods of creating the initial solution. Because positive deviance solutions come directly from the communities they are intended to serve, the pain points that might come along with bringing a top-down approach (perhaps created in a design thinking or lean start up lab) are mitigated. However, this also brings challenges: it is much easier to come up with ten possible solutions to a challenge than to find a specific deviant solution that is already successful. Design thinking solutions are built to solve a challenge that a customer faces, and I would argue, are probably more diverse than lean start-ups that originate in one founder’s mind. In my previous work in the federal government, I longed for more quick testing and modification of programs. Unfortunately, as suggested by the lean start-up article, there is little public toleration for failure in this space. Interestingly, the Obama Administration created a team of behavioral scientists within the White House who were instructed to help make government programs serve the public more effectively. For instance, this team found that by changing one word in an email to veterans encouraging them to sign up for health care benefits (“available benefits” was modified to “earned benefits”), they increased the benefit take-up rate by close to 10%.  I would love to hear from my classmates about their experiences working with these strategies, especially about how you can bring these ideas into organizations that are naturally resistant to them. -Liz Miller
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Positive deviance, design thinking and lean start-ups share one main commonality: an emphasis on listening to the consumer above all else. This mindset requires openness and receptivity, especially to ideas that one might initially find surprising. In positive deviance models, the entire solution is consumer-generated, having been identified as an existing practice that works well. For design-thinking, workers must strongly empathize with the customers they are designing for during the creation process. Finally, the lean-start up model prevents one of an entrepreneur’s worst nightmares: creating a product that no customer wants to buy.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The main difference between these processes is their varied methods of creating the initial solution. Because positive deviance solutions come directly from the communities they are intended to serve, the pain points that might come along with bringing a top-down approach (perhaps created in a design thinking or lean start up lab) are mitigated. However, this also brings challenges: it is much easier to come up with ten possible solutions to a challenge than to find a specific deviant solution that is already successful. Design thinking solutions are built to solve a challenge that a customer faces, and I would argue, are probably more diverse than lean start-ups that originate in one founder’s mind.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In my previous work in the federal government, I longed for more quick testing and modification of programs. Unfortunately, as suggested by the lean start-up article, there is little public toleration for failure in this space. Interestingly, the Obama Administration created a team of behavioral scientists within the White House who were instructed to help make government programs serve the public more effectively. For instance, this team found that by changing one word in an email to veterans encouraging them to sign up for health care benefits (“available benefits” was modified to “earned benefits”), they increased the benefit take-up rate by close to 10%.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         I would love to hear from my classmates about their experiences working with these strategies, especially about how you can bring these ideas into organizations that are naturally resistant to them.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        -Liz Miller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment (1 like)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Kevin Schuster

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Kevin Schuster

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 12:07pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Thanks so much for your post, Liz! It's really interesting to see how President Obama, who ran his campaign with lots of data and A/B testing which webpage works better, was able to keep those types of iterative approaches in some cases and how in others the stakes and bureaucracy of the government got in the way. One of the administration ideas that I really liked was running competitions on the state level to promote the best ideas - for example Race To The Top (think that's the right name) to encourage innovation at the state level around education outcomes with the best ideas receiving funding to scale. I wonder how big organizations like the government can use their power, funding, and ability to de-risk to encourage more nimble actors like towns or businesses to take on the innovation.  One way to get companies that are naturally resistant to these approaches to work with these approaches seems to be creation of innovation labs that are within the larger organization but have a level of autonomy. Similar to some of the concepts we discussed in Leading People. This of course involves organizations not being so resistant that they won't allow such a unit to exist. I've also heard of an innovation unit where part of the job of each employee within the lab was to run sessions with the larger organization on design thinking and to be embedded within certain project teams in the larger organization to infuse some of these strategies. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Thanks so much for your post, Liz! It's really interesting to see how President Obama, who ran his campaign with lots of data and A/B testing which webpage works better, was able to keep those types of iterative approaches in some cases and how in others the stakes and bureaucracy of the government got in the way. One of the administration ideas that I really liked was running competitions on the state level to promote the best ideas - for example Race To The Top (think that's the right name) to encourage innovation at the state level around education outcomes with the best ideas receiving funding to scale. I wonder how big organizations like the government can use their power, funding, and ability to de-risk to encourage more nimble actors like towns or businesses to take on the innovation. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            One way to get companies that are naturally resistant to these approaches to work with these approaches seems to be creation of innovation labs that are within the larger organization but have a level of autonomy. Similar to some of the concepts we discussed in Leading People. This of course involves organizations not being so resistant that they won't allow such a unit to exist. I've also heard of an innovation unit where part of the job of each employee within the lab was to run sessions with the larger organization on design thinking and to be embedded within certain project teams in the larger organization to infuse some of these strategies.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Beth Williams

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Beth Williams

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                May 1, 2017 May 1 at 10:58pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Hey Liz, Thanks for sharing this! I appreciated how you framed each of these in terms of the level of proximity to the end consumer (or beneficiary in the nonprofit context). And I remember reading the report put out by Obama's behavioral science team and finding it similarly interesting. From my own experience, initiatives like these have only succeeded when they have been championed from within by senior leadership. But I do think it's possible for staff members to pilot these on a smaller scale as proof of concept for larger initiatives. At my former organization, we received funding from a $18m annual appropriation from Congress (Called the Assets for Independence Act). I would absolutely love to see some of these principles applied there! They are in process of allocating $3m of that funding to an "innovation fund", so do think there is hope :) 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Hey Liz,

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Thanks for sharing this! I appreciated how you framed each of these in terms of the level of proximity to the end consumer (or beneficiary in the nonprofit context). And I remember reading the report put out by Obama's behavioral science team and finding it similarly interesting.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                From my own experience, initiatives like these have only succeeded when they have been championed from within by senior leadership. But I do think it's possible for staff members to pilot these on a smaller scale as proof of concept for larger initiatives. At my former organization, we received funding from a $18m annual appropriation from Congress (Called the Assets for Independence Act). I would absolutely love to see some of these principles applied there! They are in process of allocating $3m of that funding to an "innovation fund", so do think there is hope :) 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Edited by Beth Williams on May 1 at 10:58pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Sophie Kaady

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Sophie Kaady

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 10, 2017 Feb 10 at 8:05pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Each of the concepts discussed in the readings, “design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up” are methods used to spur innovation within organizations.  While the methods have tactical similarities across the board it seems as though design thinking and positive deviance are similar in that the starting point is focused on the experience, reaction, or emotion response of the customer or targeted community.  Those practicing these methods therefore much be able to set aside their own such reactions to ensure they are listening and acting on the feedback provided.  In the case of lean-start up one must have great steps in understanding the community in which they are working so as to understand how their proposed actions will be received, as the success of those actions is dependent on the community’s embrace. Lean start-up on the other hand seems to rely more heavily on data, with quantitative analysis and value proof points as the primary focus.  In practicing Lean start-up methods one would have to again set aside their own emotional response (likely very difficult for a founder/co-founder to achieve) and make decisions based on the metrics used in the method (MVP/s). Design thinking and Lean-start up do share similarities in that they heavily rely on experimentation and revisions to obtain the desired result. The financial services organizations I have worked with in the past largely have not utilized such methods to approach business decisions.  The extent to which they have imposed these methods relates to how they take on new business, and re-visit existing clients. In such a review process, there are predetermined metrics which must be met in order to proceed with the proposals.  These metrics include both financial and reputational aspects, and in recent years cultural fit has also played a role.  If such metrics are not met during the proposal or review the project is not pursued. I would expect that design thinking would the most applicable method of the three is most of the IBD projects.  Lean start-up would also be applicable in certain cases as well.  A large part of determining which method to use would be to understand where the organization is in its life cycle.  Early in the start-up phase the founders could benefit more from the Lean start-up approach, whereas after some growth the design thinking method could help the organization’s sustained growth and innovation. Design thinking is a term used commonly throughout Silicon Valley however I have yet to practice the methods first hand.  I am interested to hear if any others in the course have seen first-hand success stories in the realm of design thinking and how using such a method changes the way you approach problems in everyday life.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Each of the concepts discussed in the readings, “design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up” are methods used to spur innovation within organizations.  While the methods have tactical similarities across the board it seems as though design thinking and positive deviance are similar in that the starting point is focused on the experience, reaction, or emotion response of the customer or targeted community.  Those practicing these methods therefore much be able to set aside their own such reactions to ensure they are listening and acting on the feedback provided.  In the case of lean-start up one must have great steps in understanding the community in which they are working so as to understand how their proposed actions will be received, as the success of those actions is dependent on the community’s embrace. Lean start-up on the other hand seems to rely more heavily on data, with quantitative analysis and value proof points as the primary focus.  In practicing Lean start-up methods one would have to again set aside their own emotional response (likely very difficult for a founder/co-founder to achieve) and make decisions based on the metrics used in the method (MVP/s). Design thinking and Lean-start up do share similarities in that they heavily rely on experimentation and revisions to obtain the desired result.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  The financial services organizations I have worked with in the past largely have not utilized such methods to approach business decisions.  The extent to which they have imposed these methods relates to how they take on new business, and re-visit existing clients. In such a review process, there are predetermined metrics which must be met in order to proceed with the proposals.  These metrics include both financial and reputational aspects, and in recent years cultural fit has also played a role.  If such metrics are not met during the proposal or review the project is not pursued.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  I would expect that design thinking would the most applicable method of the three is most of the IBD projects.  Lean start-up would also be applicable in certain cases as well.  A large part of determining which method to use would be to understand where the organization is in its life cycle.  Early in the start-up phase the founders could benefit more from the Lean start-up approach, whereas after some growth the design thinking method could help the organization’s sustained growth and innovation.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Design thinking is a term used commonly throughout Silicon Valley however I have yet to practice the methods first hand.  I am interested to hear if any others in the course have seen first-hand success stories in the realm of design thinking and how using such a method changes the way you approach problems in everyday life.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Amol Borcar

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Amol Borcar

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Apr 18, 2017 Apr 18 at 8:51pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Hey Sophie, I actually do have some design thinking experience from before Haas, though it took me a little while to connect the dots.  When planning a workshop with one of my old managers, we developed a sample case that would capture the imaginations of the old economists in the crowd.  My manager never used the term "design thinking," she just said she didn't want it to be a boring lecture and she wanted people to "care" about it.  Afterwards I heard feedback from other attendees that the session was a huge success, so I guess we achieved our goal! Our IBD client is very open to design thinking, something I think is out of the ordinary where they're from (Turkey) and am excited to try these methods out with them!
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Hey Sophie, I actually do have some design thinking experience from before Haas, though it took me a little while to connect the dots.  When planning a workshop with one of my old managers, we developed a sample case that would capture the imaginations of the old economists in the crowd.  My manager never used the term "design thinking," she just said she didn't want it to be a boring lecture and she wanted people to "care" about it.  Afterwards I heard feedback from other attendees that the session was a huge success, so I guess we achieved our goal!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Our IBD client is very open to design thinking, something I think is out of the ordinary where they're from (Turkey) and am excited to try these methods out with them!

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Tulio Da Silveira

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Tulio Da Silveira

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 12, 2017 Feb 12 at 10:22pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When comparing the three approaches I believe design thinking requires a deep understanding of user's/customer's needs and wants, while lean start-up is more about the ability to prototype and react quickly. Positive deviance, on the other hand, encompasses identifying skills in a giving community and leveraging it. During an innovation process I believe they will have use in different timings. For example, design thinking will probably be more valuable in an initial exploration stage, while lean start-up is closer to the execution/implementation phase.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When comparing the three approaches I believe design thinking requires a deep understanding of user's/customer's needs and wants, while lean start-up is more about the ability to prototype and react quickly. Positive deviance, on the other hand, encompasses identifying skills in a giving community and leveraging it.


                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        During an innovation process I believe they will have use in different timings. For example, design thinking will probably be more valuable in an initial exploration stage, while lean start-up is closer to the execution/implementation phase.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Brian Burke

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Brian Burke

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Feb 13, 2017 Feb 13 at 12:52pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Agree 100% with your analysis of each approach having utility at different points within the product lifecycle. I'm also looking forward to leveraging design thinking and lean start-up on our IBD projects.   Quick question - when do you think a technique like positive deviance is most useful during the innovation process?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Agree 100% with your analysis of each approach having utility at different points within the product lifecycle. I'm also looking forward to leveraging design thinking and lean start-up on our IBD projects.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Quick question - when do you think a technique like positive deviance is most useful during the innovation process?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Amanda Eller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Amanda Eller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 9:55am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Great question Brian, I was thinking about this as well! I think positive deviance is especially useful for gaining community buy-in when the designers are outsiders. However, it is less useful than other techniques for selling products to a group, because it identifies things they are already doing. Therefore I view it as more useful for designing services and for social impact projects. It could also be used in an early concept stage for a new product (vs. later stage testing of an MVP.)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Great question Brian, I was thinking about this as well! I think positive deviance is especially useful for gaining community buy-in when the designers are outsiders. However, it is less useful than other techniques for selling products to a group, because it identifies things they are already doing. Therefore I view it as more useful for designing services and for social impact projects. It could also be used in an early concept stage for a new product (vs. later stage testing of an MVP.)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Mariana Martinez Alarcon

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 5:30pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Hi Brian, I like your question a lot! I think positive deviance will be most useful when we are trying to get buy in from a skeptical crowd. As we show the correlation between specific behaviors and positive outcomes, our power of persuation will increase!
