                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Brian, I'm curious to know if you've applied design thinking or lean start-up to your IBD project yet? If so, have the results been successful?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Amol Borcar

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Amol Borcar

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Apr 14, 2017 Apr 14 at 8:49pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          I find your take about timings interesting.  I felt that the design thinking reading tried to emphasize that design thinking should be observed/practiced at all points in a company's life to avoid it becoming stale.  Once a company has a mature product, it should not rely on that product to carry it forever, and design thinking skills are necessary to understand what your customers will need from the next generation of products.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          I find your take about timings interesting.  I felt that the design thinking reading tried to emphasize that design thinking should be observed/practiced at all points in a company's life to avoid it becoming stale.  Once a company has a mature product, it should not rely on that product to carry it forever, and design thinking skills are necessary to understand what your customers will need from the next generation of products.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Manav Khurana

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Manav Khurana

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Feb 14, 2017 Feb 14 at 10:37pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            In my opinion, the biggest similarity between design thinking, positive deviance, and lean start-up is that they are all customer-focused. Design thinking attempts to appeal to the emotions of customers by providing intuitive and pleasurable experiences with products and services. Positive deviance attempts to utilize an uncommon, beneficial practice to improve the lifestyles of people in a certain community. Lean start-ups try to launch MVPs as soon as possible to satisfy customer needs and test prototypes. Each of these methods have the customers in mind and try to improve the user-experience of products and services.   However, I believe that each approach targets a different aspect of the customer. For example, design thinking attempts to target more of the emotional appeal of customers. Companies that incorporate design thinking try to simplify their products and humanize the experience of using specific products and services. This seems more of a luxury trait to have (it is not absolutely necessary to appeal to the emotional sense of a customer). Positive deviance focuses more on providing customers with the tools to improve their lives. This is especially important for impoverished communities where certain families may not know how to improve their living standards. This seems more of a necessity (communication across peers is key, especially if it can benefit everyone). Lean start-ups focus more on meeting customers’ demands and attempt to test what customers are looking for. This is necessary for the company to succeed in the future and for the customer to provide feedback on products and services.         This may be a stretch, but I believe my previous firm utilized positive deviance when underwriting commercial loans (basically think of a bank that lends money to real estate investors). My company would often observe how peers in the industry were completing their underwriting processes and figure out why they may have been more successful or efficient. If there was something that we could do to improve our efficiency and improve our processes, we would try to implement it as soon as possible. If our peers were outperforming us (on a revenue basis or in the number underwritten loans), we would try to figure out what they were doing and adopt their methodology to experience similar success.   (I’m not sure if this is positive deviance, because the article only focused on impoverish communities. Can positive deviance pertain to corporations too? Does my example make sense?)       I think of a mix of all three approaches is most valuable for IBD. We will be consulting for a technology firm in another country to we need to find out what our competitors or peers are doing in the industry (positive deviance), appeal to our customers’ emotions to successfully launch a product a service (design thinking), AND launch MVPs and prototypes to really figure out how to best serve our customers (lean start-ups).   My biggest question is: Which approach should be taken first when working with our IBD teams? When is each approach appropriate to use?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            In my opinion, the biggest similarity between design thinking, positive deviance, and lean start-up is that they are all customer-focused. Design thinking attempts to appeal to the emotions of customers by providing intuitive and pleasurable experiences with products and services. Positive deviance attempts to utilize an uncommon, beneficial practice to improve the lifestyles of people in a certain community. Lean start-ups try to launch MVPs as soon as possible to satisfy customer needs and test prototypes. Each of these methods have the customers in mind and try to improve the user-experience of products and services.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            However, I believe that each approach targets a different aspect of the customer. For example, design thinking attempts to target more of the emotional appeal of customers. Companies that incorporate design thinking try to simplify their products and humanize the experience of using specific products and services. This seems more of a luxury trait to have (it is not absolutely necessary to appeal to the emotional sense of a customer). Positive deviance focuses more on providing customers with the tools to improve their lives. This is especially important for impoverished communities where certain families may not know how to improve their living standards. This seems more of a necessity (communication across peers is key, especially if it can benefit everyone). Lean start-ups focus more on meeting customers’ demands and attempt to test what customers are looking for. This is necessary for the company to succeed in the future and for the customer to provide feedback on products and services.  

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            This may be a stretch, but I believe my previous firm utilized positive deviance when underwriting commercial loans (basically think of a bank that lends money to real estate investors). My company would often observe how peers in the industry were completing their underwriting processes and figure out why they may have been more successful or efficient. If there was something that we could do to improve our efficiency and improve our processes, we would try to implement it as soon as possible. If our peers were outperforming us (on a revenue basis or in the number underwritten loans), we would try to figure out what they were doing and adopt their methodology to experience similar success.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            (I’m not sure if this is positive deviance, because the article only focused on impoverish communities. Can positive deviance pertain to corporations too? Does my example make sense?)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            I think of a mix of all three approaches is most valuable for IBD. We will be consulting for a technology firm in another country to we need to find out what our competitors or peers are doing in the industry (positive deviance), appeal to our customers’ emotions to successfully launch a product a service (design thinking), AND launch MVPs and prototypes to really figure out how to best serve our customers (lean start-ups).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            My biggest question is: Which approach should be taken first when working with our IBD teams? When is each approach appropriate to use?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Interesting example from banking.  I'm interested to know if adopting practices from peers was as easy as observing and implementing or if these practices required a bit of adaption as the operating environment of your firm may have varied a bit from that of peers.

For Wildcard it seems as though we may have to incorporate aspects of all three approaches, but once again it'll be very project dependent.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    I have a similar question about what approach will be best for IBD. I really think it will come down to the specific projects that we get assigned to. I envision design thinking to be especially useful for a project focused on consumer-facing technilogy. For Wildcard it seems as though we may have to incorporate aspects of all three approaches, but once again it'll be very project dependent.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Anik Mathur

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Anik Mathur

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 15, 2017 Feb 15 at 8:15pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      One similarity I found between “design thinking,” “positive deviance,” and “lean start-up” was the focus on learning more about the end user.  Design thinking incorporates the idea of focusing on user experiences, specifically on the emotional side.  Positive Deviance requires intensive information gathering, which can include in-depth inquiries, community norms studies, and community vetting.  This is to understand the behaviors of people with and without good health.  Lean Start-up method is based on the idea of testing your hypothesis, which often involves testing hypotheses around potential product acceptance and product needs of end consumers.  A difference between the three is that while design thinking and lean start-up rely heavily on testing, positive deviance relies on a solution that potentially already exists and is in use.  The first two require testing, such as developing prototypes, testing on customers, and performing MVP tests, while the last relies on identifying what is already working on a population and applying it to the rest.  These methods have been promoted and applied in past organizations I’ve worked with.  At Facebook, every single decision regarding the user interface was made after intensive user testing, with a huge emotional component.  Simplicity was a requirement in every new feature implemented.  In addition, prototypes of features were developed and testing on a few clients during the ad product development process.  Finally, there was a higher than normal tolerance for failure, as one of our key mottos was to move fast and since we were entering an unfamiliar realm of advertising, so failures were expected.  Positive deviance was applied through promotion of collaboration between the numerous individual advertising sales teams.  Many issues were faced by advertisers across our clientele, however, Facebook made it a point to quickly inform everyone of outlying wins.  This allowed for us to learn from the 1 or 2 teams that were experiencing success and apply their best practices to our own clients.  However, lapses in communication still existed and efficient collaboration was still an area the organization was working on. Hypothesis testing was also a key initiative as our advertising products became more complex.  Advertisers now had to make decisions on which of their advertising channels were truly more effective and on what the optimal way was to advertise on Facebook.  Because of this, we developed a statistically sound method of performing A/B tests to test the hypotheses of our clients.  Design thinking will be especially useful in our upcoming International Business Development course.  The project will likely involve determining what the idea international expansion plan would be for a technology company.  A major aspect of design thinking that will be utilized is the idea of creating models to examine complex problems.  Our projects will likely involve a significant amount of work around developing models which illustrate the business trajectory of various options of expansion.  I would like to learn how my classmates have applied positive deviance in their own careers.  It is a method that I found very interesting when applied to different contexts than the one I experienced, such as in health promotion.  I am particularly interested in examples involving human behavior.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      One similarity I found between “design thinking,” “positive deviance,” and “lean start-up” was the focus on learning more about the end user.  Design thinking incorporates the idea of focusing on user experiences, specifically on the emotional side.  Positive Deviance requires intensive information gathering, which can include in-depth inquiries, community norms studies, and community vetting.  This is to understand the behaviors of people with and without good health.  Lean Start-up method is based on the idea of testing your hypothesis, which often involves testing hypotheses around potential product acceptance and product needs of end consumers.  A difference between the three is that while design thinking and lean start-up rely heavily on testing, positive deviance relies on a solution that potentially already exists and is in use.  The first two require testing, such as developing prototypes, testing on customers, and performing MVP tests, while the last relies on identifying what is already working on a population and applying it to the rest. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      These methods have been promoted and applied in past organizations I’ve worked with.  At Facebook, every single decision regarding the user interface was made after intensive user testing, with a huge emotional component.  Simplicity was a requirement in every new feature implemented.  In addition, prototypes of features were developed and testing on a few clients during the ad product development process.  Finally, there was a higher than normal tolerance for failure, as one of our key mottos was to move fast and since we were entering an unfamiliar realm of advertising, so failures were expected. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Positive deviance was applied through promotion of collaboration between the numerous individual advertising sales teams.  Many issues were faced by advertisers across our clientele, however, Facebook made it a point to quickly inform everyone of outlying wins.  This allowed for us to learn from the 1 or 2 teams that were experiencing success and apply their best practices to our own clients.  However, lapses in communication still existed and efficient collaboration was still an area the organization was working on.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Hypothesis testing was also a key initiative as our advertising products became more complex.  Advertisers now had to make decisions on which of their advertising channels were truly more effective and on what the optimal way was to advertise on Facebook.  Because of this, we developed a statistically sound method of performing A/B tests to test the hypotheses of our clients. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Design thinking will be especially useful in our upcoming International Business Development course.  The project will likely involve determining what the idea international expansion plan would be for a technology company.  A major aspect of design thinking that will be utilized is the idea of creating models to examine complex problems.  Our projects will likely involve a significant amount of work around developing models which illustrate the business trajectory of various options of expansion. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I would like to learn how my classmates have applied positive deviance in their own careers.  It is a method that I found very interesting when applied to different contexts than the one I experienced, such as in health promotion.  I am particularly interested in examples involving human behavior.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Amanda Eller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 9:57am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          I like your point that positive deviance can be used to identify successful behaviors within an organization and not just within customer/user groups. Depending on the projects we are assigned, this could be a useful technique in our IBD projects.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          I like your point that positive deviance can be used to identify successful behaviors within an organization and not just within customer/user groups. Depending on the projects we are assigned, this could be a useful technique in our IBD projects.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Jefferson Neblett

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 3:24pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I also believe Design Thinking will be especially important in our IBD course. However, it does seem like there will be some drawbacks to the approach as we will be consulted on a project with a limited time frame to implement changes that hopefully have a significant impact. I'm curious to explore how we can think about modifying the Design Thinking approach to better fit our IBD course and projects we may be on.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I also believe Design Thinking will be especially important in our IBD course. However, it does seem like there will be some drawbacks to the approach as we will be consulted on a project with a limited time frame to implement changes that hopefully have a significant impact. I'm curious to explore how we can think about modifying the Design Thinking approach to better fit our IBD course and projects we may be on.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Mariana Martinez Alarcon

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Mariana Martinez Alarcon

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Mar 13, 2017 Mar 13 at 5:37pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Hi Anik, I applied positive deviance when I was working on my undergrad thesis dissertation. I was trying to find what health-related behaviors were statistically significant predictors of chronic diseases. Using a Mexican national survey of over 18,000 respondents that were interviewed in 2007 and in 2009, I looked into their responses for daily habits. What was their diet like? Were they smokers?I used a multivariate probabilistic model to assess which of these behaviors in 2004 contributed significantly to the probability of the person presenting a chronic disease in 2009. Although this was a more academic framework, much of the intuition behind it was based on positive deviance.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Hi Anik, I applied positive deviance when I was working on my undergrad thesis dissertation. I was trying to find what health-related behaviors were statistically significant predictors of chronic diseases.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Using a Mexican national survey of over 18,000 respondents that were interviewed in 2007 and in 2009, I looked into their responses for daily habits. What was their diet like? Were they smokers?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  I used a multivariate probabilistic model to assess which of these behaviors in 2004 contributed significantly to the probability of the person presenting a chronic disease in 2009. Although this was a more academic framework, much of the intuition behind it was based on positive deviance.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Amanda Eller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Amanda Eller

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 9:51am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    “Design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up” all share an emphasis on identifying which idea most excites the target user group, and then putting resources behind that idea, rather than traditional approaches which push an idea at users from the top down and put resource behind untested or poorly tested ideas. All three approaches requires designers to embrace failure and accept the fact that their hypotheses may be wrong, in order to arrive at the correct answer.   My previous work experiences are with early stage startups, so the above approaches were integral to our work. For example, at Dear Kate we had a product that we knew customers liked, but needed to determine which customer segment would be easiest and cheapest to reach through marketing. We took a systematic "lean startup" approach, by identifying a different segment each month (hypothesis) and three ideas for reaching that group. We then ran pilots of those marketing initiatives, and rigorously tracked conversation rates and customer acquisition costs. After a few months, we had enough information to allocate more significant marketing budgets without risking huge losses.   On the other hand, at SunFarmer we could have employed even more of a design thinking approach. We were certainly lean, testing MVPs of products and iterating quickly and constantly on our business model. But when we tried to expand to a new product and business model (solar powered water pumping for farmers in Nepal) we faced more difficulties. This target customer group (rural, poor, farmers) was significantly different from the urban customers we knew well. Of the three approaches, positive deviance best accounts for managing the outsider-insider dynamics inherent in many international development projects. We designed products based on customer interviews and pilots, but still struggled with aspects of the business model because we did not understand the customers as well as we thought.   In reflecting on the above experiences in light of the upcoming IBD project, it is clear that we will be outsiders, and must manage risks associated with the outsider-insider dynamic. This means that we should check in frequently with the client, and rather than simply run ideas by them, should attempt to test ideas with them by create something with which they can interact.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Open in SpeedGrader
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    “Design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up” all share an emphasis on identifying which idea most excites the target user group, and then putting resources behind that idea, rather than traditional approaches which push an idea at users from the top down and put resource behind untested or poorly tested ideas. All three approaches requires designers to embrace failure and accept the fact that their hypotheses may be wrong, in order to arrive at the correct answer.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    My previous work experiences are with early stage startups, so the above approaches were integral to our work. For example, at Dear Kate we had a product that we knew customers liked, but needed to determine which customer segment would be easiest and cheapest to reach through marketing. We took a systematic "lean startup" approach, by identifying a different segment each month (hypothesis) and three ideas for reaching that group. We then ran pilots of those marketing initiatives, and rigorously tracked conversation rates and customer acquisition costs. After a few months, we had enough information to allocate more significant marketing budgets without risking huge losses.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    On the other hand, at SunFarmer we could have employed even more of a design thinking approach. We were certainly lean, testing MVPs of products and iterating quickly and constantly on our business model. But when we tried to expand to a new product and business model (solar powered water pumping for farmers in Nepal) we faced more difficulties. This target customer group (rural, poor, farmers) was significantly different from the urban customers we knew well. Of the three approaches, positive deviance best accounts for managing the outsider-insider dynamics inherent in many international development projects. We designed products based on customer interviews and pilots, but still struggled with aspects of the business model because we did not understand the customers as well as we thought.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    In reflecting on the above experiences in light of the upcoming IBD project, it is clear that we will be outsiders, and must manage risks associated with the outsider-insider dynamic. This means that we should check in frequently with the client, and rather than simply run ideas by them, should attempt to test ideas with them by create something with which they can interact.
