                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Taylor Jordan

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Taylor Jordan

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 11:30am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Can you speak at all to the challenges of implementing these various processes while working from abroad?  In working on our IBD projects, how can we ensure we are truly understanding our end users' needs without being fully immersed in the culture day to day?  Or do you think this plays any role?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Can you speak at all to the challenges of implementing these various processes while working from abroad?  In working on our IBD projects, how can we ensure we are truly understanding our end users' needs without being fully immersed in the culture day to day?  Or do you think this plays any role?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Gloria Gerngross

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Gloria Gerngross

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 3:58pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            I agree that all three approaches to solve problems require designers to embrace failure. However, you mentioned that these approaches are about identifying which idea most excites the target user. I'm not sure I agree with this because I think it is more identifying which idea best solves the problem. As an example we read about positive deviance and how a study group figured out that eating eggs, beans and green vegetables reduces child malnourishment. I don't think this solution excited anyone but was an easy and cheap solution for the problem. Cakes and sweets would probably lead to more excitement :)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            I agree that all three approaches to solve problems require designers to embrace failure. However, you mentioned that these approaches are about identifying which idea most excites the target user. I'm not sure I agree with this because I think it is more identifying which idea best solves the problem. As an example we read about positive deviance and how a study group figured out that eating eggs, beans and green vegetables reduces child malnourishment. I don't think this solution excited anyone but was an easy and cheap solution for the problem. Cakes and sweets would probably lead to more excitement :)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Kevin Schuster

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Kevin Schuster

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 10:38am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The three approaches have a lot of similar themes. One of these themes is openness – being open to any and all ideas (design thinking), being open to what already works (positive deviance), and being open to having your hypotheses rejected (lean start-up). Another common theme is continuous improvement whether it’s the iterative cycles of design thinking and lean start-up or the monitoring and evaluation improvement process in positive deviance. Experimentation is another common theme as all approaches start with observations or hypotheses and eventually lead to some type of test to measure the effectiveness. On the differences between the approaches, lean start-up and design thinking seem to bring more of a blank canvas mindset to the work while positive deviance has more of a “let’s uncover what’s already working here” mindset. Design thinking and positive deviance have more of an empathetic mindset of listening and observation, while lean start-up is more on the spectrum of a scientific method mindset (although some tests do have empathetic qualities like getting a product into a user’s hands and observing). Positive deviance stands out as an approach that would have greatly benefited the work of the organization I previously worked with, VOTO Mobile. VOTO works with NGOs to provide mobile phone content to low-literacy populations in developing markets. The content was predominantly health focused, for example providing maternal health education to mothers in rural Ghana. Too often we worked with our partners with a top-down or donor driven approach when deciding what content to provide – for example adapting content from UNICEF for our maternal health campaign without taking into account practices that could already be working in these communities. I think we missed out on an opportunity to make the content more engaging, to gather greater buy-in from the communities, and to be more effective in changing behaviors. One partner we worked with who did take a positive deviance type approach was IDEO.org. We worked with them on a project in Tanzania where we set up a hotline number for mothers to call in to share advice on childhood development practices. These practices were then aggregated and shared via radio and through community groups. While VOTO’s work lacked on the positive deviance approach, I do think we made a good effort on incorporating design thinking, particularly the concept of human-centered design, into our program work. For example, in the process of launching a mobile communication program in Sierra Leone related to a Ebola hygiene and sanitation program, we conducted a serious of focus groups with families and community members. I think because we came into the conversations with a listening and observation mindset, we ended up designing another program with the community members that we had not intended on. We learned that parents and community members were concerned that so many kids were out of school due to the Ebola outbreak and that a health issue was now becoming an education issue. Through learning about families’ access to technology and that kids weren’t able to leave their homes for the most part, we ended up designing a solution that used radio to provide education lessons (most prevalent form of communication and allows kids to listen in their houses) and mobile phones for kids to engage with quizzes and additional content (teachers and NGOs stressed the need to for an interactive solution that could measure progress). I’ve had a complicated relationship with lean start-up methodology. On the one hand, it makes total sense and holds so much potential. On the other hand, I’ve found it to be very difficult to implement in practice. In my first job where I taught and advised aspiring software entrepreneurs in Ghana, The Lean Start-up by Eric Reis was required reading. Entrepreneurs were bought into the mindset and eager to approach the methodology to their startups. In practice, I saw few examples of startups actually using the approach. The natural tendency for engineers is to want their product to be complete before releasing it versus exposing a minimal viable product to scrutiny. Web developers tend to trust their gut on what landing page will work versus trying out multiple versions. Business leads are eager to jump right into scaling a product versus observing with a small group of users. This is no knock on the methodology itself, just my experiences that with cash and resource strapped entrepreneurs, the discipline to stick to the methodology can be difficult. In a way, this is ironic as bootstrapped startups would benefit most from starting with small and inexpensive tests, but I’ve seen that the pressure of the situation can encourage taking big bets early on in attempt to get to sustainability and growth quickly. I actually think it’s easier for the innovation units of large companies to have the resources and patience to implement Lean Start-up approaches. I’d be curious to get classmates thoughts who have experiences trying to implement lean start-up.  Within the IBD projects, I think all of the approaches have the potential to be helpful. With our teams entering new markets, new cultures, new industries, and a new company – approaching the problems with a mindset that is focused on being open-minded, being empathetic, and running experiments will lead to better outcomes than approaches that are more prone to thinking we have all the right answers and that rely on our guts. The positive deviance approach brings a mindset of seeing what works already and not needing to always reinvent the wheel. Design thinking will encourage us to get outside of our four walls to observe and talk with people, and to open our minds to all types of ideas. I also think there could be a lot of value in testing some hypotheses with the lean start-up approach. Given the relatively short amount of time we will spend working with our partner organization, one of the areas where we could provide the most value is through the data and findings that can come out of targeted experiments within the lean start-up approach.  
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The three approaches have a lot of similar themes. One of these themes is openness – being open to any and all ideas (design thinking), being open to what already works (positive deviance), and being open to having your hypotheses rejected (lean start-up). Another common theme is continuous improvement whether it’s the iterative cycles of design thinking and lean start-up or the monitoring and evaluation improvement process in positive deviance. Experimentation is another common theme as all approaches start with observations or hypotheses and eventually lead to some type of test to measure the effectiveness.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              On the differences between the approaches, lean start-up and design thinking seem to bring more of a blank canvas mindset to the work while positive deviance has more of a “let’s uncover what’s already working here” mindset. Design thinking and positive deviance have more of an empathetic mindset of listening and observation, while lean start-up is more on the spectrum of a scientific method mindset (although some tests do have empathetic qualities like getting a product into a user’s hands and observing).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Positive deviance stands out as an approach that would have greatly benefited the work of the organization I previously worked with, VOTO Mobile. VOTO works with NGOs to provide mobile phone content to low-literacy populations in developing markets. The content was predominantly health focused, for example providing maternal health education to mothers in rural Ghana. Too often we worked with our partners with a top-down or donor driven approach when deciding what content to provide – for example adapting content from UNICEF for our maternal health campaign without taking into account practices that could already be working in these communities. I think we missed out on an opportunity to make the content more engaging, to gather greater buy-in from the communities, and to be more effective in changing behaviors. One partner we worked with who did take a positive deviance type approach was IDEO.org. We worked with them on a project in Tanzania where we set up a hotline number for mothers to call in to share advice on childhood development practices. These practices were then aggregated and shared via radio and through community groups.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              While VOTO’s work lacked on the positive deviance approach, I do think we made a good effort on incorporating design thinking, particularly the concept of human-centered design, into our program work. For example, in the process of launching a mobile communication program in Sierra Leone related to a Ebola hygiene and sanitation program, we conducted a serious of focus groups with families and community members. I think because we came into the conversations with a listening and observation mindset, we ended up designing another program with the community members that we had not intended on. We learned that parents and community members were concerned that so many kids were out of school due to the Ebola outbreak and that a health issue was now becoming an education issue. Through learning about families’ access to technology and that kids weren’t able to leave their homes for the most part, we ended up designing a solution that used radio to provide education lessons (most prevalent form of communication and allows kids to listen in their houses) and mobile phones for kids to engage with quizzes and additional content (teachers and NGOs stressed the need to for an interactive solution that could measure progress).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I’ve had a complicated relationship with lean start-up methodology. On the one hand, it makes total sense and holds so much potential. On the other hand, I’ve found it to be very difficult to implement in practice. In my first job where I taught and advised aspiring software entrepreneurs in Ghana, The Lean Start-up by Eric Reis was required reading. Entrepreneurs were bought into the mindset and eager to approach the methodology to their startups. In practice, I saw few examples of startups actually using the approach. The natural tendency for engineers is to want their product to be complete before releasing it versus exposing a minimal viable product to scrutiny. Web developers tend to trust their gut on what landing page will work versus trying out multiple versions. Business leads are eager to jump right into scaling a product versus observing with a small group of users. This is no knock on the methodology itself, just my experiences that with cash and resource strapped entrepreneurs, the discipline to stick to the methodology can be difficult. In a way, this is ironic as bootstrapped startups would benefit most from starting with small and inexpensive tests, but I’ve seen that the pressure of the situation can encourage taking big bets early on in attempt to get to sustainability and growth quickly. I actually think it’s easier for the innovation units of large companies to have the resources and patience to implement Lean Start-up approaches. I’d be curious to get classmates thoughts who have experiences trying to implement lean start-up. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Within the IBD projects, I think all of the approaches have the potential to be helpful. With our teams entering new markets, new cultures, new industries, and a new company – approaching the problems with a mindset that is focused on being open-minded, being empathetic, and running experiments will lead to better outcomes than approaches that are more prone to thinking we have all the right answers and that rely on our guts. The positive deviance approach brings a mindset of seeing what works already and not needing to always reinvent the wheel. Design thinking will encourage us to get outside of our four walls to observe and talk with people, and to open our minds to all types of ideas. I also think there could be a lot of value in testing some hypotheses with the lean start-up approach. Given the relatively short amount of time we will spend working with our partner organization, one of the areas where we could provide the most value is through the data and findings that can come out of targeted experiments within the lean start-up approach.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Tulio Da Silveira

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 20, 2017 Feb 20 at 3:35pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Hi Kevin, enjoyed reading about your experience with design thinking in NGOs. How do you think you might have incorporate positive deviance better in your past experience?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Hi Kevin, enjoyed reading about your experience with design thinking in NGOs. How do you think you might have incorporate positive deviance better in your past experience?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Beth Williams

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Beth Williams

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      May 1, 2017 May 1 at 11:05pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Thanks for sharing about your work experience Kevin! I enjoyed reading your posting. In my own experience in the nonprofit sector I also have experience the pressure of funders wanting to implement their own solutions (i.e. they have spent a lot of money surveying "best-practices" but have limited experience interacting themselves with the beneficiaries or processes/systems they are trying to influence). I like how you described all three of the approaches as being based in a mindset of being accepting of/encouraging failure. I think that's a healthy approach, but also somewhat challenging dynamic in the nonprofit sector, as most funders are looking to support proven and impactful projects (not projects that might "fail"). I think this reduces innovation overall in the sector. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Thanks for sharing about your work experience Kevin! I enjoyed reading your posting. In my own experience in the nonprofit sector I also have experience the pressure of funders wanting to implement their own solutions (i.e. they have spent a lot of money surveying "best-practices" but have limited experience interacting themselves with the beneficiaries or processes/systems they are trying to influence).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I like how you described all three of the approaches as being based in a mindset of being accepting of/encouraging failure. I think that's a healthy approach, but also somewhat challenging dynamic in the nonprofit sector, as most funders are looking to support proven and impactful projects (not projects that might "fail"). I think this reduces innovation overall in the sector. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Mike Solarz

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Mike Solarz

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 10:57am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        “Design thinking”, “lean start-up” and “positive deviance” are all diverse approaches to tackling potentially complicated problems, resulting in positive outcomes for the end-user and beneficiary.  All of these approaches tend to have a “human-centered” approach in understanding the specific needs, wants, and reactions of end-users and, in many instances, trials and iterative processes are necessary to result in optimal outcomes.   Based upon the readings, while these concepts do seem very similar at a high level, the approaches and associated challenges tend to differ—the main premise around design thinking is to consider the end-user’s needs in utilizing a specific process or interface and requires a deep understanding of how an end-user will interact with a system or interface.  The challenges around lean start-up tend to be more focused on resource constraints and limiting expenditures during the ideation process—while there may be a strong focus on the end-user at the beginning, there doesn’t have to be, as the idea might initially be developed utilizing the founder’s vision (though the process does call for a human-centered focus later on, if not utilized initially).  The concept of positive deviance also focuses on positive outcomes for the end-user, but faces the unique challenge of defying the traditional mindset or norms of a culture and requires persuasion and motivation to a constituency which may be used to doing things very differently.   In previous organizations I’ve worked for, development of these approaches was utilized via in-company brainstorming sessions for ideation.  Additionally, the cultures of the organizations I worked for encouraged questioning the status quo, leading to “positive deviance”.  While working as an auditor, the firm I worked for was constantly streamlining templates and our software interface to make the process easier for employees and clients alike.  However, there was very minimal emphasis on collecting data from clients or beneficiaries involved—had more specific data been collected from end-users, I think that processes could have been further streamlined.   I think all of these approaches will come into play when working on my IBD project.  Specifically, I will be interested how positive deviance comes into play, as we will be bringing an American perspective to a foreign country and I will be interested to see if any “best practices” from America will differ from the “status quo” of the country in which we work.  It will be important to determine if these American practices are beneficial in a foreign country or detrimental given the cultural context.  Additionally, I am sure there will be a need for consideration for design thinking and end-users within our consulting project, but given the fact I do not yet know what project I will be working on, I am unsure how this will manifest itself.   I do tend to wonder how the need for utilizing these approaches will differ amongst different Applied Innovation courses and also within different clients within the IBD Program.  I also wonder what specific challenges my classmates who have heavily focused on these approaches in their previous jobs have faced in implementing.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        “Design thinking”, “lean start-up” and “positive deviance” are all diverse approaches to tackling potentially complicated problems, resulting in positive outcomes for the end-user and beneficiary.  All of these approaches tend to have a “human-centered” approach in understanding the specific needs, wants, and reactions of end-users and, in many instances, trials and iterative processes are necessary to result in optimal outcomes.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Based upon the readings, while these concepts do seem very similar at a high level, the approaches and associated challenges tend to differ—the main premise around design thinking is to consider the end-user’s needs in utilizing a specific process or interface and requires a deep understanding of how an end-user will interact with a system or interface.  The challenges around lean start-up tend to be more focused on resource constraints and limiting expenditures during the ideation process—while there may be a strong focus on the end-user at the beginning, there doesn’t have to be, as the idea might initially be developed utilizing the founder’s vision (though the process does call for a human-centered focus later on, if not utilized initially).  The concept of positive deviance also focuses on positive outcomes for the end-user, but faces the unique challenge of defying the traditional mindset or norms of a culture and requires persuasion and motivation to a constituency which may be used to doing things very differently.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In previous organizations I’ve worked for, development of these approaches was utilized via in-company brainstorming sessions for ideation.  Additionally, the cultures of the organizations I worked for encouraged questioning the status quo, leading to “positive deviance”.  While working as an auditor, the firm I worked for was constantly streamlining templates and our software interface to make the process easier for employees and clients alike.  However, there was very minimal emphasis on collecting data from clients or beneficiaries involved—had more specific data been collected from end-users, I think that processes could have been further streamlined.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        I think all of these approaches will come into play when working on my IBD project.  Specifically, I will be interested how positive deviance comes into play, as we will be bringing an American perspective to a foreign country and I will be interested to see if any “best practices” from America will differ from the “status quo” of the country in which we work.  It will be important to determine if these American practices are beneficial in a foreign country or detrimental given the cultural context.  Additionally, I am sure there will be a need for consideration for design thinking and end-users within our consulting project, but given the fact I do not yet know what project I will be working on, I am unsure how this will manifest itself.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        I do tend to wonder how the need for utilizing these approaches will differ amongst different Applied Innovation courses and also within different clients within the IBD Program.  I also wonder what specific challenges my classmates who have heavily focused on these approaches in their previous jobs have faced in implementing.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Taylor Jordan

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Taylor Jordan

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 11:25am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            When new software templates were implemented, what was the initial reaction from colleagues and customers?  It seems that whenever online platforms/apps make a change - i.e. Instagram, Facebook, etc. -- the first reaction is outrage.  Did you experience this at your company?  Were there any tactics that were particularly useful to ease transition or did it rely more on time and adaptation?  When the company decided to make changes, how did they make these decisions?  Did they often prototype, A/B test, seek feedback from employees and/or customers?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            When new software templates were implemented, what was the initial reaction from colleagues and customers?  It seems that whenever online platforms/apps make a change - i.e. Instagram, Facebook, etc. -- the first reaction is outrage.  Did you experience this at your company?  Were there any tactics that were particularly useful to ease transition or did it rely more on time and adaptation?  When the company decided to make changes, how did they make these decisions?  Did they often prototype, A/B test, seek feedback from employees and/or customers?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Taylor Jordan

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Taylor Jordan

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 11:13am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Design thinking, positive deviance, and lean start-up all approach problems with a focus on the end-user.  Design thinking urges one to create an emotionally enjoyable experience for the end user through prototyping and failure tolerance.  Lean start-up theory reiterates the importance of prototyping and urges entrepreneurs to launch early and often; that is, lean start-up encourages testing falsifiable hypotheses early and often to ensure the product development aligns with a true market need.  Both design thinking and lean start-up encourage reevaluation of the product throughout the design and development process, encouraging entrepreneurs to accept surprising feedback and pivot as needed.  Positive deviance focuses on the end user, but in a slightly different way.  It encourages policy and/or practice change through example.  We do still see a clear focus on ensuring ease of use and adaptability.  Both lean start-up and positive deviance deal with resource constraint challenges, positive deviance to a larger extent.  In general, all three have similar themes around adaptability and a focus on the end user, but positive deviance tends to focus on policy and practice changes while lean start-up and design thinking focus on product/service development.      In my past work, I saw elements of positive deviance, though with a different twist than was discussed in the article.  I worked in medical device sales and partnered with physicians to optimize patient outcomes regularly.  Best practices for various procedures were changing constantly and it was crucial that physicians and I stayed up to date on the latest published literature.  Additionally, physicians relied on me to bring best practices back from key opinion leaders with whom I worked at other accounts.  This sharing of information allowed us to adapt our procedures to incorporate fairly easy “fixes” to improve our workflow.  One of my greatest frustrations with my company was how little they sought feedback from physicians and field personnel.  During the product design process, they certainly did not sufficiently follow the “launch early and often” concept.  While it can be challenging to launch early and often in such a highly regulated industry, they certainly could have done more with constrained functionality and/or operational capability – i.e. more product demos throughout development process even if not using in human.   Looking toward my IBD project, I anticipate using positive deviance, as the markets in which we are working are emerging and likely have resource constraints.  Additionally, in order to get buy in from people in a culture I might not understand, positive deviance will be useful.  I also look forward to using A/B testing to test falsifiable hypotheses.  I anticipate needing to do significant market research to understand the international market in which we are working and A/B testing will prove invaluable in truly ensuring our approach meets the needs of our end users.  To that end, I’d love to hear ideas on how to run A/B testing on hypotheses while working from abroad?  Will we be able to follow lean start-up practices despite not working full time in our target market?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Design thinking, positive deviance, and lean start-up all approach problems with a focus on the end-user.  Design thinking urges one to create an emotionally enjoyable experience for the end user through prototyping and failure tolerance.  Lean start-up theory reiterates the importance of prototyping and urges entrepreneurs to launch early and often; that is, lean start-up encourages testing falsifiable hypotheses early and often to ensure the product development aligns with a true market need.  Both design thinking and lean start-up encourage reevaluation of the product throughout the design and development process, encouraging entrepreneurs to accept surprising feedback and pivot as needed.  Positive deviance focuses on the end user, but in a slightly different way.  It encourages policy and/or practice change through example.  We do still see a clear focus on ensuring ease of use and adaptability.  Both lean start-up and positive deviance deal with resource constraint challenges, positive deviance to a larger extent.  In general, all three have similar themes around adaptability and a focus on the end user, but positive deviance tends to focus on policy and practice changes while lean start-up and design thinking focus on product/service development.   

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              In my past work, I saw elements of positive deviance, though with a different twist than was discussed in the article.  I worked in medical device sales and partnered with physicians to optimize patient outcomes regularly.  Best practices for various procedures were changing constantly and it was crucial that physicians and I stayed up to date on the latest published literature.  Additionally, physicians relied on me to bring best practices back from key opinion leaders with whom I worked at other accounts.  This sharing of information allowed us to adapt our procedures to incorporate fairly easy “fixes” to improve our workflow.  One of my greatest frustrations with my company was how little they sought feedback from physicians and field personnel.  During the product design process, they certainly did not sufficiently follow the “launch early and often” concept.  While it can be challenging to launch early and often in such a highly regulated industry, they certainly could have done more with constrained functionality and/or operational capability – i.e. more product demos throughout development process even if not using in human.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Looking toward my IBD project, I anticipate using positive deviance, as the markets in which we are working are emerging and likely have resource constraints.  Additionally, in order to get buy in from people in a culture I might not understand, positive deviance will be useful.  I also look forward to using A/B testing to test falsifiable hypotheses.  I anticipate needing to do significant market research to understand the international market in which we are working and A/B testing will prove invaluable in truly ensuring our approach meets the needs of our end users.  To that end, I’d love to hear ideas on how to run A/B testing on hypotheses while working from abroad?  Will we be able to follow lean start-up practices despite not working full time in our target market?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Mike Solarz

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Mike Solarz

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 11:20am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  I wonder what roadblocks prevented your previous company from focusing more on the end-user and why it didn't iterate more.  I wonder if as these approaches continue to gain more visibility in the corporate world, if this will become more prevalent amongst companies that have adopted a more traditional methodology in conducting business.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Go To Parent
