                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  I wonder what roadblocks prevented your previous company from focusing more on the end-user and why it didn't iterate more.  I wonder if as these approaches continue to gain more visibility in the corporate world, if this will become more prevalent amongst companies that have adopted a more traditional methodology in conducting business.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Taylor Jordan

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Taylor Jordan

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 11:33am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I think the challenge is multifaceted.  1. highly regulated industry makes MVPs harder to "roll out" to customers. 2. by the time the company did seek input, they were too far along in the design and development process and had invested too many resources.  3. it is hard to get physicians to give you time on a super early stage resource.    I am interested to see if I can find ways to balance these 3 competing notions that tend to make it difficult to follow some of the practices outlined by the articles. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I think the challenge is multifaceted.  1. highly regulated industry makes MVPs harder to "roll out" to customers. 2. by the time the company did seek input, they were too far along in the design and development process and had invested too many resources.  3. it is hard to get physicians to give you time on a super early stage resource. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I am interested to see if I can find ways to balance these 3 competing notions that tend to make it difficult to follow some of the practices outlined by the articles. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Justin Wedell

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Justin Wedell

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 1:50pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Design thinking, positive deviance, and lean start-up methodology all reflect efforts to more effectively manage and succeed amidst increasing complexity. I believe that all require a mindset that is open in its approach to problem-solving and humble enough to be able to grow and adapt to new hypotheses that may conflict with original theories and blueprints. When I worked in education reform, the idea of “positive deviance” played a large role in identifying teachers and educational practices that were thriving in spite of their circumstances. These best practices were then studied, codified, and replicated so that other educators could similarly engage in more productive pedagogy. The implementation of such ideas was consequently channeled through a process similar to that of the “lean start-up” methodology. Understanding that each region and school presented different and variable challenges, educators and administrators had to be comfortable developing, implementing, and iterating new ideas in an agile fashion in order to identify the best possible framework for their students. Oftentimes, “design thinking” principles were employed to ensure that those leading the charge in bringing such new solutions to schools were able to do so with a high level of empathy and end-user focus. When I consider how these mindsets might be employed within IBD, I see numerous opportunities for them to combine toward emergent value in our projects. The program, by its very nature, places us in a foreign context - in terms of both country and stakeholder - that requires an open mind and a flexible approach in order to drive toward successful outcomes. The biggest challenge I envision is that of cross-cultural engagement and the communication hurdles that unique facets of all parties’ cultures may present. Will mindsets and best practices that may be distinctly western resonate with our stakeholders abroad? Will we be skilled enough in their use to be flexible in how they are applied? How will we hold ourselves accountable to executing on these principles instead of reverting to the crutch of the best practices that have served us so well in our professional lives to this point? It will by no means be a simple endeavor, but that’s why we’re here. For the challenge. For the service. For the improvement. I can’t wait to get started.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Design thinking, positive deviance, and lean start-up methodology all reflect efforts to more effectively manage and succeed amidst increasing complexity. I believe that all require a mindset that is open in its approach to problem-solving and humble enough to be able to grow and adapt to new hypotheses that may conflict with original theories and blueprints.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      When I worked in education reform, the idea of “positive deviance” played a large role in identifying teachers and educational practices that were thriving in spite of their circumstances. These best practices were then studied, codified, and replicated so that other educators could similarly engage in more productive pedagogy. The implementation of such ideas was consequently channeled through a process similar to that of the “lean start-up” methodology. Understanding that each region and school presented different and variable challenges, educators and administrators had to be comfortable developing, implementing, and iterating new ideas in an agile fashion in order to identify the best possible framework for their students. Oftentimes, “design thinking” principles were employed to ensure that those leading the charge in bringing such new solutions to schools were able to do so with a high level of empathy and end-user focus.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      When I consider how these mindsets might be employed within IBD, I see numerous opportunities for them to combine toward emergent value in our projects. The program, by its very nature, places us in a foreign context - in terms of both country and stakeholder - that requires an open mind and a flexible approach in order to drive toward successful outcomes. The biggest challenge I envision is that of cross-cultural engagement and the communication hurdles that unique facets of all parties’ cultures may present. Will mindsets and best practices that may be distinctly western resonate with our stakeholders abroad? Will we be skilled enough in their use to be flexible in how they are applied? How will we hold ourselves accountable to executing on these principles instead of reverting to the crutch of the best practices that have served us so well in our professional lives to this point?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      It will by no means be a simple endeavor, but that’s why we’re here. For the challenge. For the service. For the improvement. I can’t wait to get started.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Annie Kimberley

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 4:03pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Justin, I love your acknowledgement of the hurdles we may face such as communication and cross-cultural engagement.  The concept of "positive deviance" seems to be one where we can have the longest-lasting impact since we're there for such a short time and will not get to see anything truly through implementation.  However, it also seems like it will be the hardest to find in such a short time- especially when we're coming in with little cultural context.  From your experience, is there anything we can do to jumpstart that learning when we start our projects?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Justin, I love your acknowledgement of the hurdles we may face such as communication and cross-cultural engagement.  The concept of "positive deviance" seems to be one where we can have the longest-lasting impact since we're there for such a short time and will not get to see anything truly through implementation.  However, it also seems like it will be the hardest to find in such a short time- especially when we're coming in with little cultural context.  From your experience, is there anything we can do to jumpstart that learning when we start our projects?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Thanks for the insight Justin!! How were you, or your company, able to identify these "positive defiance" situations? Were you actively looking? Were there certain metrics that popped off the page that made it obvious? How were these changes then tracked moving forward?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              How were you, or your company, able to identify these "positive defiance" situations?                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Justin Wedell

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Justin Wedell

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 21, 2017 Feb 21 at 9:43pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Thanks, James! Positive deviants were identified based upon student performance. Our organization would analyze data on student progress within each teacher's classroom every month. Teachers whose data demonstrated above average growth subsequently had personnel visit their classrooms to study their methodology, record their strategies, and evaluate what made their classrooms unique. The eventual implementation of these strategies in the classrooms of other educators was likewise evaluated for success based upon student performance data.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Thanks, James! Positive deviants were identified based upon student performance. Our organization would analyze data on student progress within each teacher's classroom every month. Teachers whose data demonstrated above average growth subsequently had personnel visit their classrooms to study their methodology, record their strategies, and evaluate what made their classrooms unique. The eventual implementation of these strategies in the classrooms of other educators was likewise evaluated for success based upon student performance data.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Jefferson Neblett

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Jefferson Neblett

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 3:20pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  I believe the most prominent mindset/skill required in the three methods is the ability to approach problems or ideas in a manner similar to the way a scientist approaches an experiment. The ability to form a hypothesis and analyze is it is important in all three, even though it is not as evident in positive deviance. The article on positive deviance mentions identifying, interviewing and observing people to help explain a good outcome. Despite not mentioning the need to hypothesize, it appears as though that is exactly what one is doing in trying to explore why a good outcome came about. Scientific method seems tantamount in all the approaches to ensuring good outcomes. While I have not engaged on specific hypothesis testing in my previous work, I have approached problems in a scientific and/or customer-centric manner. Mostly, I thought about and analyzed the deeper questions like why have we been doing this process in this manner? Is this really necessary anymore? What kind of data are investors looking for that we do not currently provide them with?  Design Thinking could be a very important approach when it comes to my IBD: Wildcard Applied Innovation course. Specifically, I believe the idea of creating models to examine complex problems will come in useful as my team embarks on our project. Companies have come to the IBD program seeking MBAs to solve complex problems, and nearly all of the projects I have read about could benefit from many aspects of the Design Thinking approach. The drawbacks of Design Thinking is the fact that a company must accept more ambiguity, and I could see that making it tough to implement the process during our engagement. The lean start-up approach seems like it will offer many valuable lessons as my team dives into our consulting project. The idea of hypothesis-driven testing will be useful, although we may not be able to follow through with MVP tests in such a short time period. Questions about the approaches: What is the best way to design a hypothesis in the lean startup method? With limited time on our IBD projects, how can we best prioritize certain MVP testing? How can we carry this out if we cannot release actual product iterations? Discovering uncommon positive examples in the positive deviance approach seems to be the biggest disadvantage of the approach. Is there a framework to best do so?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  I believe the most prominent mindset/skill required in the three methods is the ability to approach problems or ideas in a manner similar to the way a scientist approaches an experiment. The ability to form a hypothesis and analyze is it is important in all three, even though it is not as evident in positive deviance. The article on positive deviance mentions identifying, interviewing and observing people to help explain a good outcome. Despite not mentioning the need to hypothesize, it appears as though that is exactly what one is doing in trying to explore why a good outcome came about. Scientific method seems tantamount in all the approaches to ensuring good outcomes. While I have not engaged on specific hypothesis testing in my previous work, I have approached problems in a scientific and/or customer-centric manner. Mostly, I thought about and analyzed the deeper questions like why have we been doing this process in this manner? Is this really necessary anymore? What kind of data are investors looking for that we do not currently provide them with? 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Design Thinking could be a very important approach when it comes to my IBD: Wildcard Applied Innovation course. Specifically, I believe the idea of creating models to examine complex problems will come in useful as my team embarks on our project. Companies have come to the IBD program seeking MBAs to solve complex problems, and nearly all of the projects I have read about could benefit from many aspects of the Design Thinking approach. The drawbacks of Design Thinking is the fact that a company must accept more ambiguity, and I could see that making it tough to implement the process during our engagement. The lean start-up approach seems like it will offer many valuable lessons as my team dives into our consulting project. The idea of hypothesis-driven testing will be useful, although we may not be able to follow through with MVP tests in such a short time period.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Questions about the approaches:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • What is the best way to design a hypothesis in the lean startup method?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • With limited time on our IBD projects, how can we best prioritize certain MVP testing? How can we carry this out if we cannot release actual product iterations?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Discovering uncommon positive examples in the positive deviance approach seems to be the biggest disadvantage of the approach. Is there a framework to best do so?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Mitchell Plueger

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Mitchell Plueger

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 18, 2017 Feb 18 at 9:49am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      In answer to your first question, you could possibly use the design thinking methods we learned in our PFPS live session to develop your initial hypothesis. I think throughout the lean startup method there are opportunities to incorporate design thinking at various stages. (It's all new to me though!)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Parent

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      In answer to your first question, you could possibly use the design thinking methods we learned in our PFPS live session to develop your initial hypothesis. I think throughout the lean startup method there are opportunities to incorporate design thinking at various stages. (It's all new to me though!)

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Gloria Gerngross

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Gloria Gerngross

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 3:50pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Design thinking, positive deviance and lean start-up all are methods to solve a problem while using different approaches. The user of every approach needs an open mindset and understand the problem and the desired outcome first before diving into the problem solving process. I worked as a financial auditor for Ernst & Young (EY) and can see that the audit practice at EY is not a very innovation driven practice. I think the problem at EY is that the focus is too much on getting results fast versus understanding the problem first which takes time at the beginning. Another challenge is that for innovation organizations need to be open to failure. However, as an audit practice EY can’t allow any failures or mistakes as this would impact its clients and its client’s shareholders. Instead, EY is relying on old and proven systems without room for innovation. I can’t pick one approach that is going to be the most important for my IBD project. I think the best approach depends on the problem we are working on.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Design thinking, positive deviance and lean start-up all are methods to solve a problem while using different approaches. The user of every approach needs an open mindset and understand the problem and the desired outcome first before diving into the problem solving process.


                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        I worked as a financial auditor for Ernst & Young (EY) and can see that the audit practice at EY is not a very innovation driven practice. I think the problem at EY is that the focus is too much on getting results fast versus understanding the problem first which takes time at the beginning. Another challenge is that for innovation organizations need to be open to failure. However, as an audit practice EY can’t allow any failures or mistakes as this would impact its clients and its client’s shareholders. Instead, EY is relying on old and proven systems without room for innovation.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        I can’t pick one approach that is going to be the most important for my IBD project. I think the best approach depends on the problem we are working on.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion James Parnham

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            James Parnham

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 4:03pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Interesting insights Gloria! I wonder when we are done with the course, will you be able to identify ways that you could have retroactively helped EY identify areas for innovation? Did you ever try to drive change in the organization, and if so, how did that effort go?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Anna Braszkiewicz

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Anna Braszkiewicz

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 5:32pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                I can really relate with your experiences at EY. Prior to Haas, I worked at a drug development firm focused on early stage pharmaceuticals and even though we were trying to come up with new/innovative therapies, the process itself was not innovative at all. I attribute that to strict FDA regulations that truly limited what can or cannot be done. I would be really interested in learning about biotech/pharma companies that are using design thinking/lean start-up approaches in their day to day operations.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                I can really relate with your experiences at EY. Prior to Haas, I worked at a drug development firm focused on early stage pharmaceuticals and even though we were trying to come up with new/innovative therapies, the process itself was not innovative at all. I attribute that to strict FDA regulations that truly limited what can or cannot be done. I would be really interested in learning about biotech/pharma companies that are using design thinking/lean start-up approaches in their day to day operations.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Collapse Subdiscussion Kim LONG

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Kim LONG

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Mar 8, 2017 Mar 8 at 12:28pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Thanks Gloria. Similarly, it was tough for me to apply these frameworks in my previous work experience. Prior to Haas, I was in investment banking, and there was no such thing as design thinking or lean approaches. On the contrary, it was mostly creating a lot of waste - one manager would decide on his own what the direction for a project should be, creating a lot of work for the juniors and we would go through dozens of iterations of a pitch deck before getting to a final client presentation. This created a lot of extra work that was actually not needed. I don't think that for the banking industry is going to change this approach anytime soon but looking forwarding to applying these frameworks in our IBD project and startup project.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Thanks Gloria. Similarly, it was tough for me to apply these frameworks in my previous work experience. Prior to Haas, I was in investment banking, and there was no such thing as design thinking or lean approaches. On the contrary, it was mostly creating a lot of waste - one manager would decide on his own what the direction for a project should be, creating a lot of work for the juniors and we would go through dozens of iterations of a pitch deck before getting to a final client presentation. This created a lot of extra work that was actually not needed. I don't think that for the banking industry is going to change this approach anytime soon but looking forwarding to applying these frameworks in our IBD project and startup project.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Annie Kimberley

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Annie Kimberley

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 3:54pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The three frameworks covered in this week’s readings all revolved around finding creative ways to solve a problem by creating a vision and iterating along the way to evolve as needed.  I worked at Target before coming to Haas and my closest experience to seeing a transition to a more design-thinking approach at work was through the technology team’s reorganization.  The technology team went through a huge transition from waterfall project management to what they called an ‘agile’ project process, which is most similar to the lean startup method approach covered in the readings.  They restructured the 1,000+ technology team members from covering specific product development phases to supporting specific areas of the company and managing their technology systems and projects from start to finish.  This approach embraced the lean startup mindset because it allowed the technology team members to be more integrated with their end consumers and better understand the problems they faced.  Shortly after the restructure, I got to work with a technology lead assigned to support ‘omnichannel merchandising’ to build a report that would allow merchants to analyze their sales and profitability across both the stores and dot com channels so they could optimize the cross-channel selling experience of their assortment.  There were hundreds of metrics we wanted to include in the report sourced from an unknown number of databases and instead of spending a year building a comprehensive report we assumed people would use, we started testing it after only a few weeks on pilot users to make sure we were providing them with the information they needed in the format they needed.  It was amazing to see the lean startup method in action in a huge corporate environment.  However, it was challenging to get people onboard because it was not how they were used to working.  At Target, you had always had to provide quantitative results to sell leadership on projects and this method did not lend itself to that approach.  Because we were trying to roll out the report so quickly and were still iterating and improving it, we did not have sales or profit improvement results we could tie to the use of the report so it was harder to sell as a worthy investment in training and time for teams.  I would love to hear about examples from you about how you’ve used positive deviance in the workplace.  I find it easy to visualize it in the context of social impact projects abroad but not in a corporate workplace as much!
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Topic

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              The three frameworks covered in this week’s readings all revolved around finding creative ways to solve a problem by creating a vision and iterating along the way to evolve as needed.  I worked at Target before coming to Haas and my closest experience to seeing a transition to a more design-thinking approach at work was through the technology team’s reorganization.  The technology team went through a huge transition from waterfall project management to what they called an ‘agile’ project process, which is most similar to the lean startup method approach covered in the readings.  They restructured the 1,000+ technology team members from covering specific product development phases to supporting specific areas of the company and managing their technology systems and projects from start to finish.  This approach embraced the lean startup mindset because it allowed the technology team members to be more integrated with their end consumers and better understand the problems they faced.  Shortly after the restructure, I got to work with a technology lead assigned to support ‘omnichannel merchandising’ to build a report that would allow merchants to analyze their sales and profitability across both the stores and dot com channels so they could optimize the cross-channel selling experience of their assortment.  There were hundreds of metrics we wanted to include in the report sourced from an unknown number of databases and instead of spending a year building a comprehensive report we assumed people would use, we started testing it after only a few weeks on pilot users to make sure we were providing them with the information they needed in the format they needed.  It was amazing to see the lean startup method in action in a huge corporate environment.  However, it was challenging to get people onboard because it was not how they were used to working.  At Target, you had always had to provide quantitative results to sell leadership on projects and this method did not lend itself to that approach.  Because we were trying to roll out the report so quickly and were still iterating and improving it, we did not have sales or profit improvement results we could tie to the use of the report so it was harder to sell as a worthy investment in training and time for teams. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              I would love to hear about examples from you about how you’ve used positive deviance in the workplace.  I find it easy to visualize it in the context of social impact projects abroad but not in a corporate workplace as much!
