                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Megha Kansra

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Megha Kansra

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 5:44pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Such an interesting example! Thank you for sharing. I had a similar experience of implementing design thinking at an organization that was used to more traditional, rigorous research / policy analysis modes of problem solving. There were a lot of growing pains involved and plenty of resistance to design thinking, as well as skepticism that it wouldn't have the rigorous evidence backing that my team was used to leveraging in problem solving. I wonder how we might make the lean start-up method easier to adopt culturally. Do you think involving more employees in its adaptation and implementation would help? Did it seem "top-down"? Could Target have done a better job of showing how the method was beneficial for all employees?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Such an interesting example! Thank you for sharing. I had a similar experience of implementing design thinking at an organization that was used to more traditional, rigorous research / policy analysis modes of problem solving. There were a lot of growing pains involved and plenty of resistance to design thinking, as well as skepticism that it wouldn't have the rigorous evidence backing that my team was used to leveraging in problem solving.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  I wonder how we might make the lean start-up method easier to adopt culturally. Do you think involving more employees in its adaptation and implementation would help? Did it seem "top-down"? Could Target have done a better job of showing how the method was beneficial for all employees?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion James Parnham

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      James Parnham

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 4:01pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I think the primary similarity between “design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up” is the idea that identifying problems (mostly through testing/prototyping) is extremely important before you can design a solution around it. So in design thinking, you are putting yourself in the customers shoes and determining what the problem is, and then forming a hypothesis and prototyping to determine a solution. The same is true for lean start-ups; you are coming up with hypothesis' to determine a problem and testing your hypothesis to determine it's viability. You continue to do this until you have found the real problem and identified a real solution or solutions. Positive deviance is similar, except the problem is typically more clearly defined. But in order to determine the solution, it's important to come up with a hypothesis to test in order to see which behaviors already being exhibited can lead to a true change. In all instances (“design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up”), testing and reiterating is extremely important, and a high tolerance/acceptance for failure is invaluable. However, each are fundamentally different. Positive deviance comes through in large scale problems where a behavior can significantly change an outcome. Lean start-up can be applied to any company or any problem, but requires significant resources and time. Design thinking provides a lot of flexibility and is more a general mindset than a specific action plan like the other two.  I think both "lean start-up" and "design thinking" will be most important in IBD. Identifying our clients problem and then determining solutions based on prototyping and hypothesis generation will be extremely valuable and relatively easy to implement with some data collection and serious thought. I do have some questions on the topic. How can these ideas be implemented in more abstract environments? What happens when your client doesn't really know their problem? In what ways can we use these techniques in our every day lives in order to improve our circumstances?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I think the primary similarity between “design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up” is the idea that identifying problems (mostly through testing/prototyping) is extremely important before you can design a solution around it. So in design thinking, you are putting yourself in the customers shoes and determining what the problem is, and then forming a hypothesis and prototyping to determine a solution. The same is true for lean start-ups; you are coming up with hypothesis' to determine a problem and testing your hypothesis to determine it's viability. You continue to do this until you have found the real problem and identified a real solution or solutions. Positive deviance is similar, except the problem is typically more clearly defined. But in order to determine the solution, it's important to come up with a hypothesis to test in order to see which behaviors already being exhibited can lead to a true change. In all instances (“design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up”), testing and reiterating is extremely important, and a high tolerance/acceptance for failure is invaluable. However, each are fundamentally different. Positive deviance comes through in large scale problems where a behavior can significantly change an outcome. Lean start-up can be applied to any company or any problem, but requires significant resources and time. Design thinking provides a lot of flexibility and is more a general mindset than a specific action plan like the other two. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I think both "lean start-up" and "design thinking" will be most important in IBD. Identifying our clients problem and then determining solutions based on prototyping and hypothesis generation will be extremely valuable and relatively easy to implement with some data collection and serious thought.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I do have some questions on the topic. How can these ideas be implemented in more abstract environments? What happens when your client doesn't really know their problem? In what ways can we use these techniques in our every day lives in order to improve our circumstances?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Mitchell Plueger

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Feb 18, 2017 Feb 18 at 9:41am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          I agree that Design Thinking and Lean Startup are probably more applicable to IBD than positive deviance. My major concern was also around how to deal with client's that don't understand their own problem. Some of the IBD projects seem incredibly vague and hopefully, we will have the opportunity to apply these methodologies alongside clients in order to quickly get to a hypothesis for a narrower scope.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          I agree that Design Thinking and Lean Startup are probably more applicable to IBD than positive deviance. My major concern was also around how to deal with client's that don't understand their own problem. Some of the IBD projects seem incredibly vague and hopefully, we will have the opportunity to apply these methodologies alongside clients in order to quickly get to a hypothesis for a narrower scope.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Tyler Owens

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Tyler Owens

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 5:08pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  It seems like there could be tension between the core tenants of design thinking, namely acceptance of failure and empathy with users, and the values of a particular company, and thus that the ability to apply design thinking techniques at a particular company would be highly dependent on that company's culture. I'll be curious to learn how these challenges are dealt with in practice (i.e., is a cultural shift necessary to accommodate the openness required to successfully employ design thinking techniques or can these techniques be employed within a cultural bubble that exists within a company that is contrary to broader company cultural norms?).
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  It seems like there could be tension between the core tenants of design thinking, namely acceptance of failure and empathy with users, and the values of a particular company, and thus that the ability to apply design thinking techniques at a particular company would be highly dependent on that company's culture. I'll be curious to learn how these challenges are dealt with in practice (i.e., is a cultural shift necessary to accommodate the openness required to successfully employ design thinking techniques or can these techniques be employed within a cultural bubble that exists within a company that is contrary to broader company cultural norms?).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Emily Gordon

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Emily Gordon

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 20, 2017 Feb 20 at 8:03pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I agree Tyler. It seems like more and more companies are trying to emphasize this type of design and saying that they're comfortable with failures, but if employees don't truly feel safe to make mistakes then these techniques won't work.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Parent

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I agree Tyler. It seems like more and more companies are trying to emphasize this type of design and saying that they're comfortable with failures, but if employees don't truly feel safe to make mistakes then these techniques won't work.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Collapse Subdiscussion Carol Macavilca Paredes

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Carol Macavilca Paredes

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 5:09pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        All three of them use frameworks to solve problems and require preparation, do research and planning before their use. All frameworks intend to be innovative and change the way in organizations are solving their problems.  However, each framework has to be applied  in different stages, environments and require different abilities to be implemented. I saw different types of companies that were trying to use these frameworks; they spent a lot of money in training and hiring consultants to implement them. However, the lack of support of its leaders made the project fail. The most successes cases were in small companies where everybody was involved.  According to your personal skills, which framework do you think you would implement successfully? Why?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        All three of them use frameworks to solve problems and require preparation, do research and planning before their use. All frameworks intend to be innovative and change the way in organizations are solving their problems.  However, each framework has to be applied  in different stages, environments and require different abilities to be implemented. I saw different types of companies that were trying to use these frameworks; they spent a lot of money in training and hiring consultants to implement them. However, the lack of support of its leaders made the project fail. The most successes cases were in small companies where everybody was involved.  According to your personal skills, which framework do you think you would implement successfully? Why?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Collapse Subdiscussion Anna Braszkiewicz

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Anna Braszkiewicz

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 5:20pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            The common thread that all strategies share is the focus on innovation, involvement of potential users and other customers in the development process and the focus on solving complex problems and coming up with creative/unique solutions. Similarly, all of the methods require open-mind, creativity, and ability to think outside of the box. On the other hand, first difference that came to my mind among “design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up” is the amount of ambiguity “attached” to each of the methods listed above. In my opinion, the most straightforward one is the “positive deviance”. As difficult as it may be to first identify the “role model” that would successfully tackle the problem we are trying to solve, once the solution is properly identified, we have a clear and low-cost path to implementing the desirable solution. In contrast, “design thinking” and “lean start-up” seem a lot more ambiguous, risky, and complex, and may require a lot more iterations/pivots in order to finally develop a viable solution. My guess is that for the International Business Development class that we will be taking later this spring, utilizing both the “lean-start up” and “design thinking” approaches will be most valuable. I would say it makes most sense to use design thinking approach early in the process to really understand the true cause/root problem and once that problem is identified we could use the “lean startup” to test our hypothesis and figure out if our solution/product would be something that our customers would be willing to buy. To be completely honest, I do not feel that I have much experience with neither of these methods. Which makes me particularly excited to participate in this course and the on-line discussions with my classmates. My question for the classmates is pretty broad: how have you used these methods in your professional work experience, are you using them now while in the business school, and what tips do you have for those of us for whom this is a completely new and confusing concept.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            The common thread that all strategies share is the focus on innovation, involvement of potential users and other customers in the development process and the focus on solving complex problems and coming up with creative/unique solutions. Similarly, all of the methods require open-mind, creativity, and ability to think outside of the box.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            On the other hand, first difference that came to my mind among “design thinking”, "positive deviance" and “lean start-up” is the amount of ambiguity “attached” to each of the methods listed above. In my opinion, the most straightforward one is the “positive deviance”. As difficult as it may be to first identify the “role model” that would successfully tackle the problem we are trying to solve, once the solution is properly identified, we have a clear and low-cost path to implementing the desirable solution. In contrast, “design thinking” and “lean start-up” seem a lot more ambiguous, risky, and complex, and may require a lot more iterations/pivots in order to finally develop a viable solution.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            My guess is that for the International Business Development class that we will be taking later this spring, utilizing both the “lean-start up” and “design thinking” approaches will be most valuable. I would say it makes most sense to use design thinking approach early in the process to really understand the true cause/root problem and once that problem is identified we could use the “lean startup” to test our hypothesis and figure out if our solution/product would be something that our customers would be willing to buy.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            To be completely honest, I do not feel that I have much experience with neither of these methods. Which makes me particularly excited to participate in this course and the on-line discussions with my classmates.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            My question for the classmates is pretty broad: how have you used these methods in your professional work experience, are you using them now while in the business school, and what tips do you have for those of us for whom this is a completely new and confusing concept.
