                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Megha Kansra

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Megha Kansra

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 5:40pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Many of your points resonate with me. I do think, however, that for IBD, positive deviance could be very useful. Given our time constraints, positive deviance could be one way to quickly unearth things that are already working and focus instead on how we might scale them up / increase adoption. Also, given the cost constraints of operating in developing countries, positive deviance may be a more cost-effective way to solve problems than either design thinking or the lean start-up method. And finally, positive deviance may gain more buy-in from the community or customer base right away, given its close collaboration with the community. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Many of your points resonate with me. I do think, however, that for IBD, positive deviance could be very useful. Given our time constraints, positive deviance could be one way to quickly unearth things that are already working and focus instead on how we might scale them up / increase adoption. Also, given the cost constraints of operating in developing countries, positive deviance may be a more cost-effective way to solve problems than either design thinking or the lean start-up method. And finally, positive deviance may gain more buy-in from the community or customer base right away, given its close collaboration with the community. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Collapse Subdiscussion Megha Kansra

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Megha Kansra

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Feb 16, 2017 Feb 16 at 5:32pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  A key similarity between design thinking and lean start-up is the mindset required to implement both methodologies. Implementers must be 1) Open to new learning and possibilities, avoiding bias, 2) Comfortable with ambiguity and change given the frequent iterations built into both processes, and 3) Customer or end user focused. For instance, in the lean start-up method, it is critical to keep the focus on responding to customer feedback and adoption of the MVP when making persevere / pivot / perish decisions. Similarly, in design thinking, the process starts with gaining empathy for the end user, understanding their motivations and behaviors more deeply, and then using those insights to drive ideation.  Design thinking and positive deviance both have in common a focus on deep and close study of the community. Positive deviance entails scoping out the rare 1-10% who may have a positive behavior, and then working closely with the community to increase adoption of this behavior. Similarly, design thinking involves closely observing and even "walking in the shoes" of the end user to develop a deeper understanding of behavior.  While each method is aimed at problem solving, they have important differences. The lean start-up method is aimed at solving a problem of product-market fit, typically with a core product category in mind. On the other hand, design thinking keeps the user's needs at the center of its focus; the goal is to better understand these needs and then design a product / service solution that may address the need. Finally, positive deviance does not engage in a ground-up problem solving process at all. Rather, this method is about scanning the landscape for already existing solutions to the problem. In a sense, positive deviance is less about solving the problem itself than about scaling up under-utilized solutions to the problem.  I believe each of the three approaches could be useful in IBD, depending on what type of problem we are trying to solve, the resources available for us (e.g., MVP may be more useful if we are trying to develop a solution on limited resources), and how much is known about potential solutions already (e.g., design thinking may be more useful if divergent or fresh thinking is needed to unearth new ideas). Having engaged in design thinking at my prior workplace, I found it difficult to apply design thinking to many complex social problems (e.g., youth unemployment among low income populations). I would love to discuss the drawbacks of each method and how we might supplement each method / deal with the potential drawbacks.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  A key similarity between design thinking and lean start-up is the mindset required to implement both methodologies. Implementers must be 1) Open to new learning and possibilities, avoiding bias, 2) Comfortable with ambiguity and change given the frequent iterations built into both processes, and 3) Customer or end user focused. For instance, in the lean start-up method, it is critical to keep the focus on responding to customer feedback and adoption of the MVP when making persevere / pivot / perish decisions. Similarly, in design thinking, the process starts with gaining empathy for the end user, understanding their motivations and behaviors more deeply, and then using those insights to drive ideation. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Design thinking and positive deviance both have in common a focus on deep and close study of the community. Positive deviance entails scoping out the rare 1-10% who may have a positive behavior, and then working closely with the community to increase adoption of this behavior. Similarly, design thinking involves closely observing and even "walking in the shoes" of the end user to develop a deeper understanding of behavior. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  While each method is aimed at problem solving, they have important differences. The lean start-up method is aimed at solving a problem of product-market fit, typically with a core product category in mind. On the other hand, design thinking keeps the user's needs at the center of its focus; the goal is to better understand these needs and then design a product / service solution that may address the need. Finally, positive deviance does not engage in a ground-up problem solving process at all. Rather, this method is about scanning the landscape for already existing solutions to the problem. In a sense, positive deviance is less about solving the problem itself than about scaling up under-utilized solutions to the problem. 

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  I believe each of the three approaches could be useful in IBD, depending on what type of problem we are trying to solve, the resources available for us (e.g., MVP may be more useful if we are trying to develop a solution on limited resources), and how much is known about potential solutions already (e.g., design thinking may be more useful if divergent or fresh thinking is needed to unearth new ideas).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Having engaged in design thinking at my prior workplace, I found it difficult to apply design thinking to many complex social problems (e.g., youth unemployment among low income populations). I would love to discuss the drawbacks of each method and how we might supplement each method / deal with the potential drawbacks.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Edited by Megha Kansra on Feb 16 at 5:35pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Collapse Subdiscussion Mitchell Plueger

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Mitchell Plueger

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Feb 18, 2017 Feb 18 at 9:32am
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      These three approaches are much more similar than different. First of all, they all focus on the users or in the case of positive deviation, on the population being served. Additionally, they all follow the general cycle of observation, hypothesis, test, and analyze. To me, Design thinking seemed to be the most universally applicable to a variety of situations with Lean Startup a more tactical roadmap for running a startup. In many stages of Lean Startup like “developing a vision or hypothesis” or “specifying MVP tests” there are clear opportunities to use Design Thinking within those processes. I did notice a major difference between the two, however. Design Thinking focused much more so on customer experience and qualitative understanding of the customer journey or needs, whereas Lean Startup prioritizes data driven hypothesis to test. Positive Deviance seemed the most narrowly applicable of the three, as all of the examples were focused on healthcare and nutritional practices in a population. I am not really sure how you could use Positive Deviance to develop, a new social networking app, for example, but I do think it could be a useful tool in many projects that are otherwise dominated by Design Thinking or Lean Startup. In my previous career as an officer in the Navy and specifically navigating a ship and running a nuclear reactor, these skills were not very applicable. We didn’t really have users or a product we were selling unless you think about “Security” as a service in a very macro sense. Also, when running a nuclear reactor there is very little tolerance for failure. I pretty much had to do everything correct and changes to procedures were painstakingly researched and debated because failure could be very dangerous. However, when confronted with novel critical equipment failures, I generally followed a system which is most similar to the Lean Startup method. For example, when a complex system failed for an unknown reason, my team would brainstorm several potential causes, attempt to rank them by likelihood or ease/cost of testing/replacing and begin replacing the most likely or least costly component. This was much faster than failing to do anything until the cause was identified 100%. We followed this method because often the failure prevented the nuclear reactor from operating and in rare cases that meant 6000 people floating, without power, on a $10B ship until we fixed it.  This had its drawbacks, however, as we often spent millions of dollars on unneeded repair parts, and frequently started up equipment that may or may not have been fixed, only to have to once again abort dangerous operations.  In general I think design thinking and lean startup is applicable for this type of environment when problems arise that are outside of established procedures and probably applicable when designing and building new ships, nuclear reactors, etc. (something I never did). I’m not exactly sure which methods will be most beneficial for IBD as I don’t have my project assignment yet. In general, I think Design Thinking will be very applicable to most, and Lean Startup to startup projects and those with user-focused products. Positive Deviance might be more applicable to social sector projects or those dealing with population-level change. My first question is if there are applications for positive deviance outside of healthcare and nutrition? I’m also curious to know how one would apply these to commodity industries, and manufacturing or operations environments? Also, how could governments use these approaches to develop smarter policies?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      These three approaches are much more similar than different. First of all, they all focus on the users or in the case of positive deviation, on the population being served. Additionally, they all follow the general cycle of observation, hypothesis, test, and analyze. To me, Design thinking seemed to be the most universally applicable to a variety of situations with Lean Startup a more tactical roadmap for running a startup. In many stages of Lean Startup like “developing a vision or hypothesis” or “specifying MVP tests” there are clear opportunities to use Design Thinking within those processes. I did notice a major difference between the two, however. Design Thinking focused much more so on customer experience and qualitative understanding of the customer journey or needs, whereas Lean Startup prioritizes data driven hypothesis to test. Positive Deviance seemed the most narrowly applicable of the three, as all of the examples were focused on healthcare and nutritional practices in a population. I am not really sure how you could use Positive Deviance to develop, a new social networking app, for example, but I do think it could be a useful tool in many projects that are otherwise dominated by Design Thinking or Lean Startup.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      In my previous career as an officer in the Navy and specifically navigating a ship and running a nuclear reactor, these skills were not very applicable. We didn’t really have users or a product we were selling unless you think about “Security” as a service in a very macro sense. Also, when running a nuclear reactor there is very little tolerance for failure. I pretty much had to do everything correct and changes to procedures were painstakingly researched and debated because failure could be very dangerous. However, when confronted with novel critical equipment failures, I generally followed a system which is most similar to the Lean Startup method. For example, when a complex system failed for an unknown reason, my team would brainstorm several potential causes, attempt to rank them by likelihood or ease/cost of testing/replacing and begin replacing the most likely or least costly component. This was much faster than failing to do anything until the cause was identified 100%. We followed this method because often the failure prevented the nuclear reactor from operating and in rare cases that meant 6000 people floating, without power, on a $10B ship until we fixed it.  This had its drawbacks, however, as we often spent millions of dollars on unneeded repair parts, and frequently started up equipment that may or may not have been fixed, only to have to once again abort dangerous operations.  In general I think design thinking and lean startup is applicable for this type of environment when problems arise that are outside of established procedures and probably applicable when designing and building new ships, nuclear reactors, etc. (something I never did).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      I’m not exactly sure which methods will be most beneficial for IBD as I don’t have my project assignment yet. In general, I think Design Thinking will be very applicable to most, and Lean Startup to startup projects and those with user-focused products. Positive Deviance might be more applicable to social sector projects or those dealing with population-level change.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      My first question is if there are applications for positive deviance outside of healthcare and nutrition? I’m also curious to know how one would apply these to commodity industries, and manufacturing or operations environments? Also, how could governments use these approaches to develop smarter policies?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        • Collapse Subdiscussion Laura Smith

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Laura Smith

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Feb 19, 2017 Feb 19 at 5:12pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Hey Mitch - thanks for sharing....the military setting is definitely a completely different ballgame to apply these approaches. To your question, the way that I thought about positive deviance outside of the scope of the article (which may be totally wrong), is the idea of taking the best practices of your competitors or similar teams within your company that are working well or making them succeed and apply those to your own team or day-to-day...Kind of a loose interpretation though. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Go To Parent

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          Hey Mitch - thanks for sharing....the military setting is definitely a completely different ballgame to apply these approaches. To your question, the way that I thought about positive deviance outside of the scope of the article (which may be totally wrong), is the idea of taking the best practices of your competitors or similar teams within your company that are working well or making them succeed and apply those to your own team or day-to-day...Kind of a loose interpretation though.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            • Collapse Subdiscussion Javier Gunther

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Javier Gunther

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Feb 27, 2017 Feb 27 at 5:29pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Thanks for sharing your experience, Mitch. I think that your first comment is very appropriate and I was thinking the same thing. We should not be thinking of these three approaches as one or the other. It could perfectly be a mixture of those depending on the specific problem we are facing, and using lean startup as the main framework, with specific design thinking for more qualitative research and deep understanding sounds great.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Go To Parent
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Thanks for sharing your experience, Mitch. I think that your first comment is very appropriate and I was thinking the same thing. We should not be thinking of these three approaches as one or the other. It could perfectly be a mixture of those depending on the specific problem we are facing, and using lean startup as the main framework, with specific design thinking for more qualitative research and deep understanding sounds great.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Reply Reply to Comment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              HTML Editor Rich Content Editor
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Cancel
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              • Collapse Subdiscussion Laura Smith

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Laura Smith

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Feb 19, 2017 Feb 19 at 4:56pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Design thinking, positive deviance, and lean start-up methodologies all anchor on engaging with a directed kind of curiosity in approaching new processes/problems/ventures. They all require an open and observant mindset. In positive deviance, the process of problem solving is grassroots and bottom-up, centered on finding and highlighting already existing solutions. In design thinking, user empathy, problem modeling, solution prototyping, and iteration all define a very human approach to problem definition and solution. Similarly, the lean startup approach uses hypothesis testing to rigorously validate each part of a potential business model. Unlike design thinking, the lean startup doesn’t presume to understand customer needs and leans on testing more to validate solutions. Positive deviance pre-defines the problem where the others lean on hypothesis. Each methodology is situationally appropriate, but at their core lean on the same experimental, purposefully open and curious approach. At my previous employer, although not branded as such, we approached problems very much in a lean methodology. There was no real solution to any problem, only a series of hypotheses to be tested and a focus on validation prior to investing in and fully executing on any given technology project. The culture tolerated and even encouraged smart risks and failures (assuming they resulted from the disciplined formation and testing of hypotheses). We didn’t, however, spend as much time or create an environment where customer empathy (and emotional empathy) were at the center, and where constraint wins out over comprehensiveness. The organization lacked the patience for some of the finer points of design thinking that invest more in problem definition, and sped right to solutions. For IBD, design and lean thinking are hugely helpful in entering a space where you know very little and are operating with a ton of ambiguity. I’m curious if anyone in our class has experience using the concepts of positive deviance to solve a problem? It seems like a really valuable short term way to solve a problem, but I wonder if it works in the long run?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Go To Topic
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Edit
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Delete
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                • Open in SpeedGrader

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Design thinking, positive deviance, and lean start-up methodologies all anchor on engaging with a directed kind of curiosity in approaching new processes/problems/ventures. They all require an open and observant mindset. In positive deviance, the process of problem solving is grassroots and bottom-up, centered on finding and highlighting already existing solutions. In design thinking, user empathy, problem modeling, solution prototyping, and iteration all define a very human approach to problem definition and solution. Similarly, the lean startup approach uses hypothesis testing to rigorously validate each part of a potential business model. Unlike design thinking, the lean startup doesn’t presume to understand customer needs and leans on testing more to validate solutions. Positive deviance pre-defines the problem where the others lean on hypothesis. Each methodology is situationally appropriate, but at their core lean on the same experimental, purposefully open and curious approach.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                At my previous employer, although not branded as such, we approached problems very much in a lean methodology. There was no real solution to any problem, only a series of hypotheses to be tested and a focus on validation prior to investing in and fully executing on any given technology project. The culture tolerated and even encouraged smart risks and failures (assuming they resulted from the disciplined formation and testing of hypotheses). We didn’t, however, spend as much time or create an environment where customer empathy (and emotional empathy) were at the center, and where constraint wins out over comprehensiveness. The organization lacked the patience for some of the finer points of design thinking that invest more in problem definition, and sped right to solutions.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                For IBD, design and lean thinking are hugely helpful in entering a space where you know very little and are operating with a ton of ambiguity. I’m curious if anyone in our class has experience using the concepts of positive deviance to solve a problem? It seems like a really valuable short term way to solve a problem, but I wonder if it works in the long run?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Emily Gordon

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Feb 20, 2017 Feb 20 at 8:01pm
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    I agree with your last sentiment Laura. I'm curious how positive deviance can be used effectively. It seems to me that it could potentially lead to a lot of biases and that there would be a challenge differentiating causation and correlation.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Manage Discussion Entry
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    • Go To Parent
